—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Watsonia Army Barracks, Victoria
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that . . .

1. The Watsonia Army Barracks contains electronic communication facilities, operated by Australian and American personel, that gives the United States the ability to pin-point Soviet nuclear submarines, hidden in the Oceans.
2. This would make it possible for U.S. killer-submarines to destroy all Soviet nuclear submarines, while the U.S. nuclear submarines launch their missiles in a ``first strike'' attack.
This makes Watsonia a potential nuclear target. A nuclear attack on Watsonia would have a disastrous effect on Melbourne.
3. The ``joint U.S.-Australian'' bases in Australia endanger rather than protect us. They also add a new menace to nuclear arms race, that must be stopped.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should close the ``Joint Australian-U.S.'' Electronic Communication Facilities in the Watsonia Army Barracks.

PETITION.TITLE: Gold Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
the gold mining industry is a vibrant expanding industry which provides employment for many Australians;
the gold mining industry provides valuable export income which contributes to a stronger balance of trade and Australian dollar, and thus a higher standard of living for all Australians;
the Federal Government's proposal to introduce a tax on gold mining represents a threat to an industry which is vital to Australia's future; and
we call on the Federal Government to withdraw its proposal for a tax on gold.
As in duty bound you petitioners will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Commercial Sponsorship
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of the Commonwealth Parliament assembled
The petition of these residents of the Commonwealth of Australia Respectfully showeth
That the Australian Broadcasting Corporation provides the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia with the only radio and television service
That the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation must be preserved in the interests of the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia
That the introduction of commercial sponsorship or any form of advertising material from commercial sources, would destroy the independence of the Corporation.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Honourable Senators will oppose the introduction of any form of sponsorship or advertising material from commercial sources into the programmes of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Childs (from 3,240 citizens) and Maguire (from 29 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Casino, Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) That we are totally opposed to the proposal for the establishment of a gambling casino in Canberra or the Australian Capital Territory.
(2) That a casino in Canberra would detract from the unique character and status of our National Capital.

Your petitioners therefore most humbly request the Senate and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to reject any proposal or legislation which would permit the establishment of a casino in the Australian Capital Territory.
And your humble petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the House assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That we most strongly oppose the process of `food irradiation' by Cobalt 60, Caesium-137, Caesium-134 or any machine sources.
That we oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process being permitted by State Governments.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Federal Government ban the importation of any radio-active substances or machinery for the purpose of food irradiation, disallow regulations permitting the irradiation of food in Australia, and ban the irradiation of food in this country.
We also call upon the Federal Government to withdraw from the Asian Regional Co-operative Project on Food Irradiation and the International Consultative Group on Food Irradiation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Isabella Plains Catholic Secondary School, Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows that:
1. They are concerned that in the Tuggeranong Valley area of the A.C.T., no non-government schools have Year 11 and 12 places.
2. They want the new Catholic secondary school to be built at Isabella Plains to go to Year 12.

The petitioners request that the Senate in parliament assembled ensure that adequate resources are provided by the Government to allow Year 11 and 12 places to be provided at the Catholic Secondary School at Isabella Plains in accordance with the Government's commitment to a dual system of education and greater school retention to Year 12.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Health Promotion Foundation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We, the undersigned,
(i) are alarmed that many sporting, cultural and community groups have been made to feel that they can attract sponsorship only from promoters of unhealthy products;
(ii) call for a National Health Promotion Foundation to be established through an increase in tobacco excise of 10 cents per packet; and

(iii) urge that the National Health Promotion Foundation provide national sporting, cultural and community groups with alternative sponsorship funding so that these groups can flourish without the taint of accepting money from tobacco companies and assisting in the promotion of their unhealthy products.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Peter Baume (from 111 citizens) and Reid (from 100 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Skateboard Ramp, North Canberra
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The people of the North Canberra Community would like to have a community skateboard ramp built in the old North Canberra area. There are keen skateboarders in the area and at present they have to catch four buses to use the Woden facility, which is expensive, time consuming, and too dangerous a trip for the younger children.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Skateboard Ramp, North Canberra
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:

That in the suburbs of Higgins and Holt there are a number of skateboard riders. Being teenagers they are not fully appreciative of the consequences of riding upon footpaths, roadways and shopping centre open areas.

To avoid a fatality or a serious injury occurring, we the petitioners seek the construction of a skateboard area in the parkland boarded by Mockeridge, Eaves, Cazaly, Griffin and Beaurepaire roadways in the suburb of Holt.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Release of Confidential Medical Information
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we express grave concern about the public release of confidential medical information by the Government, sufficient to enable the public identification of doctors and their patients and calls upon the Parliament to censure all those involved in this gross abuse of the privacy of all Australians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Drugs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens showeth:

that your petitioners deplore the Federal Government's decision to remove 53 pharmaceutical drugs, including the best available for the treatment of high blood pressure, cancer, epilepsy, high cholesterol and uneven heartbeat, and place them for cost saving reasons only on a special list requiring authority from a Canberra bureaucrat, and

that we believe a patient's doctor is clearly the best judge for medication needed for their particular illness and that it is therefore wrong and unfair to force that doctor to waste valuable time referring a case to a person in Canberra who has no personal knowledge of that case.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled will call on the Government to immediately abandon the proposal and keep its election promise of high quality and universal health care for all Australians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitution: Proposed Changes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That the Constitution of the Commonwealth has served Australia well, is not out of date, has proved to be flexible and should not be radically altered.

2. Our deep concern that the recommendations of the Constitutional Commission and its Advisory Committees which propose radical changes to the Constitution are threatening to reduce out rights as citizens of the Commonwealth.

3. our strongest opposition to any referendum proposals of the Hawke Government which give more power to the Government and less to the people which concentrate that power in Canberra at the expense of the States and weaken the role of the Senate.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aborigines: Treaty
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
that Australia is one nation which comprises people from many different racial and cultural backgrounds;
that a Treaty with one of these peoples-the Aborigines-would be divisive and would be equivalent to the setting up of a separate nation;
that a Treaty could lead to the introduction of a national system of land rights;
that we are totally opposed to the signing of a Treaty with the Aboriginal people.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Helsham Inquiry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That the Federal Government decision to ban future development in 80% of the Helsham inquiry area and rob Tasmanians of hundreds of jobs in the forest and associated industries is wholly unacceptable.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should ensure that the Federal Government abide by the majority decision of the Helsham inquiry.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: In-vitro Fertilisation Patients: Medicare Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the President and members of the Senate in Parliament.
The petition of the undersigned shows a request for Medicare benefits for in vitro fertilisation for the medical treatment of infertile couples.

Your petitioners pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled grant Medicare benefits for in vitro fertilisation, IVF, for the medical treatment of infertile couples. 1 in 10 Australian couples are infertile and unable to conceive and carry a baby to birth. Having a family is one of the most fundamental and rewarding aspects of life and benefits the community as a whole. IVF is an established and proven treatment for infertility. There are existing mechanisms to regulate and control IVF, including the National Health and Medical Research Council and the Reproductive Technology Accreditation Committee. Currently IVF patients pay up to $1500 per treatment cycle for IVF out of their own pockets. This means that some couples who need IVF to help them establish their own family do not have access. We request that Medicare funding be granted for IVF for the treatment of infertility, and your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Overseas Aid
PETITION.PARA: To the President and members of the Senate in Parliament Assembled.
We your petitioners do humbly request that the Government.
redirects overseas aid programs to the poorest communities, countries and regions
increases overseas aid, as a percentage of G.N.P., to achieve the United Nations target of 0.7%, and
restores funding to the International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD).

Australia stands disgraced internationally. Despite global recessionary trends no other Western country has cut foreign aid to the same degree. The Development Assistance Committee of OECD has expressed regret at Australia's drastic cuts and urged it to resume real increases in aid. Of 141 member countries Australia is the only one to withdraw support from IFAD.

PETITION.TITLE: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. That it be recognised the proposed Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill is a public, legal acknowledgement that Australians who are non-aboriginal do not have sovereignty in their own country.

2. That the Australian people are opposed to the idea of a treaty, compact or makarrata between the Australian people who are non-aboriginal and those who are aboriginal, and the Government has no mandate or authority to pursue it.
3. That the proposed legislation and treaty-
will damage Australia's position under international law and in any conflict,
will cause distrust and conflict between our aboriginal population (1%) and the non- aboriginal population (99%),
will extend aboriginal land rights, contrary to the wishes of the Australian people,
will not be acceptable to the aboriginal people themselves,
will solve none of the problems of aboriginal people who need housing, health services, education and employment.

That, therefore, the Senate reject absolutely the announced proposals for an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill, and the negotiation of a treaty, compact or makarrata between the Commonwealth and aboriginal people.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND PUBLIC ADMINISTRATION'S FURTHER REPORT ON NON-STATUTORY BODIES

On 18 May 1988, the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration tabled a report on Non-statutory Bodies (NSBs), further to a report of August 1986 by its predecessor, the Finance and Government Operations Committee. The Government responded to the earlier report in December 1987, agreeing that information regarding NSBs should be made available but announcing that the information would be provided in annual reports rather than in a central register as well as in annual reports as the Committee had recommended. The Government's response also excluded some classes of bodies from those which were to be subject to the new requirements. In its further report, the Committee has again argued for a central register and objected to some of the exclusions.

It needs to be emphasised, first of all, that information regarding NSBs is to be made available. This Government had already increased the accountability of other kinds of public agencies; when it turned its attention to NSBs its decisions were consistent with the record it had established for open administration and effective reform.

In questioning the effectiveness of having information provided only in annual reports, the Committee says it found that roughly one third of departments had not explicitly included lists of NSBs in 1984-85, 1985-86 and 1986-87 reports, although such lists were even then required. The Government is concerned that all agencies should meet annual reporting requirements. The Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet wrote to all departments on 29 February 1988 asking them to ensure compliance with the new requirements regarding NSBs and to draw those requirements to the attention of other agencies in the respective portfolios.
There is also a reference to requirements for information about NSBs in the guidelines which departments are statutorily obliged to follow in preparing their annual reports.

Any difficulty there might be in tracking down reports of NSBs will be significantly reduced by the requirement that parent bodies, in their annual reports, list any NSBs of theirs which produce their own annual reports, showing to whom they are presented and whether they are tabled in the Parliament or made public in any other way. This requirement was written into the Government's response to Recommendation 16 of the 1986 report.

As well as reiterating its advocacy of a central register, the Committee has considered the question of whether it would prefer such a register to be current (that is, continuously updated) or annual. It decided in favour of a current register, even though Professor Hood, the outside expert whom it consulted and whose opinions it cites as authority for its own, is reported only to have `inclined to the idea of a register updated and published annually'.

A current central register would be a trap, creating expectations of reliability but never truly current; liable, rather, to dangerous inaccuracies, as the central compiling agency would be dependent on other agencies for information and those agencies would be removed from direct responsibility for the accuracy and currency of information appearing in the register. In these circumstances, it would take constant intensive effort on the part of the central agency to achieve anything approaching accuracy and currency.

This is not to say that the central agencies simply cannot be bothered to make the necessary effort, preferring instead to abdicate their responsibilities. In the first place, when we talk about effort we are talking about resources; in the second, no agency should undertake a task that could be handled better by others; and in the third, detailed information about NSBs is to be made available. The Government has clearly and consistently shown that its responses on the subject of NSBs have been based on considerations of economy and efficiency and accountability. To sacrifice any one of these criteria would be irresponsible.

In relation to an annual register, supplementary to annual reports, there is nothing to be added to the Prime Minister's comments in paragraph 5 of his letter of 11 February 1988 (reproduced entirely in the Committee's report):

Given that . . . some information at least will need to be provided in annual reports, the Government decided to avoid the duplication and waste of resources that the creation of a central register would entail. In reaching this decision, the fact was borne in mind that your Committee and other people wishing to examine NSBs would need to consult a collection of annual reports anyway, whether or not a register also existed. The sensible decision in the circumstances was to make annual reports the comprehensive source of information.

The Government believes that the requirement to provide information in annual reports will be effective. In fact, annual reports will be more reliable than a central register would be, as responsibility for the accuracy of information they contain will rest directly with the source of the information. The new arrangements will significantly increase the usefulness of annual reports, including their usefulness to agencies such as the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet which, as Senator Coates has observed, need to be able to draw on information about NSBs in preparing advice for the Government.

Finally, in relation to the classes of bodies excluded from coverage by the new requirements, it should be observed that separate reporting requirements apply to government companies. Information regarding Royal Commissions is already available in the annual reports of the Department which services them (formerly the Department of the Special Minister of State, now the Department of Administrative Services). The activities of other excluded classes are most appropriately reported in the context of reports of the activities of their parent bodies.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are now debating two Bills, one Bill introduced by the Government through Senator Ray, the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1988, the purpose of which Bill is to allow for the appointment of scrutineers by registered political parties at the forthcoming referendums on 3 September. The second Bill we are debating is a Bill introduced by me, namely, the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) (Informal Ballot-Papers) Amendment Bill, which is designed to put beyond doubt the question of what method of voting is formal and what is informal at the forthcoming referendum.

SPEECH.PARA: I will deal firstly with the Government's Bill. In doing so, I welcome Senator Ray's proposal to amend the scrutineer provisions of the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act. This Bill will give each registered political party as defined in the Commonwealth Electoral Act the right to appoint one scrutineer during the voting and one during the count at each polling booth. Only because the Opposition raised with the Australian Electoral Commission our desire to have scrutineers at the referendums on 3 September has this provision of the existing Act come to serious attention. Several weeks ago we raised with the Electoral Commission the question of how scrutineers would be appointed for the referendums. It was only then that it was discovered that the existing provisions of the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act were archaic and had been in the Act for 70 years or more. To our knowledge and, as I understand it, to the knowledge of the Government, the provisions have never been called upon when referendums have been held independently of general elections.

Section 27 of the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act provides for the appointment of scrutineers for the hours of the poll to be made only by the Governor-General and the Governors of the States-and in the case of the Northern Territory, of course, by the Administrator. Similarly, section 89 of the Act relates to scrutineers being appointed for the period of counting of the referendum votes. Again, only the Governor-General and the Governors of the States are enabled by the Act to appoint scrutineers. When we approached the Australian Electoral Commission about this matter, those provisions and the major practical difficulty in implementing them-to enable the political parties to appoint scrutineers for either the poll or the counting of votes at the referendums-came to light.

We believe that scrutineers are absolutely essential for referendums such as the forthcoming ones on 3 September. There are several reasons for that. There are four questions on the ballot paper for the 3 September referendums, all of which will require a careful validity check. There are numerous combinations of answers to the four questions that could be given. So far as the parties involved are concerned, for the count to be conducted without scrutineers would be extraordinarily difficult. The present provisions, as I have said, are archaic and not workable in the present situation, when we believe scrutineers are essential. It is important that the provisions relating to scrutineers be attended to so that they can come into effect in time for the September referendums.

The Opposition supports several aspects of the Bill but would seek to amend it essentially with procedural changes. It does appear that the Bill, as presently drafted, would enable only one scrutineer to be appointed for the period of the poll and only for each polling centre for the period of counting. It would be very difficult for a political party to have only one scrutineer, if there were several counting tables. One of my amendments, which I have circulated and with which I will deal briefly in the committee stage, is designed to cover that.

Also, the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Bill as presently drafted enables only the registered officer or his deputy from a registered political party to do the appointing of the scrutineers. We suggest that that is a little restrictive and that they ought to be able to appoint nominees to in turn appoint the scrutineers. There was also one other technical aspect, which would enable the rotation of scrutineers during the 10 hours that the poll is open for voting. These amendments essentially are procedural and I hope the Government will not have difficulties with them. I have circulated those amendments and I will address them, as I have said, in the committee stage.

More importantly, I would like to deal with the issue of informal ballot papers. That provision is dealt with in the Bill that I have introduced, namely, the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) (Informal Ballot Papers) Bill. The purpose of that Bill is to amend the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act to make it unequivocal that the only valid vote at a referendum is one which has either the word `Yes' or the word `No' standing alone in the space provided on the ballot paper. The Australian Electoral Commission, acting on the advice of the Attorney-General's Department, has ruled that certain combinations of ticks and crosses will be allowed as valid or formal votes at the forthcoming referendums. Certain other combinations will not be allowed as formal votes. This will be the first time that ticks and crosses have ever been accepted as formal votes at referendums.

We believe that the instructions and advice that the Australian Electoral Commission has received in relation to which ticks and crosses and combinations of those will be granted as formal or informal is, whether intentionally or not, very heavily biased in favour of the Yes vote at the forthcoming referendum. The advice that the Attorney-General's Department has provided is in response to a sample package of nine possible combinations of yeses and noes and ticks and crosses that the Electoral Commission submitted to the Attorney-General's Department for an advising. Of the combination of the nine sample proposals that were submitted for an advising, there were 11 ticks and 13 crosses. The Electoral Commission has received advice from the Attorney-General's Department that, in that case, all of the 11 ticks would be regarded as valid or formal votes of a yes nature. In other words, 11 ticks equal 11 yes votes. Of the 13 crosses that were submitted for advising, only five would have been accepted as a formal no vote and the remaining eight-well over 50 per cent-would have been regarded as an informal vote.

Instructions to give effect to the advising of the Attorney-General's Department have now been included in the guidelines that the Australian Electoral Commission has sent to polling booth officials for the referendum. We believe that that is totally incorrect and that the Act ought to be amended so that it is unequivocal that formal votes can only be those votes which have a yes vote clearly recorded in the square provided. Section 24 of the existing Act states:
The voting at a referendum shall be by ballot and each elector shall indicate his vote-
(a) If he approves the proposed law-by writing the word `Yes' in the space provided on the ballot-paper; or
(b) If he does not approve the proposed law-by writing the word `No' in the space so provided.
That sounds clear and unequivocal, but there is another section of the Act, namely, section 93 which, amongst other things, states:
Effect shall be given to a ballot-paper of a voter according to the voter's intention, so far as his intention is clear.

Various court cases have suggested that the wording of the Act as it is presently framed permits certain methods of voting on the ballot paper other than an unequivocal yes or no to be regarded as formal votes. There is a great deal of confusion in the community as to what constitutes a formal vote, particularly in light of the instructions that have now been issued to polling booth officials by the Australian Electoral Commission. An enormous number of queries have been received by my office about this matter. I know that all other senators and members have also received queries. However, there is not only confusion but also a great deal of concern because of the apparently biased nature of the outcome. As I say, whether that is intentional or otherwise is a matter that I will not debate here. The whole purpose of referendums is to allow Australians to have the chance to have their say on questions on which Parliament believes it cannot make a decision without a specific Australian voters' mandate. The whole purpose of referendums is to effect constitutional change. In that sense the voter's intention must be indisputably clear. This is not the case when ticks or crosses are accepted as formal votes.

The issue was first raised in the 1984 referendums when the Australian Electoral Commission was anticipating the prospect of a heavy write-in on the ballot papers. There were two questions and the dams case in Tasmania was running very strongly. The Commission was anticipating a very heavy no-dams write-in on the ballot papers. As a result of that, it sought advice from the Attorney-General's Department on that issue. It also sought advice on various other possible combinations of answers that might be provided. It submitted a number of samples on this to the Attorney-General's Department. One of the six samples at that time concerned ticks and crosses. In 1984 the Attorney-General's Department advice that ticks or crosses constituted formal votes when taken together arrived only two days before the referendum and it was too late to be taken into account.

As a result of that and other related matters, the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform had the matter referred to it by the Australian Electoral Commission and in 1986 that Joint Select Committee recommended that the Act should be amended to `clearly provide that only unequivocal yes and no answers should be regarded as formal'. That was a unanimous recommendation and subsequently all parties in this Parliament agreed to that. An attempt was made to resolve the matter earlier this year when the Government introduced various amendments to the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act 1984, one of which was intended to reflect the unanimous recommendation, which I have just mentioned, of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform.

The proposition that came to us was, in the view of the Opposition and in the view of the Australian Democrats, technically flawed because in our view it did not fully reflect the recommendations of the Joint Select Committee. As a result of that we, with the support of the Democrats, rejected that proposition when it was voted on, as it was rushed through in the dying hours of the last session. What we have proposed in the Bill now before the Senate is a form of words which, in our view, once and for all settles the issues of contention not only in relation to ticks and crosses but also in relation to any other markings that may be on the ballot paper. The intention-and I think the drafting achieves this-is to make it unequivocal that, in future, only a yes or a no written in the space provided on the ballot paper will constitute a formal vote.

I reject completely the claims that have been made by the Government and the Electoral Commissioner-and by others-that this problem has arisen simply because, for some reason, the Opposition and the Democrats were bloody minded in terms of their rejection of the Government's proposal back in May and June. I reject that completely because, as I said at that time, the Government's proposal was technically flawed and indeed the debate surrounding that issue at the time did not revolve around the question of ticks and crosses at all. The debate was concerned with other issues even though ticks and crosses were caught up in that matter.

We are proposing an addition to the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act to add a further subclause to section 93 of the Act to say that, so far as ascertaining the voter's intention is concerned, regard shall not be had to any ticks, crosses or other symbols but regard shall be had only to the word `Yes' or `No' standing alone in the space provided on the ballot paper.

The advising that the Attorney-General's Department gave to the Australian Electoral Commission is, in our view, very questionable. It said, as I have already said, that there were various combinations of ticks or crosses that would be regarded as formal votes and others that would be regarded as informal. In particular, it said that all ticks, and that example was given, would be regarded as formal votes, particularly if there were four ticks to the four questions-they would be regarded as four Yeses-but that if there were four crosses to the four questions they would be regarded as informal votes.

We have sought legal advice to comment in response to the Attorney-General's Department advice to the Australian Electoral Commission. Regrettably, the Commission itself has not, as I understand it, received independent advice other than that it received from the Attorney-General's Department. Weeks ago I called on the Electoral Commission to seek independent advice. My understanding is that it has not done that. We on this side of the chamber have sought legal advice from Mr Goldberg, QC, an eminent Melbourne QC--

TALK.START.PARA: —Who represented you--

—Who represented us very successfully in refuting the Government's dirty tricks campaign in relation to the Government advertising on the referendums. He is an eminent and well known QC. His advice to us is confirming of the Attorney-General's Department advice in relation to the crosses. His advice is that four crosses would be regarded as informal, but he says that it is a very different question in relation to ticks. I would like to take some time to read his opinion because I believe that it is very important indeed. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . in my opinion, it is arguable that the same conclusion-
in relation to four crosses-

should be reached in relation to a ballot-paper which comprises TICKS only or which comprises TICKS and YES responses. The Attorney-General's Department says that in such circumstances the TICKS denote approval in each case and that the voter's intention is not made any less clear by the appearance of the words YES and/or NO on the same paper as TICKS. However, can it be said that in such circumstances there is a clear indication of intention? The High Court made it clear in Kane v. McClelland (supra) that the intention must be so indicated that it is ``not left to inference, still less conjecture, that it is expressed or indicated in a way that leaves it indisputable.''

In my opinion the same observations apply to answers indicated wholly by TICKS or by a mixture of TICKS and YES responses. The Attorney-General's Department may in any given case be correct when it concludes that the voter's intention can be determined from TICKS or a mixture of TICKS and YES responses but this conclusion can only be reached by ``an inference and not a clear expression or indication of the voter's intention''.

For example, the indication by a TICK may simply mean an acknowledgment of the question without recognising the fact that there are alternative answers. In this respect it must be remembered that on the ballot-paper the elector is directed to write YES or NO in the space provided opposite each of the 4 questions and that under each box in which an answer or response is to be written there appear the words ``WRITE `YES' or `NO' ''. I ask rhetorically-why does an elector place a TICK or CROSS in the box immediately alongside the exhortation ``WRITE `YES' OR `NO' ''?

The answer in any given case must be inference or conjecture. Why would an elector who wants to vote `YES' or `NO' place either a TICK or a CROSS immediately next to that exhortation? Is it because he or she does not understand English or does not understand the question? Or is it because he or she either has no view or does not want to express a view? Or is it because the elector recognises that in order for the vote to be formal and valid the elector has to write `YES' or `NO' and because the elector does not wish to record a `YES' or `NO' vote the elector makes a deliberate decision to vote informally or invalidly. Any one, or perhaps more, of the hypotheses to which I have referred might apply in any given case, so that one is left to inference or conjecture as to the elector's intention. In such circumstances the High Court tells us in Kane v. McClelland . . . that the vote is informal and invalid.

That is because the voter's intention is not indisputable. That is the legal advice that we have received from Mr Goldberg. That is why we wanted the Electoral Commissioner to get independent advice. As I have said, our advice conflicts with that of the Attorney-General. Therefore, I believe that the legality of the situation and the legality of what the Electoral Commission is now putting out to polling booth officials are at least arguable.

The other thing I mention briefly is that, as I understand it from the Minister, Senator Ray, the Government has also received advice from the Attorney-General's Department that, even if this Bill of mine goes through the Parliament, it cannot have effect before 3 September because, somehow or other, the Attorney-General's Department believes that it would establish two classes of voter in relation to the referendum. I ask the Minister to table that very important advice. I believe that it is questionable but, until we see it, we are not in a position to comment on it definitively. But I make the comment, in the absence of having seen that advice, that in our view what is being proposed in this Bill is procedural, not substantive. It is not creating two classes of voter. It is not seeking to change the method of voting, simply the interpretation of a proportion of the votes that may be voted in ways other than as is indicated in the very clear instructions on the ballot paper. We are not seeking to change those instructions in any way. Those instructions are clear. As I said earlier, those instructions state that people should write either a `yes' or a `no' on the ballot paper. None of that is being sought to be changed in this Bill. On the contrary: this Bill reaffirms and reinforces the obvious clear intention of the Electoral Commission in the instructions that it conveyed.

On this issue I again urge the Government to seek some independent legal advice. In any event, I urge the Government to look again at the thought that it may allow this Bill either to go through the Senate but not through the House of Representatives or, if it goes through both Houses, to deem that it would not be applicable to the 3 September referendum. I urge the Government very strongly indeed to look at that again. The powers in relation to voting at referendums are such, because it is such a vital matter, that the intention of voters must be absolutely clear and they must be treated with respect.

In conclusion, I call on the Government to respect this issue and the integrity of our voting system by allowing the speedy passage of this Bill through both Houses of Parliament so that it can have effect on 3 September. The integrity of the voting system, the integrity of the Government and the integrity of the Electoral Commission, all of which are very important in any parliamentary democratic system, are vitally important and should be maintained. That integrity is at risk if this Bill is not passed and given effect in time for the 3 September referendum.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1988 and the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) (Informal Ballot-Papers) Amendment Bill 1988. I wish to address, firstly, the Government's Bill which is to amend the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act 1984 with regard to the item relating to scrutineers. This Bill seeks to amend section 27 of the principal Act. When one reads it, one is rather struck by the fact that it states that the Governor-General, or a person authorised by him to act under this subsection, may appoint one person to act as a scrutineer during voting at a referendum at each place in Australia where voting is being conducted. On any reading that is a pretty extraordinary provision. In fact, one wonders how it got there and how it managed to stay there. Presumably these things have either been lost in the mists of time or somewhere else. But one wonders how the poor Governor-General got roped into this exercise or why he has to delegate responsibility. In addition, there can be only one person acting as a scrutineer when, quite clearly, the rest of the Act proposes that there can be a yes or a no vote and, hence, at least two people could have some interest in the outcome. So I think it is quite reasonable to seek a change to the method by which scrutineers are appointed. However, I am not at all sure that either the Government's proposal or the Oppositions' proposal is really the way to go.

SPEECH.PARA: I have spent the last couple of months campaigning in my State of Queensland, almost every evening and sometimes two or three times a day, with regard to the four questions which are currently before the people. One of the points I have made at every one of those meetings is that we are debating in the community an item regarding our Constitution and we should not allow that item to become a matter of partisan politics. Undoubtedly, the political parties of the day will have a view. Those views will be expressed both in the Senate and in the electorate.

I have expressed the view that there is, and ought to be, a distinction between a debate about a constitution and a debate about the ongoing partisan matters of politics that we deal with on a day to day basis. I think it is quite clear why there is that distinction. In fact, the speech that the Governor-General made at the inaugural meeting raised a point that is pertinent to this. The Governor-General said that we are dealing with matters of partisan politics in the Parliament and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) echoed those sentiments. In fact, the Prime Minister added another item that I wish to refer to-that is, that in 200 years' time people might look back and think that not only our dress was rather quaint but also the items we were arguing about were rather quaint. I am not sure that I agree with that, having read some of the debates of the first meeting of this Senate. They seem remarkably fresh to me. Senators were still arguing then about protectionism and free trade. In 200 years' time most of the partisan political exercises will have passed on and will no longer be of concern. However, the Constitution will still be there and it will be of concern to those people. So we are dealing with two quite different matters. I think it would be destructive of genuine constitutional debate in this country if we allowed it to be overwhelmed by what we might see as our immediate partisan advantage. That is why I think that neither the Government's proposition nor the Opposition's proposition really address the matter of scrutineers.

I do not wish to steal Senator Harradine's thunder, but I understand that later in the debate he will be suggesting alternative methods of dealing with this matter. Might I say that the alternative method that would suit the Democrats would be not to have the political parties appointed to appoint scrutineers. To do that seems to me to be inappropriate and it would run counter to the proposition of having a referendum debate about the Constitution. Currently clause 27 more closely reflects the type of thing that we would want. It does not specify political parties as the people who will appoint scrutineers; it proposes that others may do so.

One group who may have an interest in this matter and could be the people selected to appoint scrutineers are members of the Federal Parliament. They are already in the act with regard to the proposing of the Yes and the No cases. I think it would be appropriate for those people, proponents of the Yes vote and of the No vote, to have the opportunity to appoint scrutineers. I remind the Senate that in the last major round of constitutional proposals under the conservative Government in 1977 a considerable number of members of the Liberal Party of Australia, which was then in power, opposed some of the referenda proposals and campaigned against them. In my view, those people had a legitimate right to appoint scrutineers to go into the polling booths to scrutineer with regard to the No vote, whereas the Liberal Party-the party in government, the party proposing these changes to the public-would obviously have wanted to support the Yes case and to appoint scrutineers to look at the Yes votes. I think there is an argument for suggesting that having the political parties appoint scrutineers is not the right track to go down.

If Senator Harradine brings forward proposals to take the appointment of scrutineers out of the hands of the political parties and to place it in the hands of members of the Federal Parliament, the Australian Democrats will lend their support to such a proposal. I ask Senator Tate, on behalf of the Government, to consider whether what the Government is attempting to do could also be met by such a proposition. It would not be disadvantageous to the Government, the Opposition or anyone else and would be the way to go if we were to have a constitutional debate separated as much as possible from the partisan political consideration of the day. I ask Senator Tate whether he might be able to respond in a positive way in the committee stage, if Senator Harradine moves amendments of that type. If he is unable to respond in a positive way, could he say why, rather than simply saying no? I know Senator Tate does not like simply saying yes or no, though I am sure he will do so on 3 September. I ask him to give the House some genuine reasons for the Government's opting to enable political parties to appoint scrutineers rather than, for example, members of parliament, constituted, possibly across party lines, to write the Yes No booklet and thus probably the more appropriate people to appoint scrutineers to look at the ballot papers for the Yes and No votes.

I come to the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) (Informal Ballot-Papers) Amendment Bill. I say again that there is a good reason why this chamber has Standing Orders. Honourable senators are now expected to debate a Bill that was introduced a little over an hour ago. To me this is absurd. Senator Short spent a great deal of his half hour quoting various legal advices with regard to the nuances contained in the current Bill. He then asked senators to support the amendment. With regard to his amendment, the Australian Democrats have not had the opportunity to seek independent legal advice. Senator Short simply asked us to support it on face value. The last time a proposition came to this chamber with regard to changing an item of the Yes and No cases, as Senator Short correctly said, the amendment was rejected. It was rejected by the Opposition and by the Australian Democrats because we believed that it did not clarify the situation but made it more murky. I would like some time to consider this proposal and to seek legal advice to see that it actually does what Senator Short says it will do. He has said, `Take my word for it; it does'. With due respect to Senator Short, I am not going to do that. I am not going to indicate on behalf of my party that we support the proposal until we have had time to consider the Bill. The Standing Orders provide for the introduction of a Bill on one day and at least a day to pass before we are required to debate it. This gives us time in a calm and collected way to get the type of advice we may want to get and to do the type of research we may want to do.

I have not had a chance to go over again the debates that we had earlier this year, to refresh my memory with regard to them or to re-read the report to which I was a signatory with regard to why we wanted clarification of this particular section. I clearly remember the discussions in the committee on that matter, but I always prefer to refresh my memory of details before agreeing to changes of this type. Any citizen reading the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Bill, which I am sure some citizens do-though I cannot imagine who they would be-would read clause 24 as stating clearly that, if one wishes to vote in favour of the proposition, one writes `yes' in the space provided on the ballot paper or, if one does not approve of the proposed change, one writes `no'. That seems relatively clear. However, the lawyers have once again wandered into the area and one now finds that somehow or other ticks and crosses are acceptable. I do not wish to put myself forward as a bush lawyer in these exercises. Clause 24 seems to me to state clearly that one should write `yes' or `no' and the ballot papers state clearly that one should write `yes' or `no', yet somehow ticks and crosses are to become acceptable. But that is the way of the law.

I heard Senator Short say also that the Government had mentioned to him, and I heard it a few minutes before I had to stand up in this chamber and speak in the debate, that there was a legal opinion that the passage of this law was not acceptable because, while clarification is needed-why the Government sought clarification and the Opposition now seeks clarification and the Australian Democrats have sought clarification-we are not necessarily agreed on what is clarification of the particular exercise.

Over and above that, the Government seems to have had advice which says that if this proposal is enacted it will create two groups of voters, one group consisting of those who have already voted and the other those who have not yet voted. In the first group I include some members of my own family who have voted already because they will not be in Australia on the polling day. They sought advice from me as to what they should do and, naturally enough, I urged them to vote in a particular way and to go off immediately and vote that way by means of a postal vote. I do not know whether they took my advice. They do not on many things, so I imagine they did not on this occasion. Some people have already voted. If the Parliament changes the law in the middle of the poll, some people will be able to use ticks or crosses. I seek some clarification from Senator Short as to whether that is the case. Perhaps he will answer that later in the debate. I have not seen the Government's advice to which the honourable senator referred, which is a reason why I do not think that the debate should be on now.

However, as I understand it, two types of voters will be constituted-those who have already voted and those who are going to vote. There do not seem to be any transition provisions in Senator Short's Bill which would deal with that matter. I wonder what he would propose, on the day itself, to those seeking to count the ballot papers. Would there be any confusion in view of the fact that some people would be acting under one law and, presumably, others would be acting under another?

I do not know whether that is the advice of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) or whether it is pertinent, but it seems to me that, if that is the case, there should be some transition provisions in the Bill to accommodate that. Or does Senator Short propose that those who may have had acceptable intentions on the advice which was provided previously and which was publicly available-that is, if they were attentive viewers of things political they would know that a tick was said by the Attorney-General's Department to be counted as a yes-would put a tick? However, if this Bill is passed, that ballot paper will be declared invalid. I understood Senator Short to say that he did not agree with the Attorney's previous position, but the people out there may have taken that advice. This Bill will disenfranchise those who have already voted. I do not know whether that is the substance of the advice. I would have liked to have read it before I had to stand on my feet and speak about it, which is why I reiterate that we have Standing Orders to enable us to deal with such matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen it either.

—That is why I cannot indicate support from the Australian Democrats for the proposition. We will not vote against it, but we will not support it. I believe that the issue should be considered at a time when we have all been able to read the advices and have got other legal advice to make sure that what we are doing is not further muddying the waters but is doing something which the Opposition, the Government and the Australian Democrats want to do; that is, make sure that it is perfectly clear what a person has to do when he or she votes in a referendum. I understand that very few people listen to the debates now because they cannot find the broadcast on the new channel. Some senators have the luxury of hearing the chamber's proceedings in their rooms, but for some reason I cannot do so in my room, so I have to sit in here. I urge people who are listening to this debate on the radio to follow clause 24; that is, if they are voting yes, to put a `yes' in the box and if they are voting no to put a `no' in the box, and ignore the lawyers.

SPEECH.PARA: I am satisfied that the overwhelming majority of the Australian population know the difference between yes and no and are able to make up their own mind: they do not have to resort to crosses and ticks. But I do foresee a difficulty in that respect with Senator Short's Bill. It is a difficulty which I would have liked to have had a chance to discuss with him and to seek further clarification on. I am unable to do that. It is on those grounds that I am unable to express support for the Bill. I want the matter to be clarified, but I want to make sure that what Senator Short proposes actually gives that clarification. On my reading of it, it does do so. Putting aside the other problem of the two classes of voters, on my reading of it, it does do so. However, my reading of clause 24 suggests that one should put in a `yes' and a `no', but the lawyers seem to think something different. The lawyers probably think that there is something different in the proposal; I do not know. They seem to get extraordinary things out of plain English. I would like clarification that it is a watertight provision and that it is the type of thing which one would want to insert in the Act so that we would fix it up once and for all.

If an amendment were moved to the Government's Bill which would take the scrutineers out of the hands of political parties and put them into the hands of people such as members of Federal parliament or whoever, we would support such an amendment. That follows through with the items that I have been arguing; that is, the theme through this machinery legislation is that members of parliament vote yes and members of parliament vote no. An issue may cross party lines, as was the case with the Liberal Party in 1977. It seemed quite legitimate that members of the Liberal Party were able to appoint scrutineers in 1977 to look at the No case or the Yes case, which- ever they supported, whereas officially the Liberal Party supported one line or another.

In Queensland the Liberal Party supports a Yes vote for No. 2. However, federally the Liberal Party supports a No vote for No. 2. I think that the Liberal Party in Queensland may want to appoint scrutineers on both sides. This exercise suggests that they will appoint one person at each polling booth, whereas it may be that on 3 September members of the Liberal Party in Queensland may wish to have two people from the party in the polling booth as scrutineers-one following the State Liberal Party line of voting yes and the other following the Federal Liberal Party line of voting no. That is legitimate in terms of the appointment of scrutineers. It is not allowable under the Government's provision or the Opposition's provision. I think that it should be because it reflects the reality of the voting on 3 September. If Senator Harradine were to move such an amendment-I understand that in the labyrinth of this place he is trying to get one together-the Australian Democrats would support such an amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose I should start my speech on the Bill to amend the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act 1984 and Senator Short's Bill regarding the method of voting and informal ballot papers by raising some of the issues that Senator Macklin has mentioned. In his pontificating on this issue, as the Australian Democrats are always inclined to do, he talked about the appointment of scrutineers and of it being a political matter-that the Liberal Party of Australia, the Australian Labor Party and any other political party that might pop its head up should not be singled out to be appointing scrutineers. I suppose that in some respects that would be quite all right in the referendum if all things were fair and equal in the debate, but that, as we know, is not so. The Government has been caught with its hand firmly wedged in the dirty tricks cookie jar over this whole referendum issue. We need to cite only a few, among many, instances. One was the biased advertising that the Government tried to sneak through on television.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I entered the chamber only during Senator Macklin's address, but I understand that Senator Short kept strictly to notions of relevance in this debate, which is not to deal with the general issues but to deal with the specific matters of scrutiny-ticks and crosses and so on. It would be very helpful if the Chair were able to ensure, as I am sure you would be inclined to do anyway, Madam Acting Deputy President, that the canons of relevance were adhered to.

—I, like the Minister, only recently entered the chamber. In general terms, I always urge speakers to be relevant. I will listen to the debate and make a ruling should I believe that there is irrelevance.

—Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. It highlights the Government's sensitivity about what I am saying in relation to this matter and if the Minister would care to wait and hold his horses he will find that there is relevance in what I am saying. I am concerned with what Senator Macklin said about the appointment of scrutineers. We have seen this become a political project in the whole debate on the Constitution and I am sorry that it has had to become somewhat political as well. We have the instance, as I mentioned, of the advertising. We also have the instance of biased questions and we also now have the Bill about ticks and crosses and the marking of ballot papers. The Democrats have supported this referendum because of their short-term political gain that is likely to stem from abolishing the rotational system of electing senators.

SPEECH.PARA: We must remember that if we are to have a fair system on the day of the counting of these referendum questions we must be in a position where political parties can appoint scrutineers. To have the Governor-General and Governors and persons delegated by them appoint scrutineers is outrageously restrictive. I support Senator Short's amendment to the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1988, which allows for the registered officer of a registered political party or his nominees to appoint persons to act as scrutineers during voting at a referendum at each place in Australia where voting is being conducted, but not more than one scrutineer for each party being allowed at each polling booth at any one time. That is a very fair and reasonable request and a very fair and reasonable amendment. Therefore, I cannot understand for one moment why anyone would want to block that in any way.

It concerns me that the Government has indicated that Senator Short's Bill cannot have effect by 3 September according to its advice which Senator Short, being shadow Minister responsible for these matters, has not even seen. It is a very difficult situation and the advice on that issue relates to the ticks and crosses or the Yes and No. I will move onto that area because we have seen another case of bias where the instructions to the polling booth workers only have been such that they should accept votes with a tick and not accept votes with a cross, when in fact the sample ballot paper-and I have one here-clearly states `Directions to Voter: Write YES or NO in the space provided opposite each of the 4 questions set out below'. Senator Macklin has already said, `We are now going to create two classes of voters: those who have already cast their votes and those who haven't, if we accept Senator Short's Bill which only permits as a formal vote a ``Yes'' or a ``No'' '. That statement is simply untrue because people have not been, as he said, instructed or told that they can place a tick or a cross in the box. Those instructions have been given only to the polling booth workers and not to the people who have gone in to vote. If the people who have gone in to vote followed the directions on their ballot papers which, as I say, clearly indicates `Write YES or NO', the passage of this Bill, coming into effect prior to 3 September, makes sure that any vote with a `yes' or a `no', as per the instructions, is a formal vote. What is the problem with that? There is no problem. For the Australian Electoral Commission to be allowing a tick as a formal vote and a cross as an informal vote is duplistic in the extreme and quite unfair. In the first instance I do not know how people could be told to do this, but evidently people believe they have been told to do this. That is not so because the ballot papers are crystal clear in every way, right to the end where it says, `Answer every question'. I am sorry that those instructions are the only ones that are clear on the ballot paper because the four questions involved in the referendum are less than clear and can be considered very biased.

So Senator Short's Bill is particularly pertinent as is his amendment to the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1988. We in this Parliament must ensure that every fair opportunity is given to every elector, whether it be at a general election or whether it be at a referendum, that their vote is a valid vote and that we do not get the question all fuzzy around the edges, and that we do not start entertaining thoughts of ticks and crosses because this will only confuse the issue further. The specifics of it have been quite clear until recently when publicity was given to the fact that the polling booth workers were going to be allowed to grant the ticks and not the crosses. If that instruction had not been given to the polling booth workers we would not be in this position in the first instance. I urge the Senate to agree to Senator Short's amendment to the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Amendment Bill (No. 2) and also to his Bill regarding the method of voting, which is particularly important.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Government's Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1988 which amends the referendum legislation to provide for the appointment of scrutineers, an outcome which many members of the public and indeed many members of parliament had assumed was there anyway-of course it has not been. Therefore the urgency of achieving this in time for the important referendum in 10 days' time is one which the Opposition fully supports. It is essential that this legislation not only be passed here today but also be passed in the other place so that it can be given royal assent.

SPEECH.PARA: I am glad that we now have Senator Robert Ray and Senator Tate in the chamber, the two Ministers in this chamber most responsible for this matter, because I appeal to them to ensure not only that the full process of getting this Bill enacted is completed this week, but also that the Opposition Bill, which has a similar urgency and to which my colleagues Senator Short and Senator Knowles have spoken, concerning the clarification of what is a valid vote, what is a valid action in an elector marking a ballot paper, will be clarified before the referendum. I sound this warning-I do not make it as a threat: given the Government's commitment to both of these measures, if it says that the House of Representatives just did not get around to doing it by the 3 September referendum, in these 10 remaining days, and especially in the last remaining week, it will be a matter of maximum publicity and maximum attack upon the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did you vote in a division against it in June?
—There was no explicit reference to this matter before the Senate. It was rammed through in a matter of minutes.
—Have a look. Read Hansard.

—I am just saying sincerely that there was no conscious decision made by this chamber to make valid controversial interpretations of ticks and crosses in a referendum ballot. We now have the chance; we are now sitting and we have the legislation in front of us: we need to vote upon these matters here in the Senate this morning. There is an acceptance by the Opposition and by the Government that there is justice in the outcome of these two measures being the continuing law in these matters.

SPEECH.PARA: There is to be an important referendum on 3 September. I just warn the Government-I do not make threats. I am a member of the Opposition's task force on the referendum. I am also part of the advertising, the public meetings and the planning for the No case. I make it very clear what our position will be if there is any slippage on these two measures, if the Government says, `Well, we believe in these reforms, we agree they are important, we believe clarity must be given; but it is unfortunate that we will not be able to consider them to conclusion in the House of Representatives because of the pressure of other business'. I do not want to prejudge the outcome. I just make it clear that if there is any slippage we will make a clear political judgment about that slippage and the electorate will hear about it loud and clear. For the reasons which both the Government and the Opposition have put forward there needs to be full endorsement here in the Senate chamber today of both the Government's Bill with regard to scrutineers and the Opposition's Bill with regard to a valid vote and ticks and crosses not being acceptable as an indication of a voter's intention in the ballot.

I will not stray from the matter before us, but for a minute or so I want to explain why there will be public concern if these vital matters are not put into place. If they are not put into place the public can rightly say that one aspect of the referendum is rigged in favour of a Yes vote. The contention is that ticks would mean yes, crosses standing alone would mean yes, and ticks and crosses together would be invalid. I find that kind of standing interpretation, were we not to have this legislation, absolutely incredible. It so favours the Yes outcome-the Government is wanting that Yes outcome-that it is beyond belief that the public would not say that the Government's failure to act was so clearly in its naked self-interest that it was prepared to allow the rigging of this referendum to its own advantage. I do not want that to be said of anyone in this chamber but it will be said if these measures are not in place in time for the ballot.

The pattern of representations on this referendum issue has been described as deceit. The simple statements the Government uses on the ballot papers to describe the choices in these four referendum matters are correctly described as being so simple as to be misleading and deceitful.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. These comments relate to another one of Senator Short's Bills that really cannot be canvassed here. They really go beyond relevancy. Even in trying to reinforce the ticks and crosses issue I think the honourable senator is straying.
—I am listening to the debate closely and I urge all speakers to attempt to be relevant to the Bills before the chamber.

—The point I make is that very many people are alarmed when they read the four questions that will be on the ballot papers for this referendum. Of course, they need to be simple and brief. But when the people who have read the Yes case and the No case in the material distributed by the Australian Electoral Commission, which runs to some 15 or 16 pages, read the actual measures that will change the No. 1 law of Australia, the Constitution, and see the actual changes that are involved they will say, `This is not just a simple matter of four brief questions; this is a very complex matter with enormous implications for the No. 1 law of Australia'. The situation will be compounded if the Senate agrees that it is in the interests of justice to clarify scrutineering and to clarify what makes for a valid vote but the Government does not achieve that justice by getting the Bills through both Houses in the seven sitting days to go. It will be a major issue that will reverberate throughout the last week of the campaign. Advertising of the No case in the last week will be 10 times what it has been up to this point.

SPEECH.PARA: I come to the argument put forward by Senator Macklin of the Australian Democrats that by writing `yes' or `no' in the boxes provided opposite the four questions a valid vote will be recorded. He said that, despite that, there is an instruction to those who will be eventually counting the referendum votes that four ticks on the ballot paper may be interpreted as a Yes vote and that four crosses may also be interpreted as a Yes vote. Senator Macklin said that because of that instruction a tiny minority who have already registered an absentee vote, as is their proper right if they are to be absent on the day of the referendum, will have their ticks or crosses counted as a Yes vote if the law stands as it is now. But if between now and the referendum we bring in a just law to correct that situation, dear oh dear, ticks and crosses will not be counted as valid votes. Despite the fact that they were told on the ballot paper that a valid vote was only Yes or No, we have to stop this just measure so that a mere handful of ticks or crosses will not be declared invalid. I put it to Senator Macklin very clearly that that is a tortuous argument. It is picking at a speck in one's brother's eye and missing the beam in one's own eye. He finds a speck in a counting procedure that perhaps makes ticks and crosses valid, but by supporting a law which will advantage a Yes outcome, an outcome which he favours, he creates greater offence.

I conclude by fully supporting the Government's Bill with regard to scrutineers. I also foreshadow that I support, as does the Opposition, the amendments to be moved by Senator Short. I put it to Senator Ray that they are practical amendments. We all know polling booths very well in our experience as politicians. The amendments are practical measures to clarify procedure the Government wants to allow for the appointment of scrutineers. I also strongly urge this chamber not only to see, as it does already, the justice of Senator Short's Bill, the Opposition's Bill, with regard to what constitutes a valid indication of a voter's intentions in a referendum ballot, but to ensure that it is adopted here by this chamber this morning. I also urge the Government to ensure that it is adopted in the House of Representatives and enacted so that it becomes the basis on which the referendum is conducted on 3 September.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in favour of the Government's Bill, the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1988, in relation to scrutineers. Certainly it is highly desirable that there be plenty of opportunities for scrutineers to be present not only during the count, which is the place where I would be more familiar with the notion of scrutineers, but also in the course of the day and at the balloting. I must say that at the places I have tended to be on election day we have been flat out getting enough people at the polling booths, let alone--
—I thought you would be at the MCG or Waverley.

—It all depends, doesn't it? I hope that I will be able to combine both. But certainly the opportunity to have scrutineers during the day is a luxury that does not apply in many areas. Nonetheless, there is certainly a need to have scrutineers at the end of the day for the count. That will be well after the final siren has sounded and we can all be in proper attendance.

SPEECH.PARA: It is necessary that there be the opportunity for nominees of the representatives of the political parties to appoint scrutineers. Indeed, I would have thought that one needed perhaps to go further and allow for copies of authorisation forms to be acceptable so that those in remote country areas may be serviced by faxed authorisations. These matters should have been considered and dealt with some time ago. Certainly, given the Government's haste to get these referendum questions to the people, without waiting for advice from the Constitutional Commission or the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, this is perhaps just another example of the pitfalls that lie in the path of those who are determined to rush to judgment on these matters.

The ticks and crosses are a matter of much greater substance and a matter of concern to the Australian electorate. As I understand it from my colleague, Senator Short, who has had the carriage of this matter, in the last referendum the votes of some 17,000 people involved the application of ticks or crosses. That was in relation to two questions. This time around we are facing four. One simply does not know why people choose to tick or cross, but I for one cannot comprehend how the Government can suggest that there is a clear inference that they intend to vote yes or no when they deliberately ignore what appears on the ballot paper in two separate places. The ballot box has on it the words `write yes or no' and, in very clear and bold print, the ballot paper says `write yes or no'. So one has to be, I suppose, drunk, illiterate, blind, or--

TALK.START.PARA: —Contrary.

—Contrary. I was going to put it perhaps more strongly than that. If one were being perverse one might want to indulge in the luxury of disregarding the clear and explicit instructions. But for my money one should pay the penalty. If people are not prepared to write `yes' or `no', that is too bad. For those people who do not understand the system, again, that is one of the penalties they pay. I think they are a relatively small proportion of the population. I hope that everyone in this country is able to speak English to the extent of knowing the difference between yes and no and knowing that writing `yes' or `no' is a requirement when attending a polling booth.

SPEECH.PARA: I find it curious that the Government is now back-pedalling on this issue. My understanding is that all the political parties are in heated agreement that `write yes or no' means `write yes or no' and that it does not mean anything else. Therefore, it is desirable that there should, if necessary, be amending legislation to ensure that that is the only option available to electors. If we accept the Government's current position that somehow it is a bit late in the day for that, the consequence is that this confusion will continue. In the event of a close outcome, there may well need to be a challenge to the Court of Disputed Returns--

TALK.START.PARA: —Under the Act there is no Court of Disputed Returns.
—So it cannot be challenged?
—Yes, it can-by the States.
—Where? In the Supreme Court?
—In the High Court.
—In the High Court.
—I think you can bet that Queensland will have a go.

—It is all very well to say that one has one's legal options. Senator Ray, having given evidence in one notable Court of Disputed Returns case a few years back, would know what the costs are in those matters. It is highly undesirable to provoke litigation in that fashion. The Commonwealth ends up paying the tab in almost all instances. I regard it as a waste of taxpayers' money when the matter can be clarified in advance. The only argument which seems to be put forward at present is what I regard as the spurious notion that two classes of voters would be created because some people have already cast postal ballots. It confuses the notion of the casting of the vote and the status of the voter with the determination made on the vote. Whether or not one counts ticks or crosses does not affect the manner of the casting of the vote and, presumably, the intention of the voter. It cannot possibly be suggested that if this legislation went through it would somehow encourage more people to put a tick or a cross, or not to put a tick or a cross, because they became more acutely aware of the legislative pitfalls.

SPEECH.PARA: So we are really talking about a means of ensuring that the count is accurate, that it is fair and that it properly reflects the views of the voters. To say that because some votes have already been cast it is therefore not desirable to intervene halfway through will encourage perhaps more people than would otherwise be the case to ignore the explicit requirements on the ballot paper. I cannot for a moment imagine that one could demonstrate that those people who might already to date have chosen to ignore the `write yes or no' demand did so on the basis that somehow they thought that their vote would be regarded as valid. For their own purposes, their own reasons, they have chosen to ignore the direction. I think it is inconceivable that they did so deliberately, imagining that they had a legislative luxury and that their vote would be valid. Many strange things happen in polling booths and probably there are a great many fascinating explanations for them, but I cannot imagine that that is one of them--

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about them.
