—We do our best to ensure that not too many extraordinary things take place. That is perhaps one of the reasons why scrutineers are desirable during the day. But, as I say, it simply defies logic to suggest that the votes already cast might have been cast by persons who believed that their ticks or crosses would be counted as valid. They almost certainly have chosen for their own purposes to disregard the clear instructions. They either did not know what they were doing, misunderstood the system or were unclear in their intentions.

SPEECH.PARA: As the High Court has made very clear, and I think as Senator Short indicated from a reading of Mr Goldberg's advice, which I had the opportunity to peruse some days ago, one cannot leave the matter to inference, still less to conjecture. The intention must be clearly expressed or indicated in a way that leaves it indisputable. Mr Goldberg is able to demonstrate that there are quite a number of options that would explain why a voter does what he explicitly is told not to do. It may be because he or she does not understand English, or does not understand the question. It may be that somehow the voter thinks that because voting is compulsory his vote is not valid or his attendance is not regarded as complete unless he somehow puts an acknowledgment on the ballot paper. There are many hypothetical explanations, but ultimately they amount only to inference or conjecture.

If that is the case, I do not understand why Senator Ray continues to refuse to make available the legal opinion which he says he has on the matter. If the Australian public is to be left in this position of uncertainty, if persons are to go to the polling booths not knowing what interpretation will be placed on the count, not only by scrutineers but also by polling officers, it is incumbent upon Senator Ray to explain to the public why this should be.

I do not regard this notion of two classes of voters as valid. I do not think it is regarded as valid by others who have considered the matter-and certainly Mr Goldberg does not regard it as valid. I find it regrettable that this is yet another instance of the Government choosing to rely on its own in-house advice, in the face of what I think is the logic of the argument and the views expressed by others of repute. That is not the way in which to conduct a vote, certainly not in the circumstances where the Government is already on the ropes for a whole series of dishonest actions, such as the presentation of the booklet that has gone out to all households and the inexplicable abdication of responsibility on the part of the Australian Electoral Commission in not ensuring that there was a fair, equal and balanced presentation of the Yes and No votes.

This is against the background of the High Court of Australia telling the Government that its advertising campaign is out of order; the background of the Government very dishonestly suggesting that somehow the Constitutional Commission is the basis for these questions; and the background of these Bills being guillotined through the Parliament, with the timing being such that people go to the ballot box after two weeks of sittings when, as Senator Ray would say, some very important events are taking place on that Saturday afternoon and when a whole range of other factors militate against full and frank discussion of these issues.

The statute allows for a period of some six months to debate the issues, but they were rammed through the Parliament, with amendments, in about half that time. Against that background, it is very unfair to the Australian community if Senator Ray does not release that opinion so that the public can understand whether it has any validity. It is not good enough to say, `We have a piece of paper that someone in the Department has produced'. We have had high level advice from Mr Goldberg, who has impeccable credentials and a great success rate in this area. I just do not think it is a fair contest in that circumstance for the Government to somehow hold to itself an opinion which in every likelihood would not stand up to scrutiny in the light of day. If that is the way the Government wants to play it, so be it. But I think that is a totally inadequate outcome and a very unfair position to put the returning officers in.

If we are all in heated agreement that there is a need to eliminate anything other than a Yes or a No, let us get on with it; let us not be held up by any supposed legal technicalities, unless they are valid. And we can determine whether they are valid only if they are made available and can be thoroughly scrutinised and analysed. For my money, I have made it clear that I do not comprehend how one could say that there would be two classes of voters. There would simply be a clear, consistent and uniform decision being applied to all votes cast, whether they be cast prior to today or after today. It could not possibly affect the intention of voters-nor should it. I cannot for a moment imagine why any voter would be dissatisfied with an outcome that made it clear, as was intended in 1984 and thereafter, that the instruction `Write Yes or No' meant just that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is considering two Bills to amend the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act 1984. The first Bill, the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Amendment Bill (No. 2), proposed by the Government, seeks to determine who should be able to nominate scrutineers for the purpose of a referendum. The second Bill, the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) (Informal Ballot-Papers) Bill, comes from the Opposition and was introduced by Senator Jim Short. It attempts to clarify, beyond any doubt whatsoever, the intention of the voter in any referendum.

SPEECH.PARA: The first proposal seeks to overcome a problem that has existed for some considerable time in the legislation. That problem relates to the narrowness of the provisions concerning the appointment of scrutineers by the Governor-General. To that extent, the Bill is worth supporting. However, the Bill says that those eligible to nominate scrutineers are the political parties. That is where I diverge from the Government on this matter. I do so because referenda, of their very nature, are not specifically to do with political parties-the government or the opposition. I have been in this place for some time and I can well recall an occasion when I was one of only four persons to vote against a referendum proposal; I was not a member of a political party. That proposal went to the people and was rejected. Although I was one of only four in the whole of the Parliament, the House of Representatives and the Senate, the people agreed with what we had to say. From recollection, it was the nexus referendum proposal.

I go back one step further. Proposals that go to the people to change the Constitution, which is a fundamental document for our system of government, emerge from the Parliament in the debate in the House of Representatives and Senate chambers. They are voted upon by members of parliament. It may be that there is crossing of the floor, as there was in the case I mentioned before. It may be that members of parliament from different parties or from no parties make up the numbers for a Yes or No vote in the chamber. The legislation then provides that those parliamentarians who voted yes shall prepare the Yes case and the parliamentarians who voted no shall prepare the No case. It does not say that the parties to which those members of parliament who voted yes belong should prepare the Yes case or that those parties to which parliamentarians who voted no belong should prepare the No case. I repeat what the legislation says: it is for those members of parliament who voted yes or no, as the case may be, to prepare the respective cases to be put to the people; it is not for the government or the opposition.

It so happens that on this occasion the Government is trying to push these referendum proposals forward, and has done so in a manifestly deceptive way. We must then be careful, when dealing with this question of referendum machinery, to act with total fairness. I ask: Is it fair for a provision to be inserted in the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act which will exclude at least one member of the current Federal Parliament from appointing a scrutineer? Other Independents, elected as Independents, may be excluded in future years from appointing a scrutineer, because they happen not to be members of a registered political party or may be members of a registered political party but have been elected to this chamber, or the other chamber, as Independents.

During the committee stage I will move an amendment to the legislation which will delete reference to `registered political party' or `registered officer' and enable each member of the Parliament to appoint one person to act as a scrutineer during voting at a referendum at each counting centre in Australia where voting is being conducted. In my view, that is a fair way of proceeding in this regard.

As to the other Bill that we are considering-the Bill introduced by Senator Short-I think that Senator Short has a very valid point. It is absolutely vital when dealing with a question of importance such as this that the counters, the electoral officers, clearly know the intention of the voter. I will give the Senate an example. What does the returning officer do in regard to a square which has an `x' marked in it? How is that to be interpreted? We all know that in the majority of cases it would indicate overwhelmingly that the voter did not want that particular referendum proposal. I would like to inform you, Mr Deputy President-although I do not think you need to be so informed, because you are quite well aware of these things-that until very recently in some union elections an `x' meant support for a particular candidate. When a member of the union received the ballot paper he saw the words `mark with an ``x'' against the names of those candidates that you wish to see elected'. It is quite extraordinary. If, for example, one of those persons is able to mark the ballot paper with an `x', will his vote be counted as a vote in support of the referendum proposal or a vote against it? It is unclear.

Senator Short, quite justifiably, has attempted to overcome that sort of uncertainty by making it quite clear that a valid Yes vote will be one which has `yes' written in the box. A valid No vote will be a vote which has `no' written in the box. That overcomes any doubt whatsoever. I think that proposal deserves support, and it deserves support now. If Senator Short's Bill is not agreed to now, there will undoubtedly be confusion and dissension on the evening when the count is taken. If it is a close vote, it will very substantially affect the operation of government in this nation. If, for example, votes in one State are counted in a particular way and that State marginally supports the first referendum proposal, that will mean that the fixed term of the Senate will be abolished and that the Prime Minister of the day will have greater power to call early elections. That is a very important point. I believe that Senator Short's proposal is very timely. I acknowledge that the Government has enabled Senator Short to raise this matter so that it can be debated cognately. I think that was a fine gesture on the part of the Government. It remains only for the eminently reasonable proposal put forward by Senator Short to be supported.

Mr Deputy President, I am sorry that at this stage my proposed amendment relating to the Government's Bill has not been circulated, but it is quite simple. It proposes to delete reference to registered political parties and registered officers of political parties to nominate scrutineers and to insert, in lieu thereof, members of parliament. I think that is entirely just. By way of explanation, under the Government's legislation I would be able to nominate a scrutineer, but I understand that there is one person in this current Parliament who would not be able to do so. I am dealing not only with what happens now, but with what might happen in the future. I acknowledge, however, that what Senator Robert Ray said in his second reading speech is quite important; that is, that this amendment by the Government is not the be-all and end-all of the situation, that it is a temporary measure and that at some future time he will seek to have the matter referred to the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. I acknowledge that that is a sensible approach.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In reply-The issue of ticks and crosses was resurrected in a Press release by Senator Short. I will quote one line from it: `Now we have another episode in the Government's book of dirty tricks'. I think that is a gross distortion. I think that our record on ticks and crosses stands up to close examination. It is one example of the Opposition looking for side issues in the referendum rather than confronting the central issue. It raises advertising, ticks and crosses and scrutineers, or it says that we are interfering with the No case by correcting two or three typographical errors. Those are the sorts of issues and distortions which are perverting this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: I point to the fact that in June this Government attempted to introduce virtually the same amendment that Senator Short has introduced. It was passed in the House of Representatives. We considered it in the Senate, and we were rolled. It is not much use Senator Short starting to lecture us on ticks and crosses. Quite clearly, the Senate had an opportunity last June to settle the issue once and for all. Instead, reference is made to the fact that ticks and crosses never really came into focus in this chamber. Because of time constraints, when I addressed the matter I was relatively brief. I said:

The amendment arose out of contact between the Australian Electoral Commission and the Attorney-General's Department. Sample ballot papers were sent to the Attorney-General's Department and it found that one section of the legislation was probably in conflict with another. The section that we are proposing intends to clear that up.

I did not go further. I had already had private discussions with Senator Short as to what he intended to move and I had ascertained Senator Macklin's attitude. I knew that nothing I could say in the chamber would change those views. However, I am sure that a diligent shadow Minister, and diligent members, such as Senator Alston and the others who have spoken today, would have at least read the House of Representatives debate which preceded the Senate debate. This is what my senior portfolio colleague, Mr West, said:

I refer now to advice I have sought which I can relay to the chamber. The nature of that advice is that prior to the 1984 referendums the Australian Electoral Commission sought advice from the Attorney-General's Department in respect of the formality of certain hypothetical referendum ballot papers, including votes marked with ticks and crosses and with slogans comprising the words `yes' or `no' inside the voting square and a word or other words inside or outside the square. The advice supplied, first orally, on 29 November 1984 from the Attorney-General's Department and confirmed in writing on 21 December 1984 confirmed that section 24, prescribing the method of voting, should be read subject to section 93 (8), which deals with the saving of ballot papers where the voter's intention was clear.

This issue has been around since 21 December 1984. It was widely canvassed and discussed in the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform and, as a result of that, recommendations were made to the Parliament. Those recommendations were picked up in the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Amendment Bill 1988. They were put to this chamber, and we were rolled on them. So, when it comes to taking high ground I am a little sensitive to the sort of publicity given to the ticks and crosses issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have a bit of a nervous tic there.

—Senator Baume was another one who supported knocking over the solution to this problem three months ago. He has changed his mind again; that is not surprising. He is getting excited about the whole subject.

SPEECH.PARA: The real problem was that the shadow Minister here and Mr Reith in the other place never understood what the word `qualification' meant in regard to ticks and crosses and our amendment to the Act. If they had taken the time to read a decent dictionary definition, they would have understood our Bill, which came here in June 1988, would have covered it and would not have gone down the by-roads that they refer to as technical difficulties. The problem is that Senator Baume has sat in this chamber and heard that word used, but it has never been explained to him by his shadow Minister, by Mr Reith or by anyone else.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, you explain it, Minister.

—How can I? I did not have the technical difficulties. You were the ones who got up and said, `This has to be defeated because it is unclear and it has technical difficulties'. You never went on in your debates to properly expose, to our satisfaction, what those technical difficulties were, but I assume--
—You have admitted that you did not explain them.
—I did not have to explain them. I did not have any difficulties with the Bill.
—It was your Bill. If you were trying to get it through, you should have given an explanation.
—Senator Short asks me to delve into his mind, to give a rationale for his views not properly expressed. Not even Einstein could do that.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion on this point, the reality is that in June this year the Liberals bungled it. I think they bungled it in the House of Representatives on the basis of Mr Reith's original amendments which had to be pressed in the Senate. I think the Australian Democrats were quite happy to go along with the Liberals because they probably wanted ticks and crosses. We do not. We have made it clear, and I make it clear to this Senate chamber too, that when the issue came up again-there was no blame attached to the Australian Electoral Commission; it acts on the advice it is given-having raised this question as an issue I instructed the Parliamentary Counsel to draw up a Bill along similar but not identical lines to Senator Short's.

The only reason I have not proceeded with that is a refusal to continue with that legislation on the legal views-I do not say written opinion-and advice from the Attorney-General's Department that there would be problems in this particular area. Basically, the problem is its view that one could have two classes of voters. The attitude is that such an amendment would create two classes of voters-those voting on 3 September 1988 and those voting otherwise; that is, postal voters or pre-poll voters. There is some doubt as to the constitutional validity of such an amendment. Section 128 of the Constitution provides:
When a proposed law is submitted to the electors, the vote shall be taken in such manner as the Parliament prescribes.

This requirement could be taken to mean that the manner shall be that prescribed by law at the time when the proposed constitutional alteration is first submitted to the electors, thus ruling out any substantial amendment to the law during the voting period. The problem with that is that people are saying that, if that is the view, then we really have to take a risk and amend this law. That could throw the whole referendum into doubt and I am not willing to do that. Referendums are an expensive business. As I say, if we had not attempted to amend these areas in June, we may not have gone in with a clear conscience. But we did. I would be very interested to hear any other legal views on that particular matter.

I just want to put one other point on the record. I want to make this clear so that every parliamentarian understands it. It is an offence under the Electoral Act for anyone to advocate a tick or a cross. That should be understood by everyone here. It is an offence-I think the fine is $1,000-for anyone to advocate a tick or a cross and the instructions on the ballot paper in regard to this, in terms of yes and no, are very clear.

Let me go to one other point: what is the remedy if people are not satisfied with the current interpretation of the Act? That would be an appeal to the High Court on the basis of, I think, a State or the Northern Territory taking an appeal. I suppose a reality that we all accept in this chamber is that none of this will be relevant unless the voting is in the order-and I will be very generous-of between 53 and 47 per cent. If the result is outside that, I think we can assume that whether ticks and crosses are included or excluded is going to be an irrelevant factor.

Now we come to Senator Short's Bill itself. Talking about technical difficulties, on a close perusal of it we have another problem. At the moment the word `yes' or `no' does not have to be written in the square. Under Senator Short's proposal, on the face of it, it will have to be. If someone has actually written a `yes' in the square and crossed it out, having changed his or her mind as a result of a road to Damascus conversion, and then written `no' outside the square, under the way Senator Short's Bill is drafted, that would be excluded. I am sure that that is not the intention.

TALK.START.PARA: —They could go and get another ballot paper.

—Of course they could go and get another ballot paper. If all those people down at the Foresters Arms who are following the debate right now understand the technicalities of Senator Short's Bill, they will go up and say, `Under Senator Short's Bill carried in the Senate chamber, I demand another ballot paper'. But not even I have that much faith in his persuasion or in human nature.
—You really are stretching it.

—No; the reality is that very few people know that they can get another ballot paper in those circumstances. They would have thought that they could just put a correction outside the square, as one can with the ordinary ballot paper. Senator Short would know from scrutineering that a lot of people vote one way and, realising it is a mistake, black out the squares and then write their preferences outside the squares. I just argue that this would cause the greatest inconvenience in polling booths. Again it highlights the fact that these matters must be drafted with absolute precision.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's position is that we, in principle, do not support ticks and crosses. Our credentials are on the board from the amendments we moved last June. Our only reluctance to process this matter, either by Senator Short's Bill or by one of our own, is based on a view that it may be outside the legality of the interpretation of the Constitution at this stage. That is a problem, and one we have to take seriously, because we have no doubt at all that, if one or all of the referendums are successful on the basis simply of a surplus of ticks, the Queensland Government is going to challenge them. I agree with a comment made by Senator Alston that it is preferable always not to encourage litigation, to block all those avenues by having a perfect Act. I acknowledge that. In these circumstances where there is legal doubt as to whether one can create two classes of voters, whether one can amend the voting laws at a mid-way point--

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you had any independent legal advice?
—No, I have not, and it is not my job at this stage to seek such advice.
—Will you make your advice available?
—What I have said is that I am always open to new views and new considerations.
—What is wrong with putting it in the public arena?
—If I have a final definitive legal opinion I do. But, basically, these matters came to a head over the last three or four days. I have been given advice and I am accepting that advice at this point.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me move to the second of the Bills, the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) (Informal Ballot-papers) Amendment Bill 1988, which deals with scrutineering. It might seem strange for a government to want to amend scrutineering clauses eight or 10 days before a referendum. It is, but if we are guilty of not having amended any of these clauses, I point out that no-one has amended any of them since 1910. I will run through the history of this: in 1906 a provision was put into the Electoral Act that allowed governors of each State to appoint a scrutineer to a booth. When a similar referendum Bill not relating to that matter came before the House of Representatives, Mr Deakin-I think he is still high in the lexicon of the Liberal Party of Australia in terms of revered figures of the past-raised this question and said it was very unfair for the State governments to be able to appoint scrutineers when the Commonwealth could not do so. His views were overruled by the then Labor Government but it did not have a majority in the Senate. How history repeats itself; the first time is a farce, the second time is a tragedy. These things occur. In fact, the Bill was amended and we then had the Governor-General with the ability to appoint scrutineers.

I wonder why this has never come up before. I know why I have never wanted to scrutineer before. My first referendum was in 1967. Having spent eight hours at a booth there was no way that I was going to go in. In 1973 the Labor Party was supporting both the yes and the no cases. There was a blue and so it was not required. I recall that on the night of the referendum in 1977 I went to a wedding. On the other occasions there were referendums they were held in conjunction with general elections and I dare say that people scrutineered the referendum illegally on those nights. So this has never occurred to anyone. I wrote to both Mr Bowen and Mr Reith-this refers to the ticks and crosses and other areas-as I realised that there would be some controversy and that people may want these areas scrutinised so that they know what the facts are. I wrote to Mr Reith and Mr Bowen, I think on 21 July. I got a very prompt response from Mr Bowen saying that we may or may not want scrutineers. Mr Reith was a little slower in replying and I found his first reply confusing. As it turned out, we really ran out of time in terms of using the provisions of the current Act. It was virtually impossible to organise the State governors or the Governor-General to do it fairly.

What do we do in Queensland? Do we say that we will have a National Party scrutineer for the No vote, a Labor Party scrutineer for the Yes vote and an each way bet for the Liberal Party because we are allowed only two scrutineers per booth? Who do we exclude in those circumstances-the Labor scrutineer, the National scrutineer or the Liberal scrutineer?

TALK.START.PARA: —What happens with regard to the normal vote?

—The provisions for normal voting are absolutely contrasted. We are allowed one scrutineer per candidate per counting centre within the booth. These provisions state that we are allowed one scrutineer per booth by the Governor-General or one by a governor. So we could have a maximum of two. In the end we brought forward this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Harradine has raised some objections that I acknowledge. He referred to his previous position on a referendum. I do not think we had registered political parties at the time but it still does not deflect from some of his comments. I would have said that the ideal Act would be a mesh of both, political parties and any member of parliament being able to appoint scrutineers to cover those contingencies in some States where parties are not represented. For example, the Nationals are not represented in Western Australia, South Australia and Tasmania. I acknowledge the points Senator Harradine made that they should be referred back to the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. But I think in the instance of this election there are no practical problems in the way I have proposed it in contrast to Senator Harradine's principled stand. Will Senator Harradine appoint scrutineers? At the moment I do not think Senator Dunn has enough friends in politics to find many scrutineers because of the internal situation of the Nuclear Disarmament Party. From a practical sense I do not think we will hurt anyone by this Bill but, as Senator Harradine has pointed out, in the future there may be other circumstances when it does. Certainly, we invite the Joint Standing Committee to look at this question again. I suspect that it will be the first time it has been looked at since 1910 and we may be able to get a position from it.

I think the position of the Government is best summed up by saying that the Bill on scrutineers will leave no doubt as to the integrity of the ballot and that is the result we want. In terms of Senator Short's position concerning the ticks and crosses, the Labor Party will be supporting the Bill in this chamber. If there were a revision of legal advice that allowed us to consider it in the House of Representatives we would probably be amending it to clarify the inside and the outside of the square aspect. I give notice of that now. By the way, I know how hard it is to draw up a technical Bill of this nature when under the pressure of doing everything else at this time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought we had done rather well, actually.
—Senator Short thinks he did rather well. I give him a C plus. I wish the Bills a speedy passage.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Chaney asked: What is the source of the additional revenue? That is an arithmetic truism.

However-and I have been making this point in public speeches on many occasions in recent months-the major cause of the increase in revenue is from the existence of economic growth itself. More and more people are employed. For example, since this Government has been in office, employment has increased by a massive one million. More than a million extra people are employed now compared with the number employed when we came into office. Another one million people are paying taxes. The forecast growth for employment in this financial year is 2 3/4 per cent. That translates into about 200,000. About 200,000 extra people will be in jobs this year compared with last year. An extra 200,000 people will be paying tax.

To put it another way: in the last financial year the taxation base from personal income tax, corporate taxes, sales taxes, customs duty and excises, excluding the Bass Strait crude oil levy, which is a tax on producers rather than consumers, was around $71 billion. With economic growth at 3 per cent and without any real increase in the intensity of taxation, revenue grows by more than $2 billion. This year growth is expected to be above 3 per cent. So revenue will grow from that source alone, without any changes in the intensity of taxation, by close to $2 1/2 billion.

When a government engineers growth rates in excess of 3 per cent over a sustained period, which this Government has done, and also for a sustained period not only prevents increases in outlays but actually achieves, over three successive years-the fourth one is coming up-declines in outlays in real terms, there is an enormous change in the Budget bottom line. That enormous change has been in turning a deficit of $5.6m, I think it was, in 1985-86 into a surplus expected to be $5 1/2 billion in this financial year; that is, an $11 billion turnaround in the Budget outcome in three or four years. The principal reason for that is economic growth.

However, there are some other reasons. For instance, the Government has broadened the income tax base. When John Howard presided over the disintegration of the Australian economy back in the early 1980s and the economic chaos that he had helped to engineer, paying income tax was, to a large extent, a discretionary activity. People could choose whether to pay income tax or not. Of course, since then the income tax system has been massively cleaned up. We now have fringe benefits taxes-the days of the free boozy lunch have gone-and a capital gains tax. Hence revenue flows from that-not from discrete increases in taxation; but by ensuring that people actually pay the tax that they should have paid all along.

I will make a couple of relatively minor points. When economic growth is running at strong levels-the forecast level of 3 1/2 per cent is a strong rate of growth by Australian historic standards-not only will there be the extra 200,000 people employed but also, presumably, people will be working more overtime then they were before. ANSWER.PARA: We have had two previous occasions in the last 20 years when there was an export price boom and an export boom. They occurred in the early 1980s and in 1973. TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 August 1988 Senator Panizza asked me a question about the omission of entries from the Western Australian country telephone directories. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a detailed answer to that question.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-

Senator Panizza asked me on 23 August 1988 a number of questions about omission of entries from the Western Australian Country telephone directories. I undertook to obtain further information and to provide the honourable senator with a response.

I am informed by Telecom that there were 2,562 omissions from the three directories issued covering country areas of Western Australia which contained approximately 201,000 entries in total. These three directories replaced the former single volume Western Australian Country directory and the omissions occurred during transfer of information between the computer systems of the Western Australian Government Printing Organisation (the former printer and compilation contractor for the directory) and Telecom.

When the omissions were disclosed, Telecom was faced with two options-either reprint the directories or produce supplements. Due to the time required to recompile, print and bind all three country books, it was decided that the best option was to produce a directory supplement covering the three areas.

Telecom has advised me that every effort was made to ensure that all omitted entries were included in the supplement. In this regard media releases were issued and advertisements placed in regional newspapers asking all affected customers to contact a special `hotline' telephone number to ensure their inclusion in the supplement.

The supplement was subsequently produced and delivered to every Western Australian country business and household. The supplement is divided into three sections, each containing the omitted entries appropriate to the specific country directory. In addition, the supplement contains alterations to existing entries that have been notified since the delivery of the directories commenced in May 1988, and is designed to fit inside the front cover of the directory.
Telecom has advised that payment of compensation in these circumstances would not be appropriate and is not required under their legislation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Watson asked me a question in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. I have the answer to the question and I would like to read it out; but, given the fact that Senator Watson is not here, I seek leave to incorporate it in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The question and answer read as follows-
Senator Watson asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security on 23 August 1988:

(1) Is the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security aware that the Department of Social Security is giving advice to some large financial institutions that moneys received from certain instruments issued by the operators of those institutions will not affect social security payments either by way of pension or pensioner ancillary benefits?
(2) Does the Department keep a register of such advices?

(3) Does the Department always liaise with the Australian Taxation Office to ensure that there is not conflict of advice between the Department and the Tax Office that could embarrass pensioners and taxpayers?

(4) Will the Minister release to the Senate the full details of such arrangements so that all people in receipt of Commonwealth benefits can rearrange their investments rather than provide such tax free income to the privileged few?

Senator Bolkus: (1) Under current arrangements some institutionally managed investments are assessable under the pensions income test on a year to year basis. Others which fluctuate in value according to the market are assessable for 12 months when a profit is obtained on sale, maturity or withdrawal.

Decisions as to which category an investment falls into are made under a process of consultation with the funds management industry and in accordance with a set of criteria including publicity given to the particular product by the manager, the investment policy of the manager and movement in unit price over a particular period.
In no situation is an institution advised that its products do not affect pension or pensioner fringe benefit entitlements.

(2) The Department keeps an on line register of investment products for easy access by regional office staff which shows how investment products are to be treated for pension income test purposes and if appropriate, the earnings rate that is to be used to calculate the amount of income that is assessable on a year to year basis.

(3) The Department does not liaise with the Australian Taxation Office when deciding how a particular investment is to be treated under the pensions income test because there is no need given the different definitions of income in their respective legislation.

(4) Pensioners should not hesitate to contact their local regional office for advice on how their particular investments are treated. However it is not the function of these offices to recommend particular investment products or to act as investment advisers.

As announced in the Budget steps will be taken from 1 December 1988 to remove any pension advantage that exists where a pensioner purchases an investment that is assessable only at the point of sale, maturity or withdrawal.

Pensioners with money invested in these market linked investments, which yield capital growth, will now have a rate of return calculated and counted as income on a year by year basis. This will apply to new claimants and where existing payments are reviewed.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Short proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The deliberate attempt by the Government to deceive the Australian people in its referendum campaign.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, the Hawke Government's campaign for the referendums on 3 September has been one of the most deceitful campaigns ever to be waged in Australia's political history. A web of deceit has been spun around virtually every aspect of this campaign. It is tainted with distortions, deceptions, dirty tricks, misrepresentations and downright cheating. From go to whoa, this campaign is a con. So far as referendums go, it is indeed the con of the century. The deceit goes far and wide to the creating of an environment for the proposals, to their wording, to the promotion and advertising of the proposals, to the procedures for counting the votes. The deceit goes back to at least 1985, to the establishment by the Hawke Government of the Constitutional Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) introduced his referendum proposals in May of this year, he took the opportunity to sing the praises of the Government's hand picked, multi-million dollar Constitutional Commission. This was not because he had decided to put its recommendations to the people. No, it was because in his eyes it had done its job. It had created an environment for constitutional change. It had generated for the Attorney-General a `sense of immediacy in the task of constitutional reform', to quote his words. So this is the first con by the Australian Labor Party (ALP) Government. The Government is not interested in preserving the cornerstone of Australian democracy-the Constitution. On the contrary, it wants to radically alter it. Rather than come clean on this fundamental objective, it has pretended that a hand picked group of Labor appointees could do its dirty work for it. The Attorney-General said as much when he introduced his proposals. They are, he said, `the best way to ensure that wider questions of constitutional reform raised by the Commission are placed firmly in the forefront of the agenda of this nation'.

It came as no surprise to anyone that this Commission basically endorsed the ALP's agenda for constitutional reform-more power to Canberra, more socialism, bigger government. That is what happens when Labor stacks its committees. The first question Australians should be asking themselves when they go to the ballot box on 3 September is: Why do we need constitutional changes now? Our Constitution has served us well for 87 years. Why change it now? What is it about the Labor Party that makes it so keen to change our Constitution? Why has it tried to deceive the Australian people about its fundamental objectives?

The Government, of course, denies all this. After all, it says, not all the recommendations of its stacked Constitutional Commission have been accepted. That is true. But, when the Attorney-General introduced his proposals, he made it very clear that the reason for not accepting all the recommendations was not that he and the ALP did not accept them but rather that now was not the time. For instance, on the issue of abolishing the Senate, or emasculating it, he said, `Now is not the time to address questions of powers of the Senate'. For the Attorney-General, the measure of success of this taxpayer-funded, multi-million dollar campaign is that it is `advancing the ongoing never-ending cause of constitutional reform'.

The third deceit by the Hawke Government in its referendum campaign is the repeated claim that these proposals are modest. The Attorney-General is, to use his word, `relaxed' about them. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) did not even bother to debate them in the Parliament. `What's the problem?', they say; `These proposals don't amount to much'. There can be no doubt at all that it is a lie to say that these proposals are modest. In just four questions Australian voters are being asked to consider a total of 33 changes to the Constitution. This represents more changes in one fell swoop than all the other changes to the Constitution in our 87 years of federation to date. Labor's proposals involve the removal from the Constitution of 609 words and the inclusion of 1,732 new words. The eight successful referendums in the past 87 years of federation added only 1,411 words and removed only 263. There can be no doubt that the wording of the four referendum questions is biased. That is why I introduced into the Parliament this morning the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) (Informal Ballot-Papers) Bill 1988 to ensure that no government in future could be so downright deceitful in putting such biased questions to the Australian people. One of Australia's top pollsters, Gary Morgan, who has had years of experience in framing questions for polls, put it this way:
any public opinion polling company who asked questions as blatantly biased as the Government proposes would completely lose credibility.

In other words, Mr Morgan was saying that he would be out of a job. This Government will be before too long. Take the first question, which asks: Do you support the proposal to alter the Constitution `to provide for 4 year maximum terms for members of both Houses of the Commonwealth Parliament'? Does that convey the proposals of the Australian Labor Party? Does this proposal involve a fair rendering of the precise changes to the Constitution? It is nothing of the sort. The fine point of that proposal contains at least four hidden elements. Firstly, parliamentary terms will not necessarily be four years in future if it is successful. The reality is that it is a proposal to increase the maximum term for the House of Representatives from three years to four.

Secondly, the proposal seeks to reduce the maximum term for senators from six years to four years. Thirdly, it seeks to abolish the rotation system for senators whereby half the Senate is up for re-election at a normal election. Finally, it seeks to abolish the concept of fixed terms for senators and to replace it with the concept that all senators should face the electors each time the House of Representatives is put to an election at the whim of the Prime Minister of the day.

Not one of those hidden agenda questions has been put to the people in the proposal on which they will be voting on 3 September. During the debate in the Parliament, the Opposition implored the Government to alter the wording of the referendum questions to remove their inherent bias. We introduced amendments, we debated and we pointed out the deception contained in the questions. The ALP has always paraded its attachment to principles, fair play and decency. It has always purported to be the party of social concern and for giving Australians a fair go. There is nothing decent or fair about these referendum questions. It is grossly unfair to ask people such biased questions. We may as well ask Australians whether they have stopped beating their children.

The question Australians should ask themselves on 3 September is this: if the ALP is truly committed to being open, honest and fair, why has it decided to put such biased questions to Australian voters? Why has it decided to limit their choice by cramming so many questions into only four? Why has it put quite disparate issues-for example, the question of compensation, the question of freedom of religion and the question of trial by jury-into one question? Why has it limited an individual's ability to choose?

The Government says that its proposals will mean fewer elections. That is nonsense. How can that be so when the proposal is for maximum terms only? How can we possibly trust the Government when it has successfully called elections way ahead of time throughout its history? If Labor were really concerned about wasting taxpayers' money on elections-each election costs almost $50m-why is it not combining its referendums with a general election? This would have saved taxpayers' money. If the questions are really modest, as the Government claims, why the indecent haste to get them through now at a cost exceeding $40m? Why does that cost keep going up? A few months ago we were told that it would cost $35m but last night's Budget Papers reveal that it is to cost $40m.

The sixth element of deception in this Government's referendum campaign has been its attempt to gag debate. It cut short the consideration of the proposals from six months to a paltry three. This is the first time that Australian voters will have only three months to make up their minds about whether they should support a government's proposed changes to the Constitution. The Government has also deliberately refused to engage in public debate on the issue. The Attorney-General has refused publicly to debate the proposals with the shadow Attorney-General on any occasion. He has also refused to release the legal opinions that he has received on the referendum proposals.

The Government convened a special parliamentary session on 10 May to exploit the goodwill generated by the opening of the new Parliament House as a stimulus for encouraging a Yes vote. The decision to hold the referendum on 3 September can only be seen for what it is-a cynical attempt to push the Government's proposals through. When the Attorney-General made his speech in the Parliament on these proposals he gave the impression that it would be unpatriotic not to support them. He suggested, `After all, 1988 is the bicentennial year. It is time for change. We are leaving the old Parliament House and we are moving up the hill. Is it not time, therefore, to move away from old Constitution?'. Again this was a presentation of total deceit.

The next element of deceit in the Labor Party's campaign is the central place it has reserved for propaganda. This is the method it has chosen to adopt to get its referendums up rather than reasoned debate and careful consideration. The cornerstone of this attempt is its so-called information campaign. This is to cost taxpayers $3m and, naturally, the job has gone to the same advertising agency that the Government used during its last Federal election campaign. The Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Amendment Act specifically states that the Government shall not expend taxpayers' money on the Yes case over and above the cost of the official pamphlets. So concerned was the Electoral Commissioner about these advertisements-here I give Dr Hughes great credit-that he sought the advice of a Queen's Counsel. Further doubt was cast on the legality, not to mention the propriety, of the advertisements-we all know that they break the spirit of the law, if not the law itself-when the Opposition mounted a legal challenge in the High Court of Australia. Our views were vindicated. The High Court accepted our arguments and ruled in our favour. Our claims were absolutely vindicated in that High Court judgment. Indeed, a careful reading of that decision reveals that our case was extremely conservative. Had we challenged the legality of all four advertisements it is likely that we would have been successful. This is because we agreed to restrict the definition of `argument', crucial to the interpretation of the relevant section of the Act, to the argument contained in the official Yes and No pamphlet. Let me quote from the judgment of the High Court:

I should have thought that there was something to be said for a broader construction of the phrase `the argument', whereby it is taken as a reference to the argument for or the argument in general and not as a particular reference to the particular arguments included in the pamphlet.

Such a construction, would, I think, give effect to an intention that Commonwealth government expenditure in relation to the presentation of the cases for and against a proposed law should . . . be restricted to the preparation, printing and distribution of the pamphlets referred to or the preparation and distribution of translations of them.

These advertisements constitute a blatant attempt to manipulate the Australian public into voting yes on 3 September. The message of the advertisements is that it would be unAustralian, somehow or other, not to do so. The scripts of the advertisements bear a remarkable resemblance to the Attorney-General's speech in the Parliament when introducing these Bills and the High Court was unequivocal on this point. The scripts consist of virtually the same arguments, language and images used by the Attorney-General when he introduced the referendum legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is not authorising them, is he?

—Yes, probably. This is not the first time that the Australian Labor Party has tried to manipulate the Australian people. In 1984 the then Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans, did exactly the same thing but he was forced ultimately to withdraw. And, contrary to the image that the Australian Labor Party Government has tried so desperately to get across, these proposals are not new. For instance, question No. 1 includes the proposal for simultaneous elections. That proposal has been rejected three times by the Australian people in referendums-in 1974, 1977 and again in 1984, only four years ago. Variations of questions 2 and 3 were overwhelmingly rejected in 1974. The Government is all about propaganda. This campaign is only the latest in a long line. First, the Government spent millions of dollars promoting the prices and incomes accord. Subsequently it embarked on multimillion dollar campaigns of self-promotion, such as the fringe benefits tax campaign, and there was much ado about nothing on really constructive campaigns-the drug offensive, Priority One and Medicare, to name but a few.

SPEECH.PARA: The question that Australian voters should ask themselves on 3 September is why the Hawke Government, if it is so convinced of the genuine merit of its proposed changes to the Constitution, has not only sought to circumvent the laws of this country by stooping to waste taxpayers' money on illegal advertisements but has also decided not to rely on reasoned argument and careful debate. What is so wrong with the Government's proposals that it is reluctant to state them clearly, openly and without all this razzamatazz and deceit?

The Government has also been deceptive in its handling of the official Yes and No pamphlets. Under the law, the Government must send to all Australian voters a booklet outlining the Yes and No arguments. Electors should receive their booklets 14 days before the date of the referendum. It is only 10 days before polling day and still not all Australian voters have received their official booklets. In my own State of Victoria alone, 10 to 15 per cent of voters are still to receive their booklets.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that the fault of the Government?

—It is done through the Australian Electoral Commission but, of course, it is the Government's responsibility. Maybe there is a good explanation for this, but one does not have to be too uncharitable to conclude that this all forms part of the pattern of keeping Australians in the dark about the true nature of proposed changes to the Constitution. In addition to the Government's failure to distribute the pamphlet to Australian voters on time is the issue of the design and layout of the booklet. If honourable senators take a quick flip through the pamphlet, they will see what I am talking about. The print for the Yes case throughout the pamphlet is many times larger than the print for the No case. In fact, so blatantly biased is the design and layout of the pamphlet that I have received many telephone calls from distressed voters saying, `I have received the Yes case. When will I receive the No case?'. The responsibility of presenting and authorising that pamphlet rests with the Electoral Commissioner, and it is reasonable to put that, when the Yes and the No case were submitted to the Commissioner and he found such a difference in the presentation, he should have consulted both parties.

SPEECH.PARA: The next sleight of hand by the Government is the issue of which votes it will count and which it will not. I will not go into that in great detail; it has been the subject of debate earlier today. But the whole question of the counting of votes and the eligibility or otherwise of ticks and/or crosses in the election voting count has been a matter of very great concern and very great confusion in the electorate. It is extremely interesting that the interpretation given to date on which votes will be eligible and which will not heavily favours the ticks and therefore is a bias towards the Yes campaign.

From go to whoa the Government's referendum campaign has been surrounded by deception and dirty pool. It started with abolishing the Constitutional Convention and replacing it with the Constitutional Commission. The Government stacked this multi- million dollar Commission and told it to go around the country promoting constitutional reform. When the Government realised that the body had had only limited success, it decided to put what it told the Australian people were modest proposals in the name of advancing constitutional reform. It is obvious, as I said before, that those proposals are not modest. How can they be when they consist of 33 changes to the Constitution and deal with fundamental elements of the Constitution, including the Senate, state aid to church schools, electoral boundaries and how elections in this country are to be conducted? Nor are the proposals all new. Many have been defeated in past referendums. The polling day on 3 September has been designed deliberately to coincide with the Budget propaganda hype so that there will be as little public debate as possible. The Constitution has served the people well. It will go on serving them well without Labor's proposed changes.

Following a request to include graphs, charts and pictures in one case, the Electoral Commission agreed to permit both cases to provide their own arguments in a camera-ready copy format. As an additional guarantee, both groups were requested to provide the Electoral Commission with a typescript of their arguments, a computer disc containing the text and camera-ready copy. In discussions with the Electoral Commission, neither Mr Reith nor the No case person handling technical details raised any objection to those procedures. The second aspect to this matter of public importance is a complaint that the Yes case is in larger type. The No case could have picked whatever type it liked. Most people sitting opposite, at least in the Liberal Party, basically have a commitment to fair electoral boundaries. Of course, their uglier brother who sits a few feet to the right-the National Party-has a commitment in exactly the opposite direction. Because of the fragility of the coalition and because of the tensions that existed and were exhibited in the first half of 1987, a clear agreement was made following the 1987 election defeat and that was: no more blues among the parties, at all costs. That is reflected in the matter of public importance before us and it is reflected in the National Party copying deregulation in the wheat industry. It is quite evident that Opposition members are putting unity ahead of all principle. They are not confronting the basic issues in this referendum.

TALK.START.PARA: —There speaks the voice of Caucus; unity before principle. What a terrible thing.

—I have never apologised for being bound by Caucus decisions. When I signed the pledge when I joined the Australian Labor Party that is what I agreed to. But we are not hypocritical about it. It knows it cannot change the system internally and yet it is asking the people of Australia to make a pronouncement with regard to that particular proposition. How was I able to appear also on a platform with the Lord Mayor of Brisbane, Sallyanne Atkinson, a Liberal, urging a Yes vote on the third question?
