Lastly, we have the fourth question, about which we have had such a range of deceit as to beggar the imagination. I was on a platform when someone said, `The reason the Labor Party is introducing this one is that it wants to abolish religions'. We have had the most extraordinary lies being told about the third question. If Senator Short cannot work out why those three questions are put together it is again a very poor show. They happen to be the three items appearing in the Constitution that affect the Federal Government. That is why, and the issue is identical in every one. Since 1901 the Federal Government has not had those powers. The proposal is that as from 1988 the State governments will not have those powers. That is what the proposal is. That is why they are together. The argument is identical.

Either one does not want the States to have those powers or one does. I do not mind arguing on that basis. I have had a chance to argue with one of the Opposition's colleagues, the Leader of the Liberal Party in Queensland, Angus Innes, who was in fact able enough to argue a No case which was not a matter of lies and deceit. At least when one gets into a debate with him he will argue on the issue and not on the furphies, lies and deceit that one has had to meet in this campaign.

I find it an extraordinary proposition, but well within the keeping of the Liberal Party on this question. The way the Liberal Party has attempted to run the exercise is by accusing everybody else of trying to do this, that or something else and saying the very opposite of what the clauses are doing. It has been saying that it is trying to protect the Senate when what it is doing, in terms of its hidden agenda, is trying to get control of the Senate and turn it into a rubber stamp. It is trying to prop up its coalition colleague in Queensland, the National Party, to allow the system to be rigged and rorted ad infinitum. There will not be any Steele Hall in Queensland, I can assure honourable senators. There will not be anybody in the National Party in Queensland succumbing to principle and deciding that everybody should have an equal vote to elect the government of his choice. That will not occur in my State of Queensland although it did in South Australia, to the eternal credit of Steele Hall.

On the third question: the recognition of local government is somehow or other supposed to be an attempt by the Federal Government to get control and yet it was asked for by the local government associations themselves. They have been campaigning for it in and out of every meeting that one has ever attended with them on this issue. Let us just pause one moment on this question. I was at a meeting where one of the local government representatives brought out a sheaf of letters. They were from Liberal Party people all of whom had written back and said they would support a recognition of local government. It was in the Liberal Party's policy as late as last year when it went to the election. It was there in writing. It said, `We will support a constitutional recognition of local government'. What is it doing now when it gets the opportunity? It is running around urging a No vote.

Lastly, I find the debate-it might be only in Queensland-a very depressing exercise for democracy in this country. The Liberal Party does not actually address the issues. I am quite happy to have a debate with somebody who wants to address the issues and I acknowledge that there are arguments that can be put on both sides and that one could finally come down on one side or another. When one meets so many lies and distortions one becomes very depressed at how far democracy has sunk in this country. We cannot have a decent debate about what the issues really are and we have to sink to distortions, to lies and to deceit. This matter of public importance should have been directed against the Liberal Party, not the Government and its campaign.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to issue a challenge to the Australian Democrats and to Senator Macklin. Senator Macklin has said that the referendum debate has been overshadowed by lies and deceit on our side. Perhaps Senator Macklin is not as lilywhite as he would like at all times to make out. I issue him a simple challenge because he said the Senate has equal powers with the House of Representatives. I ask Senator Macklin and the members of the Australian Democrats to introduce into this chamber a taxation Bill and see how successful they will be.
—We have already done so.
—They will not get to first base with it. I ask Senator Macklin to introduce an appropriation Bill and see how far the honourable senator goes.
—I have already done it.

—Yes, you will introduce it for the purposes of rhetoric to show how smart you are but the point is that you will not be successful. You do it as a matter of shadow boxing. Shadow boxers-that is all you are.
—Order! I ask Senator Macklin not to interject and I ask Senator Watson, even though he may refer to Senator Macklin, to address the Chair.

—I draw attention to the fact that this whole referendum campaign has, as my colleague Senator Short so eloquently said, been hallmarked by deceit. Whichever way Australians are going to vote on 3 September the political analysts of the future will look back and ask themselves at least four essential questions. Why did this Government not ask fair questions? There is talk about fair elections but the nub of it is: why did this Hawke Labor Government not ask fair questions of the people in the first place?

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, why did the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) attempt to use the supposedly neutral Australian Electoral Commission to promote the Yes case? Why did Mr Bowen continue to refuse to debate the question with the Opposition publicly? For example, when he came to Launceston it was almost a closed meeting. We were not allowed to participate; not one member of the audience was even allowed to ask the Attorney-General a question. What sort of public debate was that in my State of Tasmania? He rushed in and when questions were posed by journalists he showed a distinct lack of knowledge as to how the implications of change would affect the upper House in Tasmania. He was not even aware of its composition. He was not even aware how it was elected. It is not surprising, therefore, that he refused to debate the issue in public either with members of the public or with members of the Liberal Party Opposition.

The third question I think political analysts are going to ask in time is: Why was there only a three-month publicity campaign rather than the usual six-month campaign that we have had in the past? Why has there been this sudden rush of blood, this need to get some legislation on the statute books, this need to change the basic law of Australia, the Constitution?

The answer to each of these four questions and others of similar nature must hinge on a single word and that word unfortunately is `deceit'. I regret that a lot of the responsibility for promoting the Yes case has fallen on the Attorney-General, a man I have had a great deal of respect for. It is unfortunate in the last years of his political office he has succumbed somewhat and his stature in many people's eyes has been lessened as a result of the proposals that he has put forward. To his credit he does not want to debate the issues publicly because he knows what the hidden agenda is. He knows what is down the track for the Australian Labor Party. I would be charitable if I said that he has been used by this Labor Party to promote an issue which I believe should not have his full backing.

The point of the referendum is to hoodwink the Australian people. It is the most blatantly opportunistic scheme that has ever been put before this Parliament. Mr Bowen has publicly stated that if these proposals are successful more proposals will be put in 1989, 1990 and so on. The effect of these changes, if the present agenda is followed, will be to whittle away the basic law of Australia, the Constitution. That law was not agreed to by politicians alone but by concerned people within the community, from all the colonies. They came together, concerned that there would be some attempt down the track by a Federal government to increase its powers at the expense of the powers of the States. So they deliberately said, `We have to protect the smaller States, the people who have less influence'. They were not considering the Bonds of this world who can use monetary gain to promote their particular interests. These people were far-sighted. They deliberately put into place appropriate checks and balances in conformity with good democratic principles.

But what are we seeing? We are seeing a whittling away of the system of checks and balances which our forefathers, in framing the Constitution, believed to be so important to the protection of freedoms. What is at risk is the basic freedoms of Australia. What the Government is seeking to change is the basic law of Australia. This whole concept is about transferring power from the people, not only to the centralist government but also to the elected Prime Minister of the day. We have already seen, over recent years, a tremendous increase in the power of the Executive. Question No. 1 will significantly increase the power not only of the central government but also of the Prime Minister of the day. This is a frightening thought to any person concerned about democracy, particularly to a federalist.

The Labor Party is caught up in the euphoria of change for change's sake based on what I term a Fabian agenda. I hope that the almighty con trick proposed to be perpetrated on 3 September will not be successful and that the Australian people will vote a decisive no to each of the four questions to be put. I remind the ladies and gentlemen listening to this debate that there is a hidden agenda which reflects the Fabian tactics of the leadership of the Hawke Labor Government.

It is true that not a single legislative, deliberative or other function of this chamber will be stripped away by the referendum proposals. That is the thrust of the Labor Party's argument. Senator Tate used it yesterday. Senator Macklin attempted to use it today. But I put it to honourable senators that if we destroy the foundations, the very fabric, the framework upon which the Senate is built, then everything else-the Senate's powers, its ability to debate-becomes superfluous. If we destroy the foundations on which this chamber has been built, we destroy the chamber itself. That is the tragedy in what has been put forward to us today.

A Yes vote will render the Australian Senate an impotent echo of the House of Representatives. A Yes vote would destroy representative democracy in some isolated areas on the west coast of Tasmania. The upper House is not the House of government. In Tasmania we have the most democratic system of electing governments in the whole of Australia. There is a need for the electoral system to be somewhat different for an upper House. We acknowledge that concept and the Government supports it in regard to the Australian Senate. If the Government is so keen about the issue of equality all along the way, I suppose that the next thing on its agenda will be to whittle away the membership of the Senate, which has equal representation from each of the States. I presume that will be next on the Government's agenda if it ridicules that sort of concept.

The other major problem I think the Australian people should be aware of is how Question No. 4 will threaten state aid to non-government schools, hospitals and welfare organisations. The referendum provisions will not extend religious freedom. If the Government wanted to do that, all it would have had to do would have been to add the words `States and Territories'. But no; the Government was cunning. It went further than that. It removed three vital words-three words so vital that the whole complexion and meaning of section 116 of the Constitution will be changed. They were the vital words on which the defence of government schools case rested. Now we are to have a new ball game. Prayers in schools and in State and Federal government buildings could even be outlawed.

TALK.START.PARA: —No money is provided for religion in this country. Money is provided for education and you know it.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, earlier Senator Macklin was asked to desist from making interjections which were not accurate. I hope that I can have the same protection that was previously provided by the Chair. If Senator Macklin thinks that there has been no deception, I draw his attention to what was said by the director of Morgan Gallup Polls, Mr Gary Morgan. He said that any pollster who posed questions like those the Government is putting up and claimed that they were unbiased would lose all credibility. That comment was made not by a member of the National Party or the Liberal Party, but by a man whose organisation is centred on assessing public opinion in as fair a way as possible. Mr Morgan has said that there is no doubt that the proposed referendum questions are biased to obtain a Yes vote because the questions do not honestly convey the issues involved.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me turn to another eminent critic of the proposed constitutional change, again not a Liberal, a National or a politician at all, but one of this country's most eminent jurists, Sir Harry Gibbs. He said that it is impossible to predict what meaning will in the future be given to any provision of the Constitution which is expressed in the words of a generality, that one cannot assume that any general provision will have more than symbolic effect.

One of the problems of these changes is that they are not clear. There is an onus on the Government, when putting forward something as important as change to the Constitution, to get it right. But the Government could not even get the legislation right when it put it before the Parliament. Senator Vanstone had to tell the Government that it had got it wrong. There is also an obligation on the Government to put it not only in fair terms but also in clear and unambiguous terms. It is well known, and the Government acknowledges, that down the track most of these provisions will be subject to High Court interpretation. That is a damning indictment of the deceitful way in which these proposals are to be put.

TALK.START.PARA: —All of them are.

—We have an acknowledgment of that. Is it not an indictment of this Government and the manner in which the questions have been put? They are deceitful in every way. I hope that the Australian people reject them-proposals one, two, three and four-with a resounding No vote.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some wild statements have been made here today. I will go to the first one, that the Constitution alteration Bills do not properly describe what is contained in the legislation. I will quickly go through them. The first one, the Constitution Alteration (Parliamentary Terms) Bill, is entitled:

SPEECH.PARA: An Act to alter the Constitution to provide for 4-year maximum terms for members of both Houses of the Commonwealth Parliament.
That very accurately describes what happens. The second, the Constitution Alteration (Fair Elections) Bill, is entitled:
An Act to alter the Constitution to provide for fair and democratic parliamentary elections throughout Australia.
It does that. The third Bill, the Constitution Alteration (Local Government) Bill, is entitled:
An Act to alter the Constitution to recognise local government.
It does that. The fourth Bill, the Constitution Alteration (Rights and Freedoms) Bill, is entitled:
An Act to alter the Constitution to extend the right to trial by jury, to extend freedom of religion, and to ensure fair terms for persons whose property is acquired by any Government.

It has been said here today that these Bills are not needed. I will go to each of the Bills in turn. The first provides for a four-year maximum term for both Houses of the Commonwealth Parliament. In every State of this country other than Queensland, the lower House, in which the Government is made, has a four-year term. When this Constitution was made, the lower Houses had three-year terms. It was properly pointed out to the founding fathers-unfortunately there were no founding mothers-who wanted longer than three-year terms that, since all the States had three-year terms, it would be wrong to give the Commonwealth terms of more than three years. Now all the States have four-year terms. When the terms of the States were extended to four years there was absolutely no outcry. It was seen as a very sensible reform. If it is a proper reform for State Houses, it is also a proper reform for the Commonwealth Parliament.

It is said that the Senate's powers would be diminished by giving senators four-year terms. The alternative to giving them four-year terms is to give them eight-year terms. What is wrong with members of parliament facing the electors of the country every four years? Of course we respect the rights of members of the House of Representatives and the Senate but, above all, we respect the rights of the people. Why should the people have foisted upon them a Senate about which they cannot speak for eight years? We are now choosing the Olympic Games team for Seoul. What would be said if we chose that team to represent us not only at Seoul but also at the next Olympic Games? It is a nonsense to have people elected for eight years. They are elected for eight years in Victoria and 12 years in New South Wales-and I simply say that that is an outrage.

Four-year terms will not diminish the power of the Senate. What gives this place its special quality is the fact that there is proportional voting for it. The record shows that from 1919 to 1949 either the Government or the Opposition held all but one, two or three of the places in the Senate. The reality is that during those 30 years this place was a rubber stamp for what was done in the House of Representatives. It is only the reforms brought in by the Australian Labor Party in 1949 which have given this Senate any meaning. This Labor Party, the one that allegedly is full of deceit and supposedly in favour of crushing the Senate, is the one that has given the Senate the power it has now, by introducing proportional representation. It was the Labor Party, under Senator Murphy, which introduced the committee system and that party, in respect of both those matters, that has made the Senate an effective body. That has to be remembered. Indeed, it is a Labor government that has brought electoral reform into every State in this Commonwealth into which electoral reform has been brought, except South Australia, where it was brought in by Steele Hall, who has paid, as has been suggested before, very dearly for that reform.

The reality is that this Bill will make government more efficient and more productive. It will enable people to plan over a longer term. This is evidenced by the fact that the States now have four-year terms, the House of Commons in England has five-year terms and the Presidents of the United States have four-year terms. Here we have a group of people who say that what they want from workers is efficiency and proper production but, when the same sort of thing is suggested in terms of their Parliament, they do not want it. They want to hold onto their seats for eight years.

The second Bill provides for fair and democratic parliamentary elections throughout Australia. I see that Senator Hill has come into the chamber. I would like to ask him directly why he opposes in this Bill the abolition of section 25 of the Constitution and why the people opposite oppose it. I ask that because section 25 of the Constitution is built on the basis that racism is okay. It states:

For the purposes of the last section, if by the law of any State all persons of any race are disqualified from voting at elections for the more numerous House of the Parliament of the State, then, in reckoning the number of the people of the State or of the Commonwealth, persons of that race resident in that State shall not be counted.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a disgrace.

—Yes, it is a disgrace that people should oppose removing from this Constitution a relic of the racism which unfortunately this country was once imbued with and which unfortunately is making a reappearance now. The Opposition has fiercely fought a Bill which seeks to delete from the Constitution a provision that is based on the concept of racism and that allows--
—It is your fault for putting all those things together.

—I would like the honourable senator to answer. There is in the Constitution a provision which contemplates that Australian citizens of a particular race will be banned from voting. When we want to remove that from this Constitution by using this Bill, that is opposed by the Opposition. It is a disgrace. I would like to hear why those opposite are opposing a Bill that does that.
—Come on, Barney; come clean. It's all about Queensland, isn't it?
—I will read what it says:

SPEECH.PARA: A Bill for an Act to alter the Constitution to provide for fair and democratic parliamentary elections throughout Australia.
I am challenged that the Bill does not do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —What does that mean?
—I am telling the honourable senator what it means. It means, first of all, that anybody who is an Australian citizen should not be barred on the grounds of race. Clause 4 states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Constitution is altered by omitting section 25.

The Opposition is opposing that provision. The next thing the Opposition opposes in that Bill is the provision that all Australian citizens over the age of 18 shall be entitled to a vote. Why do those opposite oppose that provision? Why is it so dreadful that Australian citizens over the age of 18 should have a vote? The next thing the Bill does is ensure that electorates throughout Australia, both electorates voting for the Commonwealth and those voting for the States, as far as practicable will be equal, so that one person's vote is equal to anybody else's-as happens for the House of Representatives now. I suppose the only opposition I can see to this is on the basis that there must be something other than people that comes into account. I remember the great proposition put by the pigs in Orwell's Animal Farm. The pigs said that all animals were equal but some were more equal than others. Apparently that is the proposition that the Opposition has picked up.

The second Bill abolishes the racial clause. It allows people aged 18 who are Australian citizens to vote; and it says that there should be fair elections. That is why we say it provides for fair and democratic parliamentary elections throughout Australia. The fourth Bill is entitled:
An Act to alter the Constitution to recognise local government.
It simply says:

Each State shall provide for the establishment and continuance of a system of local government, with local government bodies elected in accordance with the laws of the State and empowered to administer, and to make by-laws for, their respective areas in accordance with the laws of the State.

It has nothing to do with the Commonwealth; the Commonwealth is kept out of it completely. The Bill simply provides that the States will ensure that there is local government. We have had a great outcry from local governments about their inability to get sufficient finance for roads. They say that the Commonwealth denies them money and does not treat them properly and that the States do not treat them properly. If they want to be in a position to ask for money, so that they can say, `We're as good as the States and the Commonwealth because we are in the Constitution', then they should vote for this proposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is why Jeff Kennett is supporting them.

—That is right. I now turn to the question which proposes to extend the right to trial by jury. The founding fathers said that there ought to be a right to trial by jury for serious offences. They used the words `indictable offences'. Unfortunately, the Commonwealth then legislated to make charges other than indictable and got around the question of the jury system. This proposition will ensure that the Commonwealth will reaffirm the intentions of the founding fathers and will ensure that serious offences are tried by jury, with the notable exception of offences under martial law or contempt of court proceedings which, traditionally, are matters that are tried other than by juries.

SPEECH.PARA: The next proposition is to ensure that people whose property is acquired by a State or the Commonwealth will receive just compensation. We are supposed to be the great party of socialism. We on this side of the House say that those people whose property is taken from them by the State or Commonwealth ought to receive fair compensation. But the Opposition does not agree. It says that the sorts of things that happen in Pye's case and Magennis's case should be allowed. In other words, it says that, even if there is this protection with regard to property acquired by the Commonwealth, if the States acquire property on behalf of the Commonwealth without paying proper compensation, that is all right.

I turn to the question of freedom of religion. There is provision in the Constitution to the effect that the Commonwealth shall not make laws for the establishment of any religion, and so on. This proposition extends it to the States and ensures not only that this Parliament will not make such laws, but also that the Government will not discriminate against people. The Government, apart from the laws, will not exercise any discretion against religion, so that people will not be barred from jobs on the ground of religion. The proposition extends freedom of religion not only in regard to the Commonwealth but also in regard to the States. It has been said that this will make things uncertain.

TALK.START.PARA: —What have your Catholic bishops said about this?

—The Catholic bishops have said that there are some problems about it. Let us see how well they have been advised by some of the so-called lawyers who give advice in this area. The person in charge of the Constitutional Commission-and this Constitutional Commission was blackguarded in this chamber today, just as the High Court of Australia is often blackguarded in this chamber-and the person who drafted the proposition is Sir Maurice Byers. It is no secret that he is a member of the Catholic Church. He was the person who argued successfully on behalf of the Commonwealth in Black's case. If anybody knows Black's case, it is Byers. Sir Maurice Byers drafted this proposition. I challenge any member of the Opposition to read this case and show how any of those judges-those judges who ruled in favour of it and Mr Justice Murphy, who ruled against it-would have changed their judgments in any way, in light of the proposed changes to the Constitution. The reality is that they specifically stated that they would not follow the American model. If one looks at the American model, one will see that it talks about making no laws in respect of the establishment of a religion. That has already been rejected. If a case was brought now, simply on the reading of Black's case, which is the only case that has been dealt with here, there is no doubt that the application by anybody trying to stop state aid would be thrown out of court.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to contribute to this important debate which has been raised in the Senate this afternoon by the Opposition with regard to the deliberate attempt by the Government to deceive the Australian people in its referendum campaign. I think it can be fairly said that the reality of the questions that will be put to the people, the attempt to cloak the whole campaign in the legitimacy of a Constitutional Commission, and the campaign that the Government has irregularly sought to put to the Australian people, are becoming clear. The deliberate attempt to deceive the Australian people is being realised. The response of the Australian community on 3 September will be to say, `We will not be treated so cynically. We will reject this attempt being made by the Government', and they will vote no.

SPEECH.PARA: In the short time available to me, I will expand on these three major areas of deception that the Government is attempting to put to the Australian people. I do so as one who actually believes that the Australian Constitution is due for reform. I am not opposed to reform, but I am appalled at the way in which this campaign has been treated so cynically by the Government. It has attempted to mislead Australian voters in this whole exercise.

Let me deal with the first aspect-that is, as I indicated, the attempt by the Government to cloak the referendum campaign with an aura of legitimacy as a result of the setting up of the Constitutional Commission and its advisory committees. As you know, Mr Acting Deputy President, the Australian taxpayer spent many millions of dollars on the setting up of the independent Constitutional Commission. At the very least, the Australian taxpayer could have expected the Government to await the report of that Commission and to take into account the Commission's attitudes and advice before it determined what questions, if any, were to be put to the Australian people. This government did not do so. It would not await the first report of its Commission. It decided to proceed. It seems to me, therefore, that it clearly decided to proceed, not in an effort to produce a better Constitution, but because of some perceived political gain of the moment-a political gain that could come out of the spirit that surrounded the bicentenary, or a political gain that could come out of the fact that it could be seen to be part of an independent assessment, which I have indicated is quite improper.

I submit to the Senate that the Australian people should be outraged that the Government was not prepared to await the report of its Commission before it determined which questions it would put to the people for their approval. As it turns out, the Commission made 100-odd recommendations. Four questions are being put to the people, although I readily concede that the four questions raise a number of different issues. Even though the Government has the advantage of its Commission's report, is it putting to the people the variations between that report and the questions that it is putting in these referendum proposals? Is it putting to the people the fact that the first question, which is the key question in this referendum-the question that is designed to give a government of the day control of the Senate-is inconsistent with the recommendation of its own independent Constitutional Commission? Of course it is not, but it should be.

It should tell the people that that Commission made a recommendation that the term of the lower House be extended to four years, that there be a minimum three-year period-a system which is similar to that which has been adopted in South Australia and Victoria-and that senators chosen in the State should hold their places for two terms. That is the recommendation of the independent Constitutional Commission. But this Government did not choose to put that question to the people. Now that the Commission has reached a conclusion which is inconsistent with that of the Government, the Government is not prepared to come clean and say that the question that it is asking be approved is not consistent with the advice that it has received from this body of experts.

What has happened to the final report of the Constitutional Commission? We understand that it is with the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) at the moment but that it is not to be released until after the referendum has been put to the Australian people. I ask: Why is that the case? If the Attorney-General has the final report, why do we not find out what are the final recommendations of the Constitutional Commission so that the Australian people can take that determination into account when they make their decision on 3 September?

In the circumstances, where the Attorney-General is not prepared to make that report public at the moment, one can only presume that again the conclusions it reaches are inconsistent with the determination that the Government wishes the Australian people to make on 3 September. I believe that there is no better word to use in relation to that mechanism, that way of dealing, than `deception'. That is what we are talking about in this matter of public importance that we bring to the Senate today. I say that it is illegitimate for the Government to attempt to place its questions under a cloak of legitimacy by virtue of the Commission's report.

The second area that causes us great concern is that the questions themselves-the wording of the questions that are being put to the public on 3 September-in no way clearly reflect or reasonably reflect the substance of the matters which are included in the legislation that will become part of the Constitution if in fact these question are passed or if in fact there is a sufficient Yes vote. We regard that as deception.

As you know, Mr Acting Deputy President, we tried, in this chamber, to have the Bills amended so that the questions to be put in the referendum proposals reflected more accurately the reality of the matters that are to be put on 3 September. Our attempts to do that were rejected by both the Government and the Australian Democrats, and that is a matter of great disappointment to us. If we look briefly-and we have only a brief time-at the first question, we find that what is being put is the question: a proposed law to alter the Constitution to provide for four-year maximum terms for members of both Houses of the Commonwealth Parliament. What does that indicate? Does that in any way indicate to Mr and Mrs Average Australian that the fixed term of the Senate, which has been guaranteed by the Constitution to date, is being abandoned? Of course it does not.

Does it in fact indicate that there will be fewer elections in Australia? There is no doubt that the Government has tried to catch on to a nerve in the Australian people that we have too many elections. Of course it does not. It in no way ensures that there would be fewer elections. If the Government had taken up the recommendation of the Constitutional Commission it might have had an argument that there could be fewer elections, but it did not choose to go down that path. Does it say that it will, if it passes, abolish the rotation of terms of senators so that the advantage of continuity which exists at the moment will be lost? No, of course it does not.

Does the Government really believe that the public understands these issues from the question that is being put on the day? Surely it does not. That is why we say that it amounts to deception. Does it indicate, most importantly, to the Australian public that this will give the Prime Minister and the government of the day a new authority over the Senate which does not exist at present? That is the authority that comes from being able to haul the Senate out to the people at the will of the Prime Minister, at the timing of the Prime Minister. That control of the Senate by a Prime Minister--

TALK.START.PARA: —Fancy having to go to an election. It is terrible, isn't it?

—I am talking about a Prime Minister of any colour. My attitude is that one must maintain some independence of the Senate and that degree of independence is guaranteed at the moment by a fixed term. Without that the Senate will rapidly deteriorate into a rubber stamp. The advantages that I believe this Senate has brought to the Australian political system will be lost. That is why I regard it as an abuse. It is clear that the Australian people do believe that the Senate, with the degree of independence it maintains through a fixed term, does serve a worthwhile purpose and should therefore be preserved.

SPEECH.PARA: So, when the Australian people vote on that first question they must look behind the question. Preferably they will look at the legislation, but they will not do that. Therefore, it is important that, on occasions such as this, we bring to their attention the Government's deception and the fact that the question that is being put does not fairly reflect the substance of the changes to the law and the changes to the Constitution.

The same spirit flows through the other questions that are being put. The second question that is being put is: to alter the Constitution to provide for fair and democratic parliamentary elections throughout Australia. That immediately brings a first blush of approval. We all want fair and democratic elections. But what in fact does it mean? How are the Australian people to define what is meant by `fair and democratic'? If they were able to refer to the legislation, they would find the Government's definition which refers to a tolerance of 10 per cent either way and, in the case of upper Houses, a proportional representation system. They will also know that that in itself does not amount to fair and democratic elections; that that in itself will not guarantee fair and democratic elections.

In any event, what is so sacred about the figure of 10 per cent? Why not 5 per cent? Would that not in fact be fairer? Senator Collins would probably say that it is fairer. So, how does this question secure for the Australian people fair elections? Of course, it does not. The real motive, as we all know, has been to attempt to split the National Party and the Liberal Party in Queensland, and some might say that it has been reasonably successful. That is a cynical, base political motive. That is what question No. 2 is all about. That is what the deception is in question No. 2, and the Australian people should realise that.

The deception continues in the third question: to alter the Constitution to recognise local government. What is the deception in relation to that? It is the fact that local government believed that out of this, in some way, its ratepayers would be guaranteed funding that they are not presently guaranteed. Local government recognises that under this Labor Government its direct funding has been cut.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nonsense!

—Has it not, Senator Reynolds? Road funding has been cut also. Again at first blush it gives one a warm inner feeling that they get recognition. No, they do not. Ask the ratepayers out in the bush of Australia what they want. What they want is funding. They want better roads. They will see through this deception also. It is slowly coming. Senator Collins was right when he said that a little while ago local government was embracing this with great enthusiasm; but the reality is now coming through and by 3 September it will come through.

SPEECH.PARA: The con continues in question No. 4, with more warm inner glow questions. They are to alter the Constitution to the extent that the right of trial by jury will be guaranteed. That is not happening. What is happening, as Senator Cooney will admit, is a change of the formula. It is a change from an indictment requirement that currently exists in the Constitution to a two-year goal term. It is not entrenching anything further than what currently exists; it is changing the formula. It goes on to say that it is also to ensure religious freedom. As we know, whether Senator Cooney likes to acknowledge it or not, the Catholic bishops of Australia are putting around circulars saying, `We are afraid that in fact this provision will do the contrary'. As the bishops said, a Yes vote on this question could in fact end up seriously restricting the freedom of religion. Therein lies the deception again. Are the Australian people going to take the chance on that? Of course they are not; they are going to reject it.

Had I had time, which I have not, I would have liked to go into the question of the cynical attempt of this Government to advertise in a partisan way, in an illegal way; the fact that we had to take the Government to the High Court of Australia and the High Court had to say no to this Government; that its proposed advertisements would have been illegal, that it would have abused the provisions of the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act; and that it should not be behaving in such a deceptive way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Short started off the debate by saying that he wanted reasoned and informed debate on the referendum questions. However, it is very difficult to have such a debate in the face of a statement that he made shortly thereafter. I quote him as saying, `What does freedom of religion have to do with trial by jury?'. If the Opposition spokesman responsible for leading in the debate--
—Well, what has it got to do with it?

—The honourable senator should just wait for 30 seconds. I must say that I am appalled that Senator Short still asks that question after he got the very obvious response that he did to it from Senator Cooney. The three questions are completely linked in that they all involve powers in the Constitution devolved upon the Commonwealth Government which are not enshrined in State constitutions and they all involve some of the very rare sections of the Constitution that touch upon personal liberties and freedoms. We all know that they are inextricably linked. We all know, and it is a debate in itself, that the Australian Constitution does not have a Bill of Rights contained in it. In fact, there are very small sections of the Australian Constitution that deal with the rights and privileges of individual citizens. It just so happens that those sections of the Constitution are some of the few sections that deal with those issues-the right to trial by jury, the right to fair compensation when people's property is ripped off them by government and the right to freedom of religion. In fact, the questions are linked but, in the face of the appalling ignorance demonstrated by Senator Short, it is pretty hard to have a reasoned debate on it.

SPEECH.PARA: So many canards were flung about during this debate that it is impossible to address all of them but, to my great amusement, Senator Hill said, in another brilliant contribution, that question No. 2 was designed by the Australian Labor Party to split the National and Liberal parties in Queensland. They took care of that themselves. In fact, the split was caused very simply by the Liberal Party wanting fair elections in Queensland and the National Party not wanting fair elections in Queensland. The split is on the issue, not on the question. If we wanted any confirmation of that, and we did not, it was supplied in recent day by that prominent hero of Queensland politics, Russ Hinze, one of my personal political heroes, as I have said in this chamber before. He said quite openly that there were a number of electorates in Queensland that had had their boundaries rigged-his words not mine-for the benefit of the National Party. So there is the split. The question deals with fair elections. As I have raised this issue in the Senate before, honourable senators would know that I am pleased to say that the question also does away with that odious section 25 of our Constitution. It provides that the Commonwealth Government has to stand aside and respect the decision of any State to pass a special law exempting people from participating in our electoral processes by reason of race.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't you come clean and put that as a separate question?

—I do not know how much cleaner we are supposed to come. One of Senator Hill's assertions was that there was a hidden agenda, particularly on the question of four-year terms. The only way he can make that assumption is if he is prepared to treat people in the Australian electorate as complete and utter mugs. They are not mugs, Senator. I do not think they are mugs but Opposition senators do. Opposition senators think they are born to rule. I would have thought that after five years of being in the boondocks it finally would have got through to Opposition senators that they are not born to rule, that people are not mugs. The whole basis of the argument against four-year terms and simultaneous elections for both the Senate and the House of Representatives is that-and I quote Senator Hill again in another piece of absolute nonsense-the question is designed `to give the Government', not the electorate, `control of the Senate'. What utter nonsense! The only way he can assert that is if we assume that people in the electorates are congenital idiots who do not understand how the Senate functions. They comprehensively do. Not only do they understand it but also they have comprehensively demonstrated it at election after election and at double dissolution after double dissolution for a very long time. The public understands, the electorate understands, that the Senate is a House of review. It is not a States House. That is a sick joke that was even laughed at during the original constitutional conventions because a number of the delegates realised what a nonsense that was then. But the electorate understands, and the makeup of this Senate demonstrates, that this is a House of review.

SPEECH.PARA: The question of simultaneous elections is about accountability and that is what the people opposite are not prepared to face. I know quite a number of people in the Northern Territory-and this is reflected across Australia-who, come the Federal election, deliberately cast a vote in favour of the Labor Party in the lower House because they want a Labor government and just as deliberately, unfortunately for me, cast a vote in favour of the Australian Democrats in the Senate because the Australian electorate understands the role that the Senate plays. The question rests completely in the hands of the Australian electorate and I would have thought this a very democratic way of doing it. The people will decide whether the Senate will be just as accountable for its actions as the House of Representatives. The only basis on which we can make an objection to that is if we are sitting in the Senate and we want to play merry hell politically with what government elected by the people wants to do and not have to face up to the consequences of doing so. It is as simple as that.

Let me turn to Senator Hill's assertion-I have not even got to Senator Short's assertions and I have four pages of them-that this somehow gives the Government control of the Senate. This is an appalling aspersion on the Australian electorate and it is an aspersion which the makeup of this current Senate, provided by the last double dissolution, simply does not support.

Senator Short said that there is a hidden agenda in all these questions. I saw Peter Reith the other night on television putting the No case and Senator Short ran the same line. I waited for the No case in vain. It did not arrive. What Peter Reith said in respect of every question was exactly the same, `There is a trick to this question'. He never got around to explaining what the trick was. He said, `There is a hidden agenda in this question'. He was asked what was wrong with question No. 2. He said, `There is a trick to this question; there is a hidden agenda', but he never got to what the trick was. It was the same all the way through to question No. 4.

At the moment the Opposition is engaged in trying to frighten the daylights out of everyone in the same contemptible way as it is engaged in doing so in the immigration debate. Members of the Opposition have no substance to their debate and no rational arguments for opposing these much overdue reforms to our Australian Constitution and, in the last couple of weeks before polling day, they are engaged in a desperate campaign of trying to frighten the daylights out of everyone. If any constitutional referendum question exemplifies that more than any other, it is the proposal to amend section 116 of the Australian Constitution and I have no doubt that we will be hearing shortly from Senator Harradine about that. I have an interesting position on this.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where do you stand on state aid?

—Let me tell the honourable senator that not only am I a Catholic but also I happen to be a member of the Northern Territory Catholic Education Council. I have a very intense involvement in Catholic education in the Northern Territory and I hold no fears whatsoever for the future of state aid under this Government or any other Government. People who seriously want to address themselves to the question of the Australian Constitution should not have any doubts about it either.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Watson provided another piece of nonsense when he said that the 1981 Council for the Defence of Government Schools (DOGS) case was fought `on the three words which are being taken away from the Constitution by this question'. I have read the DOGS case but, of course, he has not. The DOGS case was fought on nothing of the sort, Senator. It was the question of what constituted the establishment of a religion that the DOGS case was fought on and will continue to be fought on. The other canard on this point was that somehow or other, magically, by changing section 116 the case will automatically be brought back before the High Court, as if there is no way to raise this question again unless the Constitution is amended. Section 92 of the Constitution comprehensively gives the lie to that. That section has been before the High Court more times than I have had hot breakfasts, and I have had a few of those.

TALK.START.PARA: —You look as though you need another one, Senator.

—The honourable senator is running out of arguments. One of the tests that I always had-it never failed-in the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly was that, when Porky or any of them got on to the question of my weight, they had nothing else left to deliver. The question of section 116 can be brought back to the High Court at any time and any number of times by anyone who has the standing to do so. The issue is: do the changes themselves change any of the fundamental principles-the ratio decidendi-used in the original DOGS case? The fact is that they will change nothing of the sort. The High Court does not have great resort to the debates of the Constitutional Convention, but it does have a long history of referring to Quick and Garran if there does need to be any interpretation. This is what Quick and Garran said about section 116:

SPEECH.PARA: By the establishment of religion is meant the erection and recognition of a State church or the concession of special favours, titles and advantages to one church which are denied others.

One does not have to be a lawyer to accept that as an interpretation of that section. It is commonsense. And that is precisely how the High Court has interpreted and will continue to interpret it. The only difference that will be made by the amendment to that particular section of the Constitution-and I think it is a commendable change-is that it is extended to the States as a result of the Grace Bible Church case in 1984. If Senator Short refers to the proceedings of the Constitutional Commission, he will find those matters dealt with. That case extends the prohibition from law-making to the executive actions of government as well-a commendable shift. It does not change the fundamental basis on which the DOGS case was fought, namely, that the provision fairly by government of public money to private schools, on established criteria that have nothing to do with religion, does not constitute the establishment of a religion. I should have thought that was commonsense, and the amendment to that particular section of the Constitution will change nothing.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Justice Murphy?
—Justice Murphy, as all honourable senators know, was the sole dissenting voice in that judgment.
—Can you guarantee that that interpretation will continue?

—Yes, Senator, I think based on the history of the High Court's judgments over the last 80 years I can confidently assert that the High Court will continue to provide that narrow interpretation of section 116 long after I am safely in the grave. Senator Macklin told me today that when he was engaged in debates on this subject in Queensland he had been faced with an argument that he had to answer: the proposed amendment to section 116 was going to lead to the abolition of Christmas. That really typifies the difficulty of trying to cope with the arguments that are being put forward now. The arguments are nonsensical; they are trying to frighten the daylights out of people. I have had it put to me in the Northern Territory that this amendment will mean an end to religious hospitals and religious charitable organisations. It is absolute nonsense. The fact is-and Senator Macklin said it very well, and this debate has demonstrated it-that the amendment will do nothing of the sort. The question of deceit need not concern this Government, which has acted honourably in this matter throughout. It does, however, need to be sheeted home very firmly to the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —There appears to be only a short time for me to speak, but I rise to support the proposition that the referendum proposals, by and large, are deceptive, because that is what they are. I am concerned that Senator Collins has taken an emotional approach-as it were, a public barnstorming approach-instead of taking a look at what has happened. The last question typifies the deceit of these questions. It is a proposal to alter the Constitution to extend inter alia freedom of religion. Section 116 essentially is the anti-establishment clause and it has been interpreted. An identical section in the United States Constitution has been interpreted to ensure anti-religious outcomes.
—That has nothing to do with Australian law.

—It has a lot to do with Australia, because section 116 was placed in the Constitution by the founding fathers-have a look at the debates-using the United States Constitution as the basis for their decision. Mr Justice Murphy pointed to that very fact when he said in the DOGS case that there should be no funding for non-government schools in this country.
—Was he in the majority?

—I am asked whether he was in the majority. No, he was not in the majority. I then ask: Can any member of the Government give a guarantee that in future years the High Court of Australia will not be composed of persons of the same view as Mr Justice Murphy or, indeed, of the same view as that held by the current majority of the United States Supreme Court, which, under an identical provision, has done a number of things, including ban religious instruction in state schools, even where the parents of the students have signed request cards? That is how bad it is.

SPEECH.PARA: In the Australian Bill of Rights debate I raised fears about what the Bill of Rights would do in respect of abortion. At that time I indicated that I was concerned that the provisions of the Bill of Rights could be used to strike down criminal laws on abortion. What was the type of reponse that I received from the Government? Senator Tate publicly stated that the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen)-Catholic father of seven, as he described him-would never have intended that. In fact, Senator Evans said in this chamber on behalf of Mr Bowen that that would not be the case. He said in another context that the provisions of the Australian Bill of Rights would operate like the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms. Is the Government aware that the Supreme Court of Canada, in January this year, struck down the criminal law on abortion in that country on the ground that it infringed the Canadian Charter provision relating to the rights of liberty and security of persons? Identical words were to be found in the Australian Bill of Rights. There is an identical provision in the Australian Bill of Rights. All sorts of guarantees were given by Mr Bowen, but they were worth nothing. The Government will not be able to guarantee that the High Court will not have a majority at some stage in the future which will interpret this provision precisely in the manner in which it has been interpreted in the United States Supreme Court.

TALK.START.PARA: —You had better take 116 out of the Constitution.

—Two of the other questions are also plainly deceptive. Senator Cooney has interjected on me frequently. I think that at one stage he said that the President of the United States has a four-year term. So he has: he has a fixed four-year term. But that is not what question one will achieve. It will not achieve a fixed four-year term. Quite the contrary. I believe that the people of Australia are sick of too frequent elections, but this proposal will not remedy that problem. The problem will not be remedied by a Yes vote to question No. 1. In fact, question No. 1 could equally be posed thus: do you approve of abolishing the fixed term for the Senate and giving more power to the Prime Minister to call an early election? I say that because if people vote yes to the first question the Prime Minister of the day will not need to go through the section 57 hoops which he has to go through now. The Prime Minister and the government of the day can place legislation before the House of Representatives and ram it through. Then it can attempt to ram it through this place. We can hold it up, but the Government can express frustration and say, `We are going to the people'.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government could have done that on the identity (ID) card issue had this proposal been in place at that time. It could have done it on the Bill of Rights had this proposal been in the Constitution at that time. However, it did not do so because this provision was not in the Constitution and time had to be given for the Bills to go back to the House of Representatives and the Senate. By that time, of course, the people of Australia had woken up to the dangers of both those proposals. Eventually, the Government woke up to the fact that it was banging its head against the wall and had no show of getting the Australian Bill of Rights through. Because the Government had to go through the section 57 double dissolution provisions, the ID card legislation was held up, thus giving the people of Australia the opportunity to understand the ramifications of that legislation. If people vote yes to the first proposition, that protection will no longer be there.

The second proposition concerns free and fair elections. It implies that if a person votes yes to that proposition there will be free and fair elections. That is plainly untrue. That provision does nothing to affect the gerrymanders of electoral boundaries. In fact, that provision will diminish the community of interest criteria that are so important for the establishment of electoral boundaries.

My time is almost up, but I want to go to the third question. I recommend a No, No, Yes, No vote. I might be the only one in this chamber recommending that, but I know that many people in my State will vote no to the first question, no to the second, yes to the third, which is the local government one, and no to the fourth. I understand the weight of the arguments against the third question, but I believe that the symbol is there. I believe very firmly in a Yes vote on the third question and a No vote on the rest.

DEBATE.TITLE: SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND PUBLIC ADMINISTRATION

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Government Response to the Further Report on Non-statutory Bodies

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This paper is the Government's response to the further report on non-statutory bodies (NSBs) from the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, which I chair. In that report the Committee reaffirmed its view that there should be a central register of non-statutory bodies of the Government. I am deeply disappointed at the Government's continued negative response to the Committee's recommendation. By giving a further report, we gave the Government the opportunity to come up with a more convincing response than before but, regrettably, there has just been further entrenchment of a difficult to justify position.

One of the arguments in the response is that any difficulty there might be in tracking down reports of NSBs would be significantly reduced by the requirement that parent bodies, in their annual reports, list any NSBs of theirs which produce their own annual reports. That is something, but there is still no explanation of what is meant by a `parent body'. One has to know about all of these unspecified parent bodies to trace an NSB. How much simpler it would be to have a single central register.
The response refers to one of the Committee's witnesses. It states:
It-
that is, the Committee-

decided in favour of a current register, even though Professor Hood, the outside expert whom it consulted and whose opinion it cites as authority for its own, is reported only to have `inclined to the idea of a register updated and published annually'.

My feeling is that that part of the response tries to damn the Committee on the grounds that we suggest something that goes further than does a witness whom we quoted, as if we were unable to use him in support of the basic issue. Professor Hood still supported a central register. Certainly, there was a difference in emphasis about whether that should be kept on a continuous or annual basis, but it does not seem an honest argument to say that it damns the whole question of a register. The response used a whole lot of emotive words, such as:
A current central register would be a trap, creating expectations of reliability but never truly current; liable, rather, to dangerous inaccuracies . . .

The point is that the content of the register would be the responsibility of the relevant Minister. If somehow or other there was an inaccuracy or it was not properly brought up to date, or whatever, the relevant Minister would be answerable for that. This is a gross example of the contempt of some senior public servants for members of this place and for parliamentary committees. I think that sometimes they think we are stupid. The officers concerned either did not read the report or deliberately ignored what we were getting at. The response continued:
. . . annual reports will be more reliable than a central register would be, as responsibility for the accuracy of information they contain will rest directly with the source of the information.

My point in response to that is that the register would have in it only that information lodged by Ministers. No work would be required of those administering the central register. It would require only minor resources. The central register would make more readily available information which should already exist.

I guess there is no point in continuing this ping-pong game with the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet for the moment, but I can assure the Senate that the Committee will keep a close eye on the less than satisfactory arrangement that is proposed of having to monitor non-statutory bodies by looking at a variety of annual reports which provide an historical record only. My only praise for the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet in this matter is that this time the government response was tabled within the required three months.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Senator Coates. I commend his courageous pursuit of the Government on this matter. It is a great shame that his tenacity has been rewarded in such a dishonest manner. The proposal for a central register is one that meets with widespread favour around the world by those parliaments that have considered it. Professor Hood is probably the best qualified expert that one could have to consider the implications of the proposal. I am outraged at the way in which the Government has dishonestly dismissed his view.

SPEECH.PARA: The question is whether we have a central register. The Government for its own purposes has made it consistently clear that it prefers not to have any central register, that it would much prefer to have information maintained in various government departments, reproduced at different times in annual reports and, by definition, almost impossible to collate and to make use of in any sensible form and certainly not with any degree of urgency. It is precisely that strategy which needs to be deplored. It is a classic example of trying to ensure freedom from information and to maintain the veil of secrecy which no doubt the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet thinks is desirable for all other departments to seek.

The way in which the Government response proceeds is to somehow pretend to dismiss Professor Hood altogether on the basis that he was inclined to the idea of a register, updated and published annually, rather than to prefer a continuous model. Even a cursory reading of the report makes it clear that Professor Hood has analysed each and every possible alternative. He has gone, in great detail, to the arguments that have been advanced from time to time against having a central register. In the report we quote him as saying:
It seems to me that none of those arguments are very convincing.

He then proceeds to deal with three reasons for having a central register. The first was a public information case, and he explains why that is very desirable. He referred to the tendencies in political debate for various persons to exaggerate the number of bodies. In every way he spelt out very clearly the advantages of having such a register. The Government has chosen not to attempt to refute any of those; it simply, at a very late stage in the debate, came up with what I regard as plainly desperate stuff. The suggestion that a current central register would be a trap creating expectations of reliability but never truly current, that somehow the agencies would be removed from responsibility, is very shabby.

Quite clearly there is always a monitoring problem. There is always a necessity for individual departments to keep their records up to date. That does not involve them in any abdication of responsibility if they are also required to pass the information on to a central register. Our report found that the cost of doing that would be minuscule, that there are no impedimenta to such a scheme, that there are very cogent examples of how it could be done quite simply. We cited an example of the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories which said in its annual report that the introduction of computer techniques to assist in the compilation of a directory had improved the method of updating and that in place of the former annual review, agencies now supply amendments on a regular basis for continuous updating, thus reducing the lead time for production. It is quite clear that this is a sensible, modern approach to take, that the information in central form would be very valuable and useful. That is precisely why this Government is not interested in any such proposal. It prefers to keep the information diffuse to ensure that those who might be able to make use of it to good advantage are deterred in the greatest possible way.

I regard the response as totally unsatisfactory and unworthy of the Government itself, let alone the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. Senator Coates's efforts deserve a greater reward than they seem to have gained in this instance. If this is all we are going to get by way of Government response, it is clear that this Government is not interested in greater information but rather in less information.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
