DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Report

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The Toomelah report is a very interesting one to have before the Senate 24 hours after we considered the motion which was moved in this place by the Government at the instigation of sundry churchmen and which was the subject of debate here yesterday. We spoke yesterday of the importance of symbols and I spoke in response to the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) and suggested there were a great many practical matters that needed attention. This report, of course, presents a series of glaring examples of the practical difficulties facing many Aboriginal people and many Aboriginal communities. As one goes through that report one reads of inter-government conflicts, one reads of deficiencies of housing and one reads about deficiencies of water and sewerage. It is a chronicle which would dismay any observer. One reads of a failure by Federal, State and local government to come to grips with the very severe problems which are exposed.

A number of additional questions are raised by this sort of report. The report does not address why it is that we have what is effectively a segregated community. It may well be, of course, that the community has come from the past practice of a reserved base community. That is a matter which is not addressed. The answer, therefore, is not apparent on the face of this report. We are told there are about 1,500 people in the township, that there are many children and many unemployed people. The question arises as to why in a community where there are a substantial number of unemployed hands it appears that so little has been done in the way of self-help to try to remedy what is obviously a drastically bad physical environment for that community.

I mentioned that only because again in the debate yesterday I made the point which was made by the Premier of Western Australia, Mr Peter Dowding. I really quoted him in my own defence in making the point that the answer to these problems involved not only an improvement in the standards of services provided by government and on some occasions an increase in resources-although I suspect that on many occasions it is not resources but the effective use of those resources we are talking about; in other words, it is the avoidance of waste. It is also vitally necessary that there be a strong Aboriginal involvement, because without that personal contribution and a determination on the part of the Aboriginal people involved to take control of their lives and to use what resources are available everything else will fail. It is timely that after an essentially theoretical debate about our attitudes to Aboriginal Australians in 1988 we have before us this report of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission signed by His Honour Mr Justice Marcus Einfeld and Sir James Killen and Kaye Mundine. I do not have time in what is a very brief opportunity for debate to go through the findings at any length. We find, for example, in the first chapter of the report:
The Inquiry finds that one result of the existing policy conflicts-
these are conflicts between Commonwealth, State and local government-

is that the residents of Toomelah, and no doubt of other similar communities, are denied many of the benefits and services provided as a matter of right to all non-Aboriginal citizens of the State. They are denied them because they are Aborigines living in Aboriginal communities. Services, if they are provided at all, are more likely to be provided from specialist, usually Federal Aboriginal Affairs budgets. These budgets are then drained from these purposes so that insufficient funds remain for the support of programs which would boost the living standards of Aborigines to par with community norms, ensure their `equal enjoyment or exercise of human rights and fundamental freedoms' and enable them to realise their right, `in community with the other members of their group, to enjoy their own culture, to profess and practise their own religion, [and] to use their own language'.
In one of the gloomy final sentences the report goes on to say:
On the other hand, we have seen nothing to demonstrate a willingness or a capacity within the Department of Aboriginal Affairs adequately to design and deliver programs to achieve these ends.

Mr President, I wish we spent a little less time talking about theory in this place and addressed our minds to the severe and practical problems facing these Aboriginal communities and discussed why it is that a department of which I myself was once Minister is branded as a failure in the way that it is branded as a failure in this report. I believe we might then show a little more sincerity in terms of dealing with the problems of Aboriginal Australians in this bicentennial year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak on similar lines to Senator Chaney on the Toomelah report which seems to me to be a case study of the plight of Aboriginal people in many of such communities around Australia. I must say that in reading the report I find myself embarrassed. It is a real indictment of us all. I refer to the findings in chapter 9:

SPEECH.PARA: The Toomelah community of 500 Aboriginal people endures appalling living conditions which amount to a denial to them of the most basic rights taken for granted by most other groups in society, and by other Australian communities of similar size. Their houses are substandard and overcrowded, actually contributing to a range of diseases. The community has for decades lived without an adequate and certain water supply, a properly functioning sewerage system and a safe means of sewage disposal.
The report continues in the next part of that chapter:

Community members display higher than average rates of a range of debilitating diseases for which they cannot get adequate treatment. They suffer from a lack of adequate education and chronic unemployment. Their traditions have been largely destroyed and their self-esteem is low. Their treatment by Government at all levels has been insensitive and uncaring. Their human rights have been ignored.

In this report the failure of administration is put at all levels of government. It is hard to apportion blame, but it infuriates me in a similar way to Senator Chaney that we get this continuing self-congratulatory rhetoric from the Government when we have reports such as this indicating such basic shortcomings in major functional areas of health, education, housing and the like.

Let me put that in the context of a recent experience I had in visiting the Pitjantjatjara lands in the north-west of South Australia, which would be very familiar to you, Mr Deputy President. I must say that there were things there that I thought were pleasing. Nevertheless, the health clinic in the communities of Kalka and Pipalyatjara, which I abbreviate to Pip because I have trouble with the word, is in fact an empty shipping container that has been turned into a health clinic with no privacy, no separate rooms for men or women. It is an appalling state of affairs that would simply not be tolerated in white communities of that size. They are permanent communities-it is not as if they are there only on a temporary basis-with basic health facilities that are intolerable in the state of Australia's development. The more aware we become as individuals of these shortcomings and the more determined we are to do something in a practical way to overcome them, the better. In this instance the community has no choice but to seek funds from State and Federal governments. State and Federal governments will not support it in providing an adequate medical clinic. I think that is appalling.

In conclusion, it is important for us also to realise that these communities are seeking to do as much as possible about their own difficulties. I refer to an excellent document entitled `An Environmental and Public Health Review within the Anangu and Pitjantjatjara Lands' published in December 1987 which sets out how basic health and housing needs can be met and how some of the major shortcomings that have been indicated to us in this report before the Senate today, albeit in relation to another community, can be resolved in relation to the Pitjantjatjara people. I hope that in the future we will look at the areas in which we can make positive change rather than simply dwell on the rhetoric of Aboriginal affairs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I read the Toomelah report on the Problems and Needs of Aborigines Living on the New South Wales-Queensland border by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission with great concern. I would like to echo the remarks of Senator Chaney who, as an individual, has been more directly involved in trying to help the Aboriginal people to help themselves-with the possible exception of Senator Collins-than anyone else in this chamber. What he did as a compassionate Minister and as a compassionate individual has been of great help to the Aboriginal people.

SPEECH.PARA: One aspect of the report appalled me, although I was also interested in two omissions from it. The description of the behaviour of the local council towards the Aboriginal community is an outrage in a civilised community. The local council did not treat the Aboriginals as equal citizens of the area. It treated them in a way it would not have contemplated treating non-Aboriginal citizens of the shire. It did so for pseudo-legal reasons, but they were obviously phoney reasons. It was a severe indictment of a local organisation to behave like that. It was also an indictment of the State and Federal governments that their arrangements permitted the local shire council to get away with such behaviour.

I was also interested in two things that were not covered in the report by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. Firstly, why was this separate community of Aboriginals created at all? Was it created by the Aboriginals' own choice? Did they want to live as a separate community or were they forced there by the intolerant behaviour of the white community? That surely is a matter which should have been looked at by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. Why do we have this separate community, particularly living in such squalor, with no proper roads, no sewerage, no reliable water supply and substandard housing? Why do they live separately? Why are they not integrated into the rest of the community? That surely should have been a matter for proper report by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. It should have been dealt with in detail.

The other point that worried me was touched on by Senator Chaney. Accepting that the health standards were poor, that the roads were substandard and that the housing was dilapidated and falling down, this was a community with almost total unemployment, with several dozen totally unemployed able-bodied men. Why did they not help themselves to some extent? Why do they have to sit back and wait for the Government to provide? We have made them terminal cases-terminal Government recipients. That is doing them more harm than anything else. I am not suggesting that we endorse or approve the behaviour of the local shire council, but if we have a community that chooses to live separately, if they did so choose, why have we reduced its members to a state of not even being prepared to try to help themselves, sitting back in substandard accommodation complaining of the lack of government support? Obviously the government support is not there. Why have we reduced them to a state of being unwilling or unable to help themselves? It is a severe indictment and an aspect that is not covered by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission in its report.

There are two deficiencies in this report. Why was a separate Aboriginal community created at all and, if it was created by the choice of the Aboriginals, why has the result been that they are unwilling or unable to help themselves? They are the two glaring deficiencies in an otherwise good report.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON REGULATIONS AND ORDINANCES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I present the eighty-fourth report of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances.

The report deals with the motion for disallowance, passed by the Senate on 24 March 1988, of certain freedom of information regulations relating to the Australian Bicentennial Authority. This motion for disallowance was the first occasion since the Committee was established in 1932 that a disallowance motion moved on the Committee's behalf had been passed as a formal motion. It was also the first disallowance motion actually moved on behalf of the Committee since August 1971.

The Committee takes the step of moving for disallowance of delegated legislation on its own initiative only as an act of last resort. It is a drastic remedy to be resorted to on the rare occasion when a Minister declines to accommodate the Committee's concerns about the effects which subordinate laws may have on the rights of people. In this instance, the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) was unwilling to make new regulations restoring the Australian Bicentennial Authority to the schedule of prescribed bodies subject to the Freedom of Information Act 1982.

The Australian Bicentennial Authority was set up in 1980 with the specific object of coordinating the running of events in Australia's bicentennial year. When the legislation was introduced, it contained an amalgam of provisions which allowed the Authority an appropriate degree of autonomy and flexibility to operate in a businesslike way, yet subjected the Authority to ministerial direction and parliamentary accountability. As part of that accountability, the Authority was made subject to the Freedom of Information Act in 1982, through regulations listing those bodies which were regarded as prescribed bodies. These regulations were subsequently amended in December 1983, June 1985, December 1985 and March 1986, but no change was made in the status of the Australian Bicentennial Authority.

Yet, on the eve of Australia's bicentennial year, a regulation was made which excluded the operations of the Authority from the provisions of the Freedom of Information Act. At the time of the making of the regulation, a political controversy broke out concerning the ramifications of excluding the Authority from the provisions of the Act. The Committee did not participate in that debate but looked at the exclusion of the Authority in bipartisan manner being concerned that individual rights to obtain information, especially in the bicentennial year, were being prejudiced by the regulations. The Committee noted the undertaking of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) at that time to ensure that the Authority would still be subject to the provisions of the Freedom of Information Act, but believed that in the interim it was important to have the Authority subject to a legal provision, even if the Government's view was that it could not be enforced. The Committee's view was that the place to test that regulation was in the courts.

The major issue concerning the regulations related to the definition of the word `control'. This issue was based upon a legal interpretation as to who controlled the activities of the Authority. It was the belief of the Attorney-General's Department, in three legal opinions to the Attorney-General which were supported by a number of legal decisions, that the Commonwealth was not in a position to exercise control over the Authority. Hence, using this strict company law interpretation of the word `control', the Government's view was that the Commonwealth could not control the activities of the Authority and, therefore, the Authority failed to be a prescribed authority within the terms of subsection 4 (1) of the Freedom of Information Act. The Committee was concerned that none of the legal opinions looked closely at the powers conferred on the Australian Bicentennial Authority, preferring to concentrate on the application of company law concepts and legal precedents in what was clearly a hybrid and unusual body. None of the entities referred to by the courts in the decisions that had been cited on the meaning of control was a body subject to an Act of parliament which conferred a wide range of directive powers on government.

In the Committee's opinion, the question of whether the statutory powers amounted to a requisite degree of control had been dealt with in a less than satisfactory way. Those powers and discretions appeared to be a source of considerable potential control over many aspects of the Authority's existence and operations. It struck the Committee that the power to give policy directions which had to be obeyed, the power to appoint a majority of the directors, the power to terminate the Chairman's appointment on six months' notice and the power to issue directions for the expenditure of money were considerable degrees of power.

In the final analysis, the Committee recognised that the issue of the applicability of the Freedom of Information Act involved extremely difficult legal questions about which there was no definitive opinion or recommendation that could be followed. This matter was made more difficult because of the political controversy that the removal of the Authority from the provisions of the Freedom of Information Act had caused at the time. I said in March:

The Committee is anxious, in a bipartisan spirit, to remain above the politics of this situation. A remedial Bill will, hopefully, very soon make this statement and tomorrow's disallowance merely a matter of history. But until then, the Regulations and Ordinances Committee must act in defence of the principle that the right to freedom of information about the affairs of the Authority should be a legal and enforceable right as far as the law, as applied by the courts, will allow. That was the situation until Regulation 3 was made. Disallowance will return us to that preferable situation while we wait for the legislation.

I am happy to say that the remedial Bill was passed by this Parliament on 3 June 1988 and came into operation on 1 July 1988. From that date, any doubt as to the Authority being subject to the Freedom of Information Act was removed. I believe that this report once again shows the importance of the watchdog role that the Committee performs in this Parliament. What many people may regard as an insignificantly brief regulation contained an important limitation on the rights of individuals to obtain information concerning an authority which had been entrusted to organise significant events on behalf of this country and to spend large sums of taxpayers' money in the bicentennial year.

The Committee's action in moving the motion of disallowance of regulation 3 of the Freedom of Information (Miscellaneous Provisions) Regulations, and the Senate's response in passing that motion without the need for any debate, will, I hope, provide a useful guideline whenever it is proposed in future to amend delegated legislation to make it clear that assumed rights do not, in fact, exist. The Committee will not lightly accept that delegated legislation may be used to remove purportedly doubtful rights before their validity is clarified by a court, or confirmed by an Act of Parliament. I wish to thank my fellow members of the Committee for their bipartisan support on this matter. In closing, I would also like to commend the scrupulous way in which the former secretary of the Committee, Peter O'Keeffe, carried out his work and congratulate him on his recent promotion. I was very sorry to hear that Peter is quite ill. I wish him a speedy recovery and a speedy return to the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances I am delivering on behalf of the Deputy Chairman of the Committee, Senator Bronwyn Bishop, who is absent from the chamber on parliamentary business, a statement in support of Senator Collins's remarks. The Committee, as is its practice, examined the question of disallowance in a bipartisan way without indulging in any of the political debate that occurred outside the Committee. The long-held tradition that members do not use the Committee for the purpose of political pointscoring while acting for or on behalf of the Committee has given the Committee its strength to meet the Executive on equal terms in ensuring that the Committee's criteria are always upheld to make certain that individuals' rights and freedoms are protected.

SPEECH.PARA: Having reiterated the premise which is the basis of the Committee's existence, it is interesting to note when turning to the report just how important a role the Committee can play in the protection of an individual's right to seek information under the Freedom of Information Act. I draw honourable senators' attention to paragraph 9.1, part (e), which states, in part, that the name of the Authority was removed from the schedule as part of a larger `tidying up' exercise and `insufficient attention was given to the policy implications'. This view was expressed in one of the legal opinions submitted to the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) by his Department. The Committee then makes the following and, I believe, important statement:

Over a period of some 18 months there was at the very least a surprising failure within the Attorney-General's Department to grasp the significance for personal rights and liberties of the advice prepared in November 1986 and confirmed in May 1987 that freedom of information rights did not, and had never, existed.

I hope that officials from the Attorney-General's Department and other government departments take a close look at the implications of that statement which are the key to this report, namely, that in looking at subordinate legislation the personal rights and liberties factors cannot be ignored. If they are ignored, the Regulations and Ordinances Committee will act in its bipartisan manner to ensure that they are restored. I should emphasise the fact that it took over 18 months for the Department to act on this matter and when it finally did act it was only a matter of weeks before the bicentennial year commenced, thereby depriving individuals of the right to seek information from an Authority which is and has played a major role in the bicentennial year.

Turning to the difference in legal opinion that occurred between the Committee and the Attorney-General's Department, I refer honourable senators to the speeches made on this issue in March of this year, but would like to emphasise a comment that I made at that time:

In a situation of such doubt, the Committee prefers, as a matter of principle, to leave it up to the courts to determine, if necessary, whether the Freedom of Information Act applies to the Australian Bicentennial Authority. Regulation 3 removes from the courts any right to decide whether the Act applies because it expressly and unequivocally removes the Authority from the scope of the Freedom of Information Act. Previously it was thought that individuals had a clear, justifiable right to freedom of information regarding the Authority. Doubts were raised about that proposition. Now by virtue of the regulation there are no legal rights whatsoever. Disallowance of regulation 3 will revive the previous regulation and restore the status quo pending the passage of a Bill to place the entire matter beyond doubt by providing that the Freedom of Information Act does unquestionably apply.
The simple fact that the Senate concurred with the Committee's view by allowing a formal motion to be passed is a vindication of the principle enunciated in that comment.

I join Senator Collins in thanking the then secretary of the Committee, Mr Peter O'Keeffe, for the work he undertook in relation to this matter, and urge honourable senators to read this significant report. I add my and Senator Bishop's congratulations to Peter O'Keeffe on his promotion and reiterate our wishes for his speedy recovery from his illness.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: REFERENDUM (MACHINERY PROVISIONS) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1988REFERENDUM (MACHINERY PROVISIONS) (INFORMAL BALLOT-PAPERS) BILL 1988

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the debate was interrupted earlier today I was responding to a question that Senator Macklin had asked: whether I had included any transitional arrangements in the Opposition's Referendum (Machinery Provisions) (Informal Ballot-Papers) Bill to meet the claim that there would be two classes of voter for the 3 September referendums if the Bill were enacted before then. The argument being put by some, including apparently the Attorney-General's Department, is that we would get two classes of voter in the sense that some people have already voted-for example, through postal votes-and that these voters would somehow be treated differently if the Opposition's Bill were enacted and applied only to those persons who have not yet voted, including of course all those millions of people who will vote at polling booths on the referendum day, 3 September. The answer to Senator Macklin's question is no, the Opposition has not included any transitional arrangements to take account of that assertion. I do not know whether it would be possible to include any such arrangements. More importantly, the Opposition does not believe that this would be necessary, because we do not believe that the Bill would create two classes of voter for the forthcoming referendums.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill is procedural. It does not change the substance of the method of voting; on the contrary, it is strongly supportive of what is written on the referendum ballot papers, namely, that voters should register their vote only in the form of the words `yes' or `no'. The Opposition's Bill has nothing to do with the casting of one's vote; rather, it is about the counting of that vote. I fail to see how that can be said to create two classes of voter.

Senator Macklin said that voters who have already voted may have been misled by being told that ticks and some crosses may constitute valid votes. That, of course, is not so. The only reference to ticks and crosses has been in guidelines issued by the Australian Electoral Commission to polling booth officials. There has been no public statement that ticks or crosses are acceptable ways of voting. Indeed, such a statement would, as Senator Robert Ray pointed out this afternoon, be illegal in any event.

The two classes of voters assertion, apparently, has come in the form of relatively informal advice to the Government from the Attorney-General's Department. So far the Minister for Home Affairs, Senator Robert Ray, has not felt able or been prepared to table that advice. Again, I ask the Minister to do so. I believe that he said today that the Attorney-General's Department had advised that there was `some doubt about the constitutional validity' of the referendum if the Bill was enacted. Certainly, that advice does not sound to be definitive advice by any means. I think the Minister also said that he would `be interested to hear other legal advice'. I hope that he will seek further advice, either more formal advice from the Attorney-General's Department than he appears to have at the moment, or independent advice. The Opposition has already informally sought legal advice, as I said earlier today. That informal advice is contrary to that of the Attorney-General's Department.

I urge the Government to put this Bill before the House of Representatives for debate and speedy passage as a matter of urgency. It is in accord with the wishes of all parties and with the unanimous recommendation of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. Of course, it has very significant implications. It is essential that voters' intentions at the referendum be indisputably clear; only the passage of this Bill will ensure that that occurs.
Bill agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is now debating what has been described by the Government as a major industrial relations reform. It is a rather belated follow-up to the Hancock Committee of Review of the Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems, which sat for a very considerable time and produced a voluminous report. The Government delayed its response for a very considerable time. The Government introduced a Bill in May last year. That Bill produced a storm of protest which related to the attempt by the Government to cut off access to the common law injunction in industrial disputes and also put some barriers or pre-conditions in the path of people seeking to use sections 45d and e of the Trade Practices Act-sections which became very widely known in Australia because of their use in the dispute at Mudginberri. In a rare example of employer unanimity, all sorts of employers in Australia were united in saying to the Government that they did not wish to see those changes to the law. In that regard, they spoke with one voice with the Opposition. The Government withdrew its Bill and it was not until May this year that Mr Willis reintroduced legislation which is in some ways an improvement on the legislation of last year, but which is in other ways a clear step backwards.

SPEECH.PARA: We are about to commence serious debate on the Industrial Relations Bill 1988 because in the House of Representatives, as is so often the case, a tiny amount of time was allowed for discussion and debate. Mr Willis described this as a major reform of industrial relations. We know that industrial relations is a matter of enormous interest and, indeed, concern, to the Australian people, yet it was allowed 3 1/2 hours of debating time. No opportunity was given for a committee consideration of the Bill. In other words, detailed concerns of the Opposition could not be expressed in the House of Representatives and amendments to the legislation could not be moved in the House of Representatives.

I am pleased that we have the prospect of a genuine debate on this legislation in the Senate and of a committee debate which will enable us to deal with the detailed concerns of the community, the detailed concerns of the Opposition and, I understand, some concerns which will be expressed by the Australian Democrats. We face a lengthy debate, but I believe that, as in the past, that lengthy debate will serve a useful purpose in educating the public further about what the Government is doing and about the errors in what the Government is doing. Also, I hope there will be opportunity, if the required majority is obtained in the chamber, for substantial amendments to be made to the legislation, because I think those substantial amendments are required.

The debate is taking place in the context of relative complacency about industrial relations. I open the debate for the Opposition by pointing out that there is no room for complacency about the state of industrial relations in this country. The major difference between the situation in Australia now and the situation in May 1986 when the Treasurer, Mr Keating, warned us that we were in danger of achieving banana republic status is that there has been a quite remarkable turnaround in the terms of trade. Whereas Mr Keating was continually telling us until that turnaround occurred that the difficulties we faced were a product of declining prices for our exports, now that he has been put in a rather more comfortable position, and the Australian economy has been put in a more comfortable position by an improvement in the price of our exports, there is this almost conspiracy of silence about the continuing weaknesses which afflict the Australian economy. The truth is, of course, that the position could change at any time. The reality of our failure to come to grips with the need to increase productivity quickly in this country and to get a more flexible labour market will again become a matter of great public urgency.

We have an extraordinary level of external debt. That level of debt has yet to stabilise. It has been affected favourably, of course, by the revaluation of the Australian dollar. But the fact is that we face a very long period with significant balance of payments deficits. It will be a long time before we can say with any confidence that we have stabilised our external debt. We have a situation in which the members of the Australian work force are entitled to question the system because it has delivered to them static or declining real wages. It has done that in the context of ever-increasing debt. In other words, even though Australian living standards under the current arrangements are declining, we have, during that period of decline, been going into increasing debt. So, the negative for the members of the Australian work force is even greater than the pressure that they have felt between the pincers of declining real wages and higher taxation. Those problems have not disappeared.

Our productivity, as I said before, is stagnant. We have a situation in which we have predicted productivity growth, if one looks at the budget figuring, of 0.75 per cent over the current financial year, following growth of approximately half a per cent last year. When one looks at the current situation and compares us with the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development generally, one sees that we have a labour productivity situation in which the figures that I have for 1986-89, which include some estimates for the current year, show Australia with a productivity increase of half the OECD average. There is no room for complacency there if we want Australian living standards to improve.
We have had nominal wage rises which in general are about twice as fast as the wage rises in our trading competitors. I have a paper which I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: We find in every economic survey of Australia, whether it is by the OECD or by some private body, that greater labour market flexibility is an essential element in improving the Australian economic situation. We now find the Labor Government saying the same thing. The Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission can, and still does, obstruct direct employer-employee negotiations in the interests of the centralised system. I am sorry that Senator Button is not yet with us at the table. He is the Minister in charge of this Bill. I understand that he will be with us during the committee stage of the debate. I am sorry he is not here now because no other Minister in the Government is clearer in his thinking on the importance of having employer-employee relations which are productive and positive. He talks about having a productive culture.

Yet in this debate I will give examples of employers and employees who have sought to work together, who have reached agreement on the way they should work together and who have been obstructed by the system of conciliation and arbitration from doing so. In this country we regard as major advances things like the second tier wage negotiations and the award restructuring principles of the current wage case. When we examine those things we see that they are simply means of trying to impress upon the enterprises the need for flexibility. Yet we are doing that in a very bureaucratic and centralised way which in itself can be a barrier to change. There is an inherent illogicality, an inherent conflict, in the system as it is and in the demands of the modern economic world. Perhaps the most serious thing is that in this country we continue to allow the oppression of individuals, whether they are employers or employees--

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—Senator Burns laughs. I invite Senator Burns to read the judgment of the Victorian Supreme Court in the Dollar Sweets case. Let him examine the position of the driver who is dragged from his truck, assaulted and kicked and whose health is permanently impaired. That is the sort of minority behaviour which still occurs in this country and which is a disgrace. When Senator Burns giggles and objects to references to it he does less than justice to his oath of office and to the country which he is supposed to be looking after in the Senate. We do not stand for the oppression of individuals in that way, whether they are employers or employees, and that is a deficiency in the present system which needs to be remedied too.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer the Senate to the continuance of absurd work practices which have been identified, not merely by Liberal and National Party members in this place, but by many Labor Party observers and many honest observers of the industrial scene. There are plenty of hard figures available on the enormous cost to Australia of many of these restrictive work practices. On the waterfront we have a situation in regard to productivity in Australian container terminals. In the Business Council Bulletin of June 1988 we are told:

Lifting productivity in Australian container terminals would save at least $125 million per annum. Changes in manning and closure of under-utilised facilities could provide savings over and above this amount.

When we look at the time taken to unload and to unpack containers in this country and compare it with the European figures, the United States figures and the figures of East or South Asia, we see an appalling amount of waste in this country.
