TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. When we look at those figures we find that Australia is among the worst. We find that in many of the countries which are admired by the Labor movement in this country the figures are almost invisible. Somebody in industry said to me the other day, `We are one of the few countries left in the world where strikes are seen as an answer'. I ask honourable senators opposite to study that table, to look at the days lost per thousand in Japan-4.3-compare that with Australia, at 202, and ask: Is it any wonder that we are losing the economic race?

SPEECH.PARA: I simply pose those matters because this debate is important. It goes to an area of Australian life which is fundamentally in need of correction. If Senator Burns and some of his trade union friends feel that that is unfair and unjust, I simply remind them that, on the very day on which John Howard, in his response to the May statement, identified deregulation of the labour market as the key to achieving higher productivity, their Treasurer, Mr Keating, was reported as follows:
. . . that labour market reform was the `last great area of change to be overcome'.
He said the policy objective was to create a flexible industrial relations system in which wages and conditions reflected the different levels of prosperity of different industries.

I welcome the recognition of the reality that is emerging in this country because that recognition will precede and help the changes that are needed. We do not need to be in an adversary situation on this matter if we realistically assess what is required. The differences between the Government and us are really quite critical in the area of the pace of change. Everyone now seems to accept the need for flexibility, for work place emphasis. Yet in this Bill the Government is putting down a restatement of an approach which puts barriers in the path of that flexibility and work place emphasis. A good deal of what the Government is doing in this area clearly is simply to preserve labour interests and institutional interests which are not necessarily the interests of the Australian people generally.

So, our general charge with respect to this Bill-and we will have many specific charges which I will not have a chance to deal with in this second reading debate, but will have an ample chance to deal with in the committee stage-is that this Bill fails Australia. It does not meet the current needs. Paul Keating may have caught up with what John Howard was saying five years ago about labour market flexibility being the essential next area of reform, but this Bill does not reflect that recognition by the Government of how essential this is.

We are looking at a Bill which maintains heavily controlled, centralised and essentially bureaucratic procedures. For people who doubt that, let me give some specific examples. I say to Senator Burns that these examples happen to have been drawn from the State of Queensland so they may be examples with which he is familiar. Two of them relate to the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union, which has not had a good record in terms of the negotiation of second tier arrangements, not nearly as good, for example, as the metal workers who were much quicker into that business as they have been into the business of award restructuring. But in a number of enterprises that union was able to force employers into granting a 4 per cent increase without any productivity improvements. Where the union has not had the ability to do that a number of employees have simply missed out. Their union has not been able to do the necessary work for them which involved negotiations with employers.

As a result of that rather defective attitude on the part of that union some employers in the industry decided to enter into negotiations with their own employees. One company was Castle Bacon Pty Ltd which employs 550 workers in Victoria, so the first example is from Victoria. The company reached agreement with the great majority of its employees on productivity improvements which were worth at least 4 per cent and 485 of the employees signed individual agreements governing those changes and their entitlement to extra pay. They elected six representatives to put their case to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. The employer then applied to the Commission to give effect to the agreement under the restructuring and efficiency principle. In other words, by agreement, these employees, having dealt with their employer, were to get increased pay and they agreed that they could improve the effectiveness of their work in a whole series of ways. That application was opposed by the union and the Commission. Commissioner Caesar, who was sitting, found that an agreement of the nature contemplated by the wages principle did not exist. The Commission then arbitrated, awarded the 4 per cent increase and deleted most of the productivity improvements contained in the original agreement. I ask: Where is the sense of that? Here we have an agreement between an employer and employees and the Arbitration Commission simply moves in and destroys that because the union objects to it.

The other example, which was a Queensland example, involved Deputy President Riordan. He directed in this case that all discussions among the parties should involve the union, the employer organisation and the employer. He directed:

. . . employer initiated conferences at an enterprise level occurring without the presence of the union should cease because such conferences will not assist this Commission in its important task of preventing and resolving disputes.

The words I have just read are from Deputy President Riordan. In my words he is saying that employers should not talk directly to their employees because the union does not like it. I have those decisions here and I would be happy to share them with Labor, Liberal, or National senators in this place. I simply give them as an example of a structure which can get in the way of the sort of productive culture which Senator Button, who is now at the table, has been urging is required in this country. That is why we will be arguing that this Bill must provide for a greater degree of flexibility than the Government is prepared to allow.

There are further examples which I will not have time to deal with in this second reading debate. For example, unions at Sanctuary Cove arrived at a common agreement governing employees across a range of jobs which were satisfactory to them and satisfactory to the local Commission and which has now been challenged in the Federal Commission because it does not apply, as this new law will say things should apply, across the board in industry. In other words, there is the active obstruction of people who are trying to do precisely what Senator Button is lecturing them and urging them to do-and I use the word `lecturing' in the positive sense-that is, to find more cooperative and productive ways to work together. The first voluntary agreement in Queensland, under the Queensland Government's voluntary employment agreements, is being challenged before the Federal Conciliation and Arbitration Commission because unions cannot stand the thought that these people--

TALK.START.PARA: —By one union.

—By one union, but we wish to deprive that one union of the chance to do this. If people wish to have the freedom to enter into productive agreements as a voluntary matter, why should that be a matter which should be stopped by this system? So that is very squarely, put in example form, what we are concerned about. We want to see a system where people can do what the Government, with its other voices, is urging them to do to enable them to work flexibly and cooperatively together.

SPEECH.PARA: Our complaints about this Bill relate to our fundamental economic objectives which are to have a more productive, more wealthy economy which can pay off our debts and deliver higher living standards to the working men and women of Australia. Our second set of objectives, which is closely allied with the first, relates to the promotion of individual rights and freedoms in an area where individual rights and freedoms too often are ignored. We are seeking to foster productive and cooperative change.

Our main complaint about this legislation relates to what has been omitted. There is, for example, no protection in this legislation of freedom of association and no protection of the right not to join a trade union. I do not know how the Government maintains its apparent support for the Universal Declaration of Human Rights which provides that we have the right of peaceful assembly and association and specifically provides that no-one may be compelled to belong to an association. I do not know how the Government can subscribe to the International Labour Organisation conventions concerning freedom of association and yet deny individual Australians the right not to join a trade union. But that is what this Bill does. Effectively, this Bill enables the continuance of de facto compulsory unionism through the preference clause. We believe that that is a matter which is against the individual interest and against the long term economic interests of this country.

We are very concerned that this Bill omits what Mr Willis was prepared to provide in his May Bill last year, which is effective compliance provisions within the system. This is what Mr Willis had to say on 14 May last year:

An essential element of any industrial relations system which provides benefits and protections to registered organisations and their members is that there should be effective means of ensuring compliance with the decisions of its institutions . . .
He said a little later in his second reading speech:

The principal initiative is that the present bans clause provisions, which have long since fallen into disrepute and are now substantially moribund, will be replaced by a new direction and injunction process.

Mr Willis said in May 1987 that the present compliance provisions, the measures that could be taken to make unions obey directions of the Commission, are moribund. He proposed an effective direction and compliance provision. In the course of the election campaign, when that Bill had been withdrawn, Mr Willis said in my presence in Melbourne:
That will leave us with a compliance system which is more similar to the one which currently exists-
he was talking about the new Bill that he would introduce-

but with some very substantial differences, a direction system which I believe will be much more effective than the current bans clause which has virtually been moribund for 20 years and also with an array of non-monetary penalties where unions or the employers refuse to accept Commission decisions or orders.
On 17 August Mr Crean spoke. Mr Crean, no doubt having heard what Mr Willis was still saying, said this:
They can still introduce a Bill but it will have to be one which does not do anything on compliance.

We now have a Bill which meets not what Mr Willis promised in the election campaign; we have a Bill which meets what Mr Crean said the Government could do in August after the election. I think that is a shameful situation. We will certainly move amendments which will put into the Bill precisely the sorts of measures that Mr Willis was saying in May 1987 were required. I might say that the Metal Trades Industry Association, which has been in the forefront of working with the metal trades unions on the new award restructuring proposals, has been loud in its support for the private member's Bill which we have put in and which puts this direction and injunction procedure forward.

TALK.START.PARA: —Taking orders from employers.

—These are comments made after we had introduced our legislation-a very important difference. What the Metal Trades Industry Association had to say was that we had done the community a service by focusing attention on the need for long overdue compliance provisions in the compulsory conciliation and arbitration system. The Association went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition's Bill has been carefully drafted with the practicalities of day to day industrial relations in mind. It contains no provisions which any fair minded person prepared to abide by the rules of compulsory conciliation and arbitration could object to. On the other hand, it removes the present imbalances which exist and which favour recalcitrant unions at the expense of employers who are trying to work within the system.
That is an area which will be the subject of major debate in the committee stage of the Bill.

I want to touch on another area which is probably even more fundamental. This Bill contains provisions which alter the arrangements for trade union amalgamation. Those provisions are clearly in line with the ambition of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) to obtain a relatively small number of large unions in Australia. Those plans were outlined by Mr Kelty and they have been made very clear by the ACTU. This Bill not only introduces a new minimum size for unions of 3,000 members-a matter strongly objected to by many small unions-but also opens up the possibility of forced amalgamations and eases the way for amalgamations which will not produce the sort of industry base or enterprise framework that is wanted by people who are concerned about the effective operation of enterprises within this country but which, on the current record of what is happening now with respect to union amalgamation, is clearly going to produce large union structures with no typical logic in terms of employer-employee relationships. Again, that is a matter that can be dealt with in more detail in the debate at the committee stage and by other speakers in this debate.

Big is not beautiful in this area. When this Bill was introduced the Opposition looked at the most recent statistics on demarcation disputes and, of the 32 disputes we examined, only one involved a union that would be affected by the amalgamation provisions. Almost all of the demarcation disputes involved large unions, such as the Storemen and Packers Union and the metal workers and other unions which on any description are large unions.

The other matter that is of great concern to the Opposition is the general lack of flexibility. I have dealt with that by way of example. The sorts of examples that I have given will continue to occur under the new system. I agree that the present system has moved in a number of important ways to try to encourage flexibility, but I have given examples of the way in which intervention by the Commission stands between employers and employees who are trying to work together constructively for themselves, for greater profits for employers or higher rewards for employees-the combination that this country surely wants.

The Opposition is opposed to payments of strike pay. We are opposed to the overriding of State legislation. We are opposed to the idea that conditions of employment should as far as possible be uniform, when Mr Keating himself has said-I have already quoted him on the day of our response to the May statement-that what we want is greater flexibility. Elements of this Government are working hard to try to push this country in the direction in which it must go. It is the view of the Opposition that in significant ways this legislation moves contrary to the basic thrust of the economic plans of the Government. The Government should reconsider the legislation. It should redraft it and design it so that it will fit in with its industry and general economic policy in a way that will be much more productive for Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today the Senate is debating the Industrial Relations Bill 1988. We are fortunate to live in a country that is inherently rich, with a highly educated population. Though we have tertiary institutions with courses in industrial relations, we have one of the worst industrial relations records in the world. We have a disgraceful reputation which adversely affects investment and our export trade; it costs us jobs-the jobs of many Australians. Notwithstanding this appalling record, the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) claimed in his second reading speech that with this Bill the Government was improving a system which had served Australia well. He also described the Bill as the most substantial revision of Australia's industrial relations system since 1904. Both these statements are a joke. Nothing could be further from the truth.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government says that industrial relations have improved over the last few years, and so they have-but relative to other periods in the nation's history. Relative to the rest of the world our record is an embarrassment. Senator Chaney has already tabled figures to prove that point. They are facts. I can tell honourable senators from personal experience that marketing Australian exports is no fun when most negotiations and discussions centre on buyer concerns about lack of reliability because of strikes in key areas-strikes that cannot be predicted, strikes that hold up imports and put buyers in the position where they are required to diversify imports of goods, equipment and commodities that they would prefer to buy from Australia. The effect on negotiations is such that it decreases the quantities we supply and the prices we obtain.

It is worth pointing out that from an industry point of view probably the worst period of industrial turmoil and blackmail was the sustained period when the man who is now Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU). He probably thought he was successful. I can recall him bragging to press people about how successful he was. And so he was, if success is measured by the number of industries lost and, more importantly, the number of jobs lost-in many cases lost forever-from this country. Recovery, particularly in our manufacturing industry, must occur if Australians are to restore their standard of living. I am sure Senator Walsh would agree with that statement and support it.

Australia must produce more goods, both for import replacement and for export. To achieve this, a number of things must occur. Australia must have an interest rate equivalent to that of its trading partners. We must have inflation that is somewhere near the same ball park level as that of our trading partners. In the particular area the Senate is debating today-industrial relations-we must become more productive. Our unit cost of production must come down to be equal to or less than that of our competitors. If business is to grow, we must be able to borrow at rates comparable with those of our trading partners.

Of vital importance in achieving these goals and restoring confidence is the necessity to rid ourselves of an industrial system that has not served Australia well. One need only look back in history to prove that point. The system, because of its rigidity and because of excessive power in the hands of a few powerful trade union leaders, has destroyed complete industries over the last few decades. We must have an industrial relations system that is productivity orientated-not a centralised system based on big government and big unions, but a system at the enterprise level.

Employees and their employers at an enterprise level are in the same boat. That is a comment often made to persons marketing exports by our major trading partner-the Japanese. They have great difficulty in understanding why we in Australia cannot comprehend that simple matter. In many industries that relationship does exist. Sen- ator Chaney referred in this speech to a few. I know of others where we have achieved success in this country. Nucleonics is one that we all know reasonably well. Palmer Tube Mills Australia Pty Ltd is a company in a recent growth industry. There is an intimate relationship between employer and employee, all of whom are kicking in the same direction. The success of individuals, in respect of their rewards, achievements and preservation of their jobs, depends on employers and employees pulling in the same direction. The result is an increase in productivity. Firms become more competitive and create more jobs.

We should and must look at and learn from countries which have been successful. The most successful country this world has ever seen, from an economic point of view, certainly in the lifetime of all honourable senators, is Japan. Its near neighbours, Korea and Taiwan, had no hesitation in learning from Japan. In many industries they are now competitive with that country. The key to Japanese success came about from a national will to be the best, and to succeed has been its approach to industrial relations. That is what we want to engender in this country. We do not want hang-ups that go back a century, that in recent times have put us in a position in which our standard of living has been reduced, industries have been destroyed and jobs have been lost.

I can recall being in Japan in the 1970s when there was one of the few strikes that have taken place in that country. The strike was at Mitsubishi's heavy industries plant. The reason for the strike was that Mitsubishi had cut back the working week from six days to 5 1/2 days. The workers were on strike because they believed that such a cutback would make them less competitive on world markets, thus reducing growth and eventually putting their jobs at risk. I recount this little story to highlight the attitudinal difference between our unions and theirs. While ours have been doing their best for decades to destroy industries and jobs-I know that they do not do so consciously-by featherbedding and all the other things we know about, the whole thrust in Japan has been to develop and grow. The Japanese knew that they would reap the rewards and they are reaping the rewards today.

There has been some improvement in recent years in pockets, such as the motor vehicle industry. I believe that that has occurred not because of any accords but because of the necessity of survival. It is a great pity that we have to reach that survival stage before things happen. Regrettably, one cannot say the same about the coal industry of which you, Mr Acting Deputy President, would be aware, coming from the same State as I do. Restrictive work practices, which the unions would call hard-won gains, have been entrenched in the coal industry for many years. Everyone knows that for the industry and companies to survive, and certainly to grow, in some areas, those old practices must go. Many were introduced at a time of great prosperity in that industry. I would say that at that time the industry could afford it, but it can no longer afford it.

Let me give a few examples. Machinery, which is very expensive capital equipment, must stop at midnight on Friday and cannot start up again until midnight on Sunday. Moves were made and agreements were close to being reached-in fact, they were reached in Queensland-between employees and mining officials in the coal industry to remove some of those practices in an effort to keep the industry going, to make it more productive and to increase jobs. By not removing those practices, union members in the underground mines destroyed themselves. In the open cut areas overburden on coal can be removed seven days a week, 24 hours a day; yet, underground, work has to stop at midnight on Friday and cannot start again until midnight on Sunday.

The effect of introducing shifts would have been the employment of more men. It would have lowered the unit costs of production and made coal more competitive. It would have meant that more could be sold on export markets. What happened? The Australian Coal Consultative Council, which is dominated by the left wing unions of New South Wales, overrode the agreement that had been reached in Queensland and, as a result, there was a 14-day strike in which nobody won and everybody lost. The miners lost two weeks' salary, the companies lost production and this country lost exports.

What I am saying is that the system that allows this to happen is at fault. I do not blame some trade union leaders; they are doing their job. They might not be doing it in a way which I agree with. In fact, they are doing it in a way which I totally disagree with, but what is at fault is the system whereby agreements were reached and overturned simply because of the weight of numbers from some other part of Australia. That is what happens in a centralised monopoly control situation. It does not matter whether one is talking about the labour market or the product market.

There are five major problems with this legislation. First of all, it does not deregulate the labour market but rather enhances the monopoly of centralised trade union power, perpetuating a system which has caused enormous problems to this country. It will cause problems to this Government in time. It caused problems to the last Government and to the Chifley Government. I remind honourable senators of the problems that occurred with not only the Chifley Government but also the Curtin Government during the war. Secondly, the compliance provisions do not exist. Thirdly, the legislation entrenches compulsory unionism. Fourthly, there are problems of union amalgamation, which I will refer to in more detail. Finally, there are payments for health and safety strikes.

On the compliance provisions, the Government claims that the Industrial Relations Bill represents the most substantial revision of Australia's federal industrial relations system since 1904. The Bill fails to tackle a number of glaring problems in the current system. The most obvious shortcoming is that it fails to rectify the existing lopsided nature of the arbitration system and does not introduce effective compliance provisions which would give the new Industrial Relations Commission the power to enforce its decisions and directions. Trade union compliance with the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission is virtually optional these days.

Again, I refer to the coal industry. A direction was given by the Coal Industry Tribunal and the unions thumbed their noses. Nothing happened. As I said earlier, everybody lost. The men lost their wages, the industry lost production and this country lost export income. Even though the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) recognised how useless the Commission's compliance regulations were when he introduced the first Industrial Relations Bill last year, he said:

An essential element of any industrial relations system which provides benefits and protection to registered organisations and their members is that there should be effective means of ensuring adherence to the principles on which the system is founded and compliance with the decisions of its institutions.
He went on to say:

The principal initiative is that the present bans clause provisions, which have long since fallen into disrepute and are now substantially moribund, will be replaced by a new direction and injunction process.

The Minister blamed employer hostility to the 1987 version of the Bill for new compliance measures having been dropped from the Bill before us. That is an incredibly pathetic excuse for the Government's caving into ACTU pressure. Simon Crean told the Government in an interview in the Australian Financial Review of 17 August 1987:

Our position is that if the Bill does not touch Common Law or the secondary boycott provision of the Trade Practices Act then it must not increase or strengthen sanctions. They can still introduce a Bill but it will have to be one which does not do anything on compliance.
This is another example of the Government doing what the ACTU demands.

The third point relates to the lack of protection against compulsory unionism. This Bill fails to protect the right of workers not to join a trade union and permits the continuation of de facto compulsory unionism through the use of preference clauses and industrial pressure. Compulsory unionism is a brutal reality in Australia today. It cannot be enforced by law but it is widely practised. A combination of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission's preference clauses and trade union power implement and maintain compulsory unionism. If a worker chooses not to join a union he can be harassed and, in many cases, can lose his livelihood. I will not go into one of the many cases I could tell the Senate about today, but it happens all the time.

Let us take an example-and one would not expect this sort of thing to happen in Australia-of the way compulsory union membership can be enforced by union muscle, where we have closed shop preference clauses. We have a great example of this in Broken Hill where the mining industry has what it calls `badge show day'. It makes sure that in the Broken Hill local newspaper the rules are printed so that if anyone goes to work and does not comply with the requirements of badge show day he is in trouble. I seek leave to incorporate those rules in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
BADGE SHOW RULES
The Barrier Industrial Council's badge show rules to be observed today are:

(1) That, it be an instruction to all members of affiliated unions that they shall not work on a shift with any non-unionist (other than a recognised staff official) or with any member of an affiliated union not in possession of the recognised badge.
(2) Badge Show shall be confined to all members of the Barrier Industrial Council employed on the mines and in the city.
(3) No member shall commence work until such member has been okayed by the head steward.
(4) No member of an affiliated union shall commence work until the ``all clear'' signal is given by the head steward.
(5) Employees are instructed that they are to see that their plants are in a safe condition or handed over to some other responsible person before leaving the mine.
To report
(6) Members are asked to report to the stewards when they know of anyone who misses the badge show.
(7) Members are requested to note the new rule in reference to returning on another shift when sent home on Badge Show day.
(8) Members must wear badges in a conspicuous place visible to stewards for the whole of the working shift.

(9) In the case where a member may be on one shift up to the day of show and then at the last minute his shift is changed and he has not had time to see the secretary of his union in order to get his badge changed, the steward will take the badge number and check at the union office.
Authority to stewards:
This means only in case of wrong badges of members having already procured badges from the union secretary and forgotten to bring them to work.

This means that, if a man has obtained a badge from his union and has forgotten it the steward shall be authorised to allow the man to return home to get his badge. On his return, he must show the badge to the steward before starting work.
OK ticket
(10) In the case of a member's being absent from work on badge show day he must present an OK ticket to the steward within two days, the onus being on the man to find the steward.
(11) Case of members being sent home on badge show day, they are not allowed to work on any other shift of that day.
(12) Members must wear only current badges on badge show day.
(13) Badges can be collected up to the commencement of the shift.
Conspicuous
(14) Members are requested to pass the steward with badges in a conspicuous place on their clothing.
(15) Any member of any union failing to display his badge, or failing to pass the appointed places, or committing any breach of the foregoing resolution shall be fined.

(16) Any members of any union obstructing the stewards, or who insults the stewards, or in any way obstructs the smooth working of the badge show, shall be reported by the steward to the next meeting of the BIC immediately following the badge show, which shall decide the matter and shall have the authority to fine such member.

(17) QUICK SHIFT: Members on night shift on badge show day who are brought in on a quick shift report to their union secretary to get permission, which must be given to a steward before commencing work and the member must wear his previous badge during the quick shift.
Day's pay as fine
(18) Any member found guilty of working on badge show day without a badge shall be fined the equivalent of a day's pay.
The union of which the offender is a member is to be notified and the union held responsible for collecting the fine and forwarding it to the BIC.
Engine-drivers are to remain at the winders till all the men on the previous shift are raised: but not relieving men are to be lowered.

TALK.START.PARA: —The right to refuse to join a trade union is no less a basic human right than the right to join one. It is a right contained, as Senator Chaney referred to, in article 20 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights adopted by the United Nations. The article provides:

SPEECH.PARA: Everyone has the right to freedom of peaceful assembly and association. No-one may be compelled to belong to an association.
Having said that I will revert to badge show day at Broken Hill. I have incorporated all the rules in Hansard so I will refer to just some of the requirements:
The Barrier Industrial Council's badge show rules to be observed today are:
Badge Show shall be confined to all members of the Barrier Industrial Council employed on the mines and in the city.
The rule applies to members employed in the whole place. I continue:
No member of an affiliated union shall commence work until the `all clear' signal is given by the head steward.
Employees are instructed that they are to see that their plants are in a safe condition or handed over to some other person before leaving the mine.
Members are asked to report to stewards when they know of anyone who misses the badge show. Members must wear badges in a conspicuous place visible to stewards for the whole of the working shift.
This is an industrial ID card. The rules state:

In the case where a member may be on one shift up to the day of show then at the last minute his shift is changed and he has not had time to see the secretary of his union in order to get his badge changed, the steward will take the badge number and check at the union office.
The rules go on about authority to stewards and so on. Another rule states:
In case of a member's being absent from work on badge show day he must present an OK ticket to the steward within two days, the onus being on the man to find the steward.
Another rule states:
Any member of any union failing to display his badge-
his industrial ID card, and this is typical of closed shop preference clauses-
or failing to pass the appointed places, or committing any breach of the foregoing resolution shall be fined.
What does he get fined? The rules state:
Any member found guilty of working on badge show day without a badge shall be fined the equivalent of a full day's pay.

Australian workers have no statutory protection of the basic human right in the work place and this Bill provides none. It does make some noises about smoothing the rocky road for conscientious objectors to union membership, but it is still an extraordinarily difficult procedure. The very fact that workers must formally object to union membership proves that they are compelled to join unions. The very fact that they must object conscientiously and that they do not have the freedom to choose whether they wish to associate with an organisation is an infringement of the international human rights document.

I raise a fourth point which relates to union amalgamations. We do not agree with the Government's proposal for achieving reform through union amalgamations. We reject the paternalistic proposition that small unions should join large unions for their own good. We do not necessarily agree that there are too many unions in Australia. In fact, we would like to see a growth of enterprise-based unions where employer and employee speak to one another, where either side does not go out to seek the intervention of third parties who may be, in some cases, 400 or 500 miles away, and have no particular interest in the long term growth and prosperity of that particular company or industry.

Japan, which I referred to earlier and which is held up as having a model industrial relations system, has tens of thousands of unions. The problem is that any one enterprise in Australia has to deal with a number of unions and in other countries such as Japan, the enterprise deals with a single union. It is not necessary that a single union be involved. Single groups of unions could operate at the enterprise level with everyone with the same goal, everyone wanting to improve productivity, everyone wanting to get the rewards that come from increased productivity, and everyone wanting to see the organisation grow, not just from a monetary point of view but from the personal satisfaction that everyone gets from participating in a growth organisation. There is nothing more debilitating to management or to workers than seeing their organisation dying on its feet. We recognise the need to move to a system where each employer faces a single bargaining unit. Union amalgamations will not necessarily prevent union demarcation disputes. As mentioned by Senator Chaney, a survey of recent demarcation disputes shows that of 32 such disputes only one involved a union that would be affected by amalgamation.

I come to the final and major point-health and safety. In 1979 the Fraser Government removed from the Commission its power to act in respect of disputes involving strike pay. The Hancock Committee of Review of the Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems recommended that this discretion be returned to the Commission. This Bill returns limited discretion to the Commission where a claim over strike pay arises out of a dispute over health and safety, where the employer has not acted reasonably and the employees affected have maintained a reasonable control. One of the most offensive aspects of this is that the Hawke Labor Government is supporting the absurd notion that workers should be paid for not working. It is a basic right of workers to withdraw their labour. That is fair enough, but it is absolutely outrageous to suggest that they should be paid for striking, and that is precisely what this part of the Bill will encourage the Commission to involve itself in.

If strikes were legitimate no-one would be concerned, but health and safety strikes are historically and traditionally one of the arch rorts of many industries, particularly the building industry. The Australian Federation of Construction Contractors found, for instance, in its interim report on restrictive work practices in the building industry that alleged safety hazards frequently bring work on an entire building site to a halt. Employees will stop work until the complaint is resolved to their satisfaction or they may opt for a 24- or 48-hour stoppage. Under those conditions they get paid. But who suffers? Every Australian suffers. It will cost somebody something. There will be either a reduction in productivity or an increase in the capital cost of what is being constructed, which cost must be recovered later in some sort of rent. If it is in an export industry we all suffer.

Hence, the direction we would like to take is to get more and more consultation, discussions and agreements at the enterprise level, not by remote control and not by the industrial relations club. I see that Senator Cooney has come into the chamber. He lives in the city which is the centre of the industrial relations club. I am sure he is not part of it though; he is too decent. I can go through numerous examples. Employees have been known to stay away from a site for two days simply because a handrail was missing. This occurred after the handrail had been deliberately removed to create the so-called safety hazard. These are small examples of the things that happen. On the site of this Parliament House we are sitting in today, which is one of the most famous building sites of the century, we had strikes on health and safety grounds because there was no water in an urn or no toilet paper in the toilets, and so on. I could go on but time precludes me.

I sum up by saying that we in Australia must become more productive. We must restore confidence for investment in the productive wealth creating sector of the economy. We must rid ourselves overseas and domestically of the reputation we have as one of the worst and most unreliable countries in the world in regard to industrial disputation. We must lift our game and recognise that we are part of a highly competitive world economy. We must decentralise the decision-making process and put it back in the hands of the individual employees and employers at the enterprise level. This Bill entrenches in Australia a malaise which will guarantee, at best, mediocrity on the world stage or, at worst, a continuing deterioration in our standards of living.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should explain why I was not here earlier. Unfortunately, this new building, grand as it is, does not seem to have adequate lifts. I was trapped in a lift for 43 minutes. I am not too sure what we can say about private enterprise, employment or what have you. I thought to myself--
—They will do anything to stop you talking.

—They will; that is right. I hope that capital and labour get together to provide better lifts and a better form of communication in future. Senator Parer has talked about the shortcomings of workers and has said that there ought to be a different system.
—No-the system, not the workers.

—He corrects me now and says that what we need is another system. The Industrial Relations Bill 1988 superimposes on the traditional form of regulating of labour relations and of settling of disputes new and imaginative instruments which no doubt will contribute to industrial relations continuing as they have under this Government. The reality, whether we like it or not, is that under the present Government, with the cooperation of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) and the trade union movement generally, fewer working days were lost during 1987 than at any other time since 1967, so 176 working days per 1,000 employees were lost in 1967 compared with 223 last year.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia is now much more prosperous, is much better off and has better labour relations because of a responsible attitude taken by the trade union movement. If one can point to anything that has led to this recovery it is the trade union movement and the way it has adhered to the accord during the period this Government has been in office.

This Bill is the result of much work by the present Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) and it is a tribute to the way he has worked over the years in his present ministry. It was he, in many ways, who was the architect of the accord. When we point to the various Ministers who have made this a successful Government, the Minister who is often overlooked is Ralph Willis. He, as much as anyone, had much to do with the making of the accord between the Australian Labour Party and the union movement. It is that accord which has led to the economic turnabout in Australia. It has led to a relationship between employee, employer and Government which has not existed before in the history of this country. That is something to be proud of. Senator Parer suggests that in some way it is a bad thing that there should be this close relationship. But if in fact that relationship has led to the present situation, then in my view it is much to be praised.

In so far as Australia has recovered, it has recovered because of the sacrifices made by workers and by their unions. Senator Parer is suggesting that we ought to go to a new system, that in some way there ought to be a change from the traditional way of settling disputes in this country to a way that goes back at least to the time the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Act was first passed in 1904. That Act established the pattern for labour relations in Australia. That pattern is repeated in the Bill before us. The Bill does two things: first, it gives emphasis to conciliation and then arbitration to settle disputes when they arise between the parties; and, secondly, it makes conciliation and arbitration effective. It sets up employee and employer organisations.

The history of industrial relations in Australia is the history of how organisations have become more and more central to the resolution of industrial disputes. For example, the Burwood cinema case decided in 1925 said that a log of claims related not only to currently employed members but to other people who might be employed in the future and extended it to employees of employer respondents who were not dissatisfied with their wages and conditions. The metal trades case of 1935 extended that principle further and said that award conditions and rates of pay gained by unions would relate not only to members of those unions but to everybody employed in that industry. The whole concept then became one of the unions representing their members in the interests of the whole work force and, through that process, obtaining for them reasonable working conditions.

That is a central point to any labour relations conducted in this country. If we go to the decision of Mr Justice Higgins in the Harvester case, which was decided in Melbourne in 1907, it is interesting to see the sorts of things he had to say. He said that fair and reasonable remuneration must be looked at in terms of what the employee, the worker, needed to maintain a reasonable standard of living. He went on to say:

I do not regard it as my duty to fix a high wage, but a fair and reasonable wage, not a wage that is merely enough to keep body and soul together, but something between those two extremes . . . The employer can displace men by introducing machinery as he chooses. He can make the work as monotonous and mind-stupefying as he thinks to be for his advantage. He has an absolute power of choice of men and of dismissal. He is allowed, if my view of the Act is correct, to make any profits that he can and that they are not subject to investigation, but when he comes in the course of his economies to economise at the expense of human life, when his economy involves a withholding from his employees of reasonable remuneration, of reasonable conditions of human existence, then as I understand it the Act of Parliament insists on payment of excise duty.

Mr Justice Higgins was talking there of an Act separate from the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, but the principles are the same. In this day of economic rationalism what must be kept in mind is that people are entitled to a decent standard of living, that in spite of economic considerations it is correct that people should be paid a wage, not only to keep body and soul together, but also to enable them to live with dignity, to live as decent human beings ought to be allowed to live.

If we go from the Harvester case to a later case involving the Federated Municipal and Shire Employees Union of Australia and Melbourne Corporation we find this statement by two great judges of the High Court of Australia, Mr Justice Isaacs and Mr Justice Rich, which again put into context the problems that workers faced in the history of their employment and the suppression and oppression they have suffered. On page 555 of the report the two justices have this to say:

It is needless to trace the course of the industrial development by which the worker in a trade seeks to carry on a handicraft in which he naturally passed from apprentice to journeyman and then to master and became by force of the application of various interventions a mere animated cog in the capitalist machine. What is called in the industrial revolution of the latter part of the 18th century, and particularly of the 19th century, so transformed his position as to drive him into combination . . .
into the unions, in other words. The judgment continues:
The details of the struggle which led to the Acts of 1825, 1871, 1875, 1896 and 1906 in England would be tedious.
Those Acts deal with the establishment of unions as the proper instrument of workers response to the oppression that they might otherwise face. The judgment goes on:

But the broad fact that emerges is that the position of industrialists by a singular reversal of what has been thought to be the general current of history has been gradually changed from one of the pure contract to one of status . . . The industrial revolution made the workman's labour a mere marketable commodity to be bought at the lowest price as individual competition between workers would permit. The degradation and the suffering that ensued, the revolt against the system, the repression of illegal acts, the amelioration of the law, the organisation of labour, the gradual recognition of collective bargaining, the introduction of private conciliation and arbitration as well as of industrial laws securing better conditions for workers are all well known historical facts. From about 1882 to 1896 industrial conditions in Australia by reason of sweating and strikes had received great public and parliamentary attention.

During that period the Constitution was drafted and finally accepted by the people of Australia. One of the main planks in section 51 was the settlement of disputes beyond one State. From that the Commonwealth Parliament drew its power to set up the original Conciliation and Arbitration Act which, as I said before, depends on two concepts, conciliation and arbitration and, to enable that to take place, the setting up of both employer and employee organisations. That has worked successfully since then.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why are you forcing some out of existence because of this Bill?

—Senator Harradine asks most legitimately why we are forcing some of those unions out of existence-in other words, why we are saying that unions cannot be registered unless they have at least 3,000 members. I take it that that is what Senator Harradine is referring to.
—Organisations, whether employer or union.

—I think employer organisations can be registered with as few as 1,000 members. That is done in terms of where we have got to at this point in the history of labour relations. Union and employer organisations-Senator Harradine would no doubt agree with this-depend for their effectiveness on their ability properly to represent workers. They need a certain amount of income, research staff and the ability to put the case of the workers strongly before the tribunals and, if necessary, to take industrial action. This Bill provides for those organisations to be strong enough to carry out those functions, but those unions which are smaller than the provisions allow for in this Bill are not effective. If they are, then there is provision in this Bill to enable the Commission to deal with them. So it is a matter of efficiency. It is a matter of ensuring that unions represent their workers as effectively as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 100 is central to the Bill. It deals with the question of conciliation. The heading states that disputes are to be dealt with by conciliation where possible. If that is not possible, then procedures are taken to arbitration. The Bill sets up ways in which unions can become registered under the Act and have the ability properly to represent their workers. In this context I turn to the question of Mudginberri. Mudginberri has been claimed as a great victory for the forces of the New Right. What the union was asserting in the Mudginberri case was its right to know what negotiations were taking place between employers and employees in its industry whenever they were taking place. After the union's action that right was accorded to it. The law recognises that the knowledge of what people within an industry are doing is central to the way a union operates.

We were looking at the question of organisations. As Senator Harradine has said, the Bill provides that a certain number of people must be in a union before it can be registered. In addition, the Bill enables unions to amalgamate. It is proper, for the reasons I have suggested to Senator Harradine, that unions amalgamate and that their ability to do so is made easier. If there is a community of interest between two unions and those two unions then make an application to the Commission, and the Commission through its President or presidential member approves, then a simple vote is held; and if a majority of those in both organisations vote for the proposal, an amalgamation takes place. If there is not a community of interest, then at least 25 per cent of the members of each organisation have to vote and half of those that do vote, plus one, are sufficient to bring the amalgamation about.

I spoke before of the necessity for any wage-fixing body to take into account what workers need to live in decent fashion. Over the last few years real wages have fallen, but what has been done or what in any event has been attempted is to preserve at least a basic wage which will enable workers to live with dignity. But there have crept in-and, indeed, they have now been established-other considerations for the Commission to take into account when it is considering an appropriate wage. Under clause 90, the Commission has to take into account public interest, the state of the national economy, and the likely effects of decisions on the level of employment and on inflation. It is always necessary for the Commission, in determining wages, to balance the interests of the community against the interests of the people who are receiving a level of wages at the hands of the Commission.

It would be wrong to regard labour and workers simply as commodities and to concentrate, as some do, solely on the state of the economy, on the state of inflation, and on the level of employment. There are other issues to be taken into account. These other issues are part of the traditions of wage fixing. Those are the sorts of considerations that Mr Justice Higgins took into account and the sorts of considerations that judges of the High Court of Australia, such as Mr Justice Isaacs and Mr Justice Rich, have taken into account in the past. They must be taken into account in the future. There is in this Bill provisions for parties to enter into agreements. Clause 115, in part, reads:
If the parties to an industrial dispute or any of them agree on terms for the settlement of all or any of the matters in dispute, they may make a memorandum of the terms agreed on.
Agreements can be made, subject always to the approval of the Commission, so that no unconscionable wages are paid-wages must enable people to live with dignity.

Another issue which this legislation addresses, as set out in clauses 13, 14 and 15, is the dual systems of industrial relations in Australia. We have both Federal and State systems. That has proved to be a clumsy way of dealing with industrial issues. This Bill, if it becomes an Act, will enable people who staff the Federal Commission to also sit as State appointees. It is of course necessary for both the Federal Government and the States concerned to appoint people to that tribunal. If that is done it will lead to a much more sensible resolution of disputes. The Bill further provides that the people who staff the Federal bodies meet with the people who staff the State bodies and discuss with them issues of common interest so that the State system and the Federal system at least know what the other is doing.

Clauses 194, 195 and the following clauses deal with the rules of organisations. I note that the rules of an organisation may allow for collegiate voting. Collegiate voting is allowed under this Bill, but I think it is time that direct voting was the only voting allowed. I will rephrase what I am saying: I think it is time that collegiate voting be not allowed and that the only thing that is allowed is direct voting for the officers of organisations. I cannot see, in this day and age when unions are expected more and more to be democratic institutions, that there is a place for collegiate voting. I have a concern with that. However, the Bill allows collegiate voting to take place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you say the same for the Prime Minister of Australia?

—I simply say that most unions do provide for the election of their officers, presidents and secretaries by the direct voting of the members. After all, the members pay fees and it is proper that they should directly determine the officers that will govern the affairs of the organisation.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the heading `Rules of the Organisation' what is required of unions is set out. It can be seen from this that unions are amongst the most democratic institutions in this community. Their members must undergo elections at least every four years. Members of a union have effective rights to question what their officers do. That there is talk here of unions not conforming to the will of their members is extraordinary, given the obligations on union leadership as set out in this Bill.

Another thing I want to say is that this Bill allows for preference clauses to be inserted into awards. Great criticism is made of that. I say that, where people pay their union fees and where unions struggle to obtain proper conditions and wages for their members, it is proper that those people who are members of the union and who are willing to support, financially and in other ways, that organisation which obtains proper conditions for all workers be given preference in employment.

It is said by the Opposition that people should simply have the right to join or not to join a union and that in some ways whether they are members of a union should make absolutely no difference to their entitlements. That approach attacks the whole concept of an organisation which represents the workers, obtains conditions for them and looks after their needs. The whole of the industrial relations tradition in Australia is based on the concept that unions and employer organisations will get together to work out what is a proper wage and what are proper conditions, given the needs of the workers and the needs of the economy. People who attack that system are attacking a system that has served this country well over many decades.

This legislation represents a rewriting of the industrial relations provisions of this country. The Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission will now, in effect, be renamed the Industrial Relations Commission. It sets out, as I say, all of those things that have served the country, the union movement and employers over the years, and served them well. It has added new provisions. It has added a new way of amalgamation. The Bill has written into it matters that can be taken into account when the Commission considers its decisions, such as the state of the economy and the level of unemployment. The other thing it does, which is new, is to give recognition to peak councils, such as the ACTU or the Confederation of Australian Industry, so that they are brought into the actual ambit of the Act and can more securely represent the point of view of their constituents before the tribunals.

The legislation is a substantial monument to a Minister who has served Australia well and who has served the industrial relations scene well. As he leaves the portfolio, having been an architect of the accord, this Industrial Relations Bill, soon to become an Act, will be a worthy monument to his efforts on behalf of the industrial relations system of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening we are debating the Industrial Relations Bill 1988. Because of the time I will be able only very briefly to cover some of the points this evening. This current Industrial Relations Bill, as we know, is the culmination of years of ducking and weaving on the part of the Hawke Government in its approach to industrial relations. The legislation before the Senate represents the attempt by the Government to disguise the fact that, when it comes to industrial relations, it will do nothing to offend its Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) paymasters, and it will do what it can to weaken effective sanctions against trade union power. That is something that I think Australians should be very much aware of. That is the thrust of this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Even those observers who are prepared to accept that the Hawke Government has in some areas moved away from its socialist sacred cows are not in the least impressed by its industrial record. Let us face it: that industrial record can now be seen by all to be anything but satisfactory. In particular, it fails to stand up to the pretensions of the ACTU, or actively abets it in its desire to put back the industrial clock. We must remember how much this Government seeks to consult with the ACTU before anything is done. Whether it be in the industrial relations area, wages or any other such areas, the ACTU and Simon Crean are the ones who ultimately make the decision-not the Government, not the people, but the ACTU.

The only good thing that can be said about this Bill is that it is less destructive than the 1987 legislation that was seen to be such an electoral disaster by the Government itself that it was withdrawn on the eve of the 1987 election. The Government has accepted that neither employers nor the Australian public would accept the removal of common law remedies from the industrial scene when it has been proven time and time again that these are the only effective means of injecting commonsense and basic justice into industrial relations.

How pathetic it is of this Government to attack employers for alleged intransigence in forcing the backdown over the question of removal of access to sections 45d and 45e of the Trade Practices Act and, of course, other forms of civil law protection. To use a blunt term, did it really expect that employers, especially small businessmen, had come down in the last shower? Who would expect Australian businesses to give away legal protection that has been seen to work, at Mudginberri, in the Dollar Sweets Co. Pty Ltd dispute and in various other disputes, in favour of small employers against the evil of secondary picketing, and put their trust in some new labour court that is likely to follow the traditions of the industrial relations club, wagging its finger at unions while it sends businesses to the wall? We all know that the union movement has been instrumental in ensuring that many small businesses have been sent to the wall. If this Government wants to continue that practice, it does so at its own risk.

The Australian public would not have accepted such a capitulation to union power. The Government has retreated from its original Bill because it did not want to write its own political death warrant. Let us not forget that it withdrew the Bill on the eve of the last election because it knew that it was electorally unsaleable. Of course, what we are left with, in the form of this Bill, is the attempt by the Government to salvage something to appease and please the ACTU. It is, therefore, a Bill that either fails to enhance protection for the small employer and the individual worker or erodes the rights of individuals, smaller organisations and, of course, the public. It is, therefore, to be expected that there are no new and effective compliance provisions made available to the Industrial Relations Commission. The Government blames the employers for their rejection of the 1987 package. The Government should not blame the employers. The Government simply wanted to get re-elected. It knew that it could not do so with such a Bill.

It is obvious who makes the final decisions in industrial relations when we look at a statement made by Simon Crean on 17 August last year. As President of the ACTU, he made it quite clear that any industrial relations Bill would have to be one that did nothing to enforce compliance. Unchanged monetary level penalties ensure that existing compliance provisions will be ineffective, underscoring the importance of civil court remedies. Of course, we cannot be too surprised that this legislation will do nothing to promote voluntarism in the Australian industrial scene. The limitations of the Hawke Government once again become obvious in a question that threatens the interests of union officials as opposed to those of the ordinary Australian workers-workers who should have a choice, but workers who, under the ACTU, have no choice whatsoever.

This Bill continues to impose effective restrictions on the right of workers not to belong to unions. That is a further removal of their freedom of choice. It remains necessary to prove conscientious objection to the joining of any union, without allowing objection to a particular union. If that is freedom of choice, I will go he. There is no freedom of choice; to have to prove conscientious objection in this day and age is absolutely outrageous. It therefore continues to contravene article 20 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, the second clause of which states unequivocally that, `no one may be compelled to belong to an association'. The fact that it contravenes that article of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights means nothing to this Government. It is quite happy yet again to appease the ACTU. The Government cannot afford to concede any ground on this matter because its ACTU masters will be very conscious of the Australian Bureau of Statistics survey that showed a decline in the unionisation of the work force between 1976 and 1986, from 51 per cent to 46 per cent. Of course, if real choice were given, it would decline even further. So it is quite obvious that the Government is not prepared to bite the bullet on these hard issues. It is prepared only to go along with softening certain edges, and the softening has not taken place to any great degree in this Bill.

Mr President, I will complete my remarks tonight at that point because of time constraints, but tomorrow I will continue to make more points which show how this Government's Bill is a very weak and washy attempt to appease people in industrial relations.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 April 1988 (Hansard, page 1958), Senator Watson asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Minister aware of the provisions of section 26 (e) of the Income Tax Assessment Act, and other provisions, which make it clear that income earned through shares issued under an executive incentive measure are fully assessable as part of the taxpayer's income, although maybe on a deferred basis?
The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Commissioner of Taxation has advised that section 26aac of the Income Tax Assessment Act operates to include a benefit received under an employee share acquisition scheme as assessable income. The benefit is measured by reference to the amount by which the value of the shares at the time they were acquired by the employee exceeds the consideration given for them. Section 26aac has no further application in respect of any additional gain that the recipient may make from the subsequent sale of those shares (i.e., where the sale price is higher than the value of the shares at the time they were acquired).
The operation of section 26 (e) is expressly excluded by subsection 26aac (10).
The question of whether any further profit not already caught by section 26aac is assessable will depend on the particular facts of each individual case.
